description:
Note that this place is cash only!

My friends and I came craving for soup and read that this place was a good spot. The soup was delicious and they have a big menu to chose from.

I got the duck wonton. The was good and very tasty. It only had a few pieces of duck but the broth was great.
author: Anarie S.

description:
Won-Ton House...They were inexpensive?  

I'm not sure why we ventured out for dinner.  Our hotel was feeding us hors d'oeuvres every night.  We weren't really hungry.  Since I had this place bookmarked, and the price was cheap, I decided that we needed to come here.  They are a typical Cantonese place.  They weren't too busy when we showed up at about 8 PM, and were quickly seated.  We ordered a couple of their won ton Noodles soups.  With "Won Ton" in their name, I assumed that their won tons were good.  Never make assumptions.  Their won tons were average and contained more pork than shrimp.  The soup?  It's Cantonese...and is typical MSG soup.  Yeah, I'm struggling to write more about them.  They were pretty quick and cheap.  Yes, I've experienced better. I can skip this place and stay at my hotel for free less than mediocre food.   2 1/2 stars.
author: Phil Y.

description:
The current 3.5 star rating Won-Ton-House currently holds is quite accurate. It's priced reasonably and the wonton soup is pretty average. That's not really a bad thing, but in my opinion, if you're going to call Won-Ton-House, I would think your wontons should be pretty spectacular. 

Note: This place is cash only and has a $3 minimum per person
author: Charles L.

description:
A pretty simple restaurant awaits you here, nothing fancy, large tables, okay staff. The menu is somewhat limited, but still has a small variety of items. It wasn't busy at the 5pm hour, so everything was quick. Prices are also pretty cheap.

I got the fish cake noodle soup. It's not the largest serving, but for about $6 it's decent. There's a good portion of noodles and toppings. The broth looks fine but I was expecting something better as it lacked a little flavor.

For a quick, cheap meal this is the place to go to.
author: Spencer H.

description:
Super legit Chinese restaurant for comfort food. I was in the neighborhood and was craving for something light but warm, so I walked in to check the menu out.  I got the beef porridge which completely hit the spot for a foggy day in SF.  

No frills, CASH ONLY, happy tummy.
author: Lyn C.

description:
Hole in the wall late night eats? This place has you covered. The place is called Won Ton House so that's exactly what you need to order. 

The won tons are deee-licious! Stuffed with loads of pork and shrimp, this was perfect on a winter night, with or without noodle.
author: Lloyd B.

description:
If you get chicken here, make sure it's cooked. They served me cold, undercooked chicken. Yuck! At least it's just 10 minutes from this place to the nearest emergency room at UCSF in case you get food poisoning. 

They also don't take credit cards in 2018. In an age of free credit card readers that plug into a cell phone, you have to ask why they're doing that. (3% credit card fees are offset by customers spending more, and more customers coming through the door.)
author: Al S.

description: Porridge and bbq pork taste bad , I ate 1 piece of bbq pork , it smells stinky and taste likes moldy meat ! Finally I leave the whole plate bbq pork on the table ! I won't go there again !! Never
author: Bing L.

description:
I was hungry for something cheap like wonton soup and this random stranger on the street recommended this place as a good spot for wonton when he caught me talking out loud. Given the name of the place, I trust it. He described it as low-key and cheap or something along those lines.

Prices are cheap. Cash only. Wonton noodles hit the spot for me. I also had the pan-fried turnip cakes and it's rare to be able to get some dim sum items at 10PM at night. Turnip cakes were good, fried to perfection. 

The place looks clean enough. Yes, there was a dead bug floating in my tea but that wouldn't turn me away yet. They also seem to have a nice porridge selection so this might be a good place to get food for when I'm too sick to chew.
author: Diana C.

description: This is my go to place for won ton noodle soup and beef stew hor fun. It is the closest won tons i can get that is close to the Guangzhou or Hong Kong styles. Noodles are freshly made and is just delicious. Would be perfect if they comply to their business hours instead of closing when they should be open.
author: WeR5 L.

description:
I never noticed this place despite always eating at the other restaurants on the same block. For the first time in a long time, this place caught my eye and we decided to try it. This place had plenty of seats late at night, so we sat down and looked at the menu right away. This place is cash only, but everything on the menu is cheap. Pretty much the whole menu is less than $10 per dish which is rare in SF.

My friend ordered the gnaw jap wonton noodle soup, I ordered the bbq pork (cha siew) wonton noodle soup, and my friend ordered noodles with bbq pork and duck. The portions for everything was HUGE. There's no way that one person can finish their dish and still be hungry.

As for my dish, the bbq pork could be a little more fresh. They were generous with the amount though. The wonton was delicious and the broth was even better. Next time I'd be satisfied with ordering a wonton noodle soup without any additional items.

Will be here a little more often now when it is cold and gloomy.
author: Julian Y.

description:
Your typical local neighborhood joint. Great food. Cash only.

We don't live near here but stumbled upon this little gem. It is definitely a no frills neighborhood place and reminds me of a lot of the restaurants back in Hong Kong. 

Ordered their ngow jaap (beef stomach and innards) and wonton noodle soup. The ngow jaap is flavorful and delicious. It's not too chewy and no too soft. The wontons are well made and delicious as well. There is a piece of shrimp in every wonton. I didn't get the traditional egg noodles but opted for the thicker egg noodles. I didn't know they had ho fan or else I would have gotten that.

We also ordered some turnip cake and it was yummy. It would have used a little more sear on each side for crisp but I still ate all of it.

Will def come back to try everything on the menu. Chinese comfort food at it's best!!
author: Junella T.

description:
Nothing fancy except solid, comfort homey Cantonese food. Yummy wontons, congee, beef brisket.. you name it! I've been here a bunch of times whenever I feel homesick or just want some authentic Chinese food. 

The food comes out quickly too :)
author: Claudia C.

description: I used to come here all the time with my friends on Thursday nights for a quick cheap bite, but I see that they raised their prices :/ They're definitely still reasonable though. We got the won ton noodle soup ($5.75) and fish ball noodle soup ($6.15). You can substitute the egg noodles for the flat white rice noodles at no additional charge. The won tons didn't taste that great to me. We also ordered the spicy beef tripe ($5.25) and the pig ears ($5.25). There's never a wait, so this is a good option for fast and cheap food.
author: Nicole M.

description:
My favorite porridge I've had in the city so far . I crave the roasted duck porridge from time to time especially with the weather around here. I also like that this place is super affordable (always incredibly full with leftovers for under $10 / person). For some reason I've been finding it harder than I thought to find good, cheap food...

Service: I always go with my friend who speaks Cantonese so I don't know what they're saying but the lady always greets me and is smiley and nice. She's also very attentive to your tea / water and service is always quick. 5/5

Food: I've liked pretty much everything I've had here and it's very consistent. The only thing I can say is there are noodle things a little over cooked and a fried flat noodle dish that wasn't really fried. But all their meats and side dishes are awesome. I'll just review our food from tonight..
BBQ pork rice dish: very flavorful and rice was perfect. One or two pieces that were a little too fatty but overall delicious. It's also a gigantic plate. The only reason we finished is my friend can eat A LOT. 4/5
Roast duck porridge: perfect rice soup ratio and the duck is so deliciousssss. When I eat something I like I get really excited and this soup makes me do a happy dance. It always hits the spot and I could get fat eating these succulent pieces. Also perfect amount of fresh green onion to offset the juicy duck. 5/5
author: Anna N.

description:
Not a fancy restaurant but legit Asian/Oriental cuisine. Service was very good. Seated quickly and food came out quick as well.

How do I explain that in Asian culture, customer service is not.... well, to be quite frank, there is no customer service. Hahaa!! I don't have an issue with it. It's more about the food than service to me. Not a complaint, just an observation. 

Looking around everyone's table, looks like the duck with egg noodle soup is quite popular. So I had to try it as well. My date requested for wonton soup but got duck & wonton. He was surprised & couldn't finish the duck not because he didn't like duck, but he was stuffed with wontons, which he said were delicious! The duck soup was excellent! Think this might be their specialty. 

This is going to be a go to for a late night munchies run... an after a night out on the town when it's cold outside and needs hot soup type of spot. Love that it's walking distance. 

I'd recommend this spot to duck, wonton & soup lovers.

So if you're expecting kiss-ass customer service, you ain't getting it anywhere in this neighborhood. It's more about quality food. 
My type of service. My hood! Hahaa!!
author: Anh L.

description:
I really wish I could give this mom-and-pop shop a better review, but I found the food to be mediocre. I came with a couple friends, one who was vegetarian. Usually Asian places offer a few vegetarian dishes but the only option this restaurant had was just a giant plate of Chinese broccoli. We were so hungry that we just decided to stay and order. 

My friend ordered the giant plate of veggies which were just steamed broccoli in oyster sauce and I ordered the won-ton noodle soup. I was super disappointed because I was hoping to get a traditional-style soup (the way my mom makes it), but unfortunately what I got was completely different. The noodles were really tough and the broth itself tasted so off. It just tasted like a light broth with a lot of salt added to it. 

If they ever make any changes, I'd definitely be down to try this place out again just because I feel like there's so much potential.
author: Andrea K.

description: Inexpensive and delicious all in one big bowl of noodle soup! This is a cash only place so be prepared. The interior is has a hint of homey feeling. I usually get beef tendon wonton egg noodle soup. The broth is perfect for those cold long days after work. It just rejuvenates me back to life. The tendon is perfectly boiled until it's perfectly tender. The wonton is delicious with the mix of pork and shrimp. I always love home made wonton. You get to really taste the creativity in the person who made it.
author: Ada H.

description: Was this place always owned by the same people? I came here because of the tantalizing pictures, but what I received was decidedly not in the same vein. The spicy Szechuan noodle soup I got was weird. It had a very Progresso canned soup taste to it. The meat had this weird artificial red hue to it. My meal was super cheap, and the experience matched the price tag.
author: Yu Z.

description:
Two things I look for in a won ton house:
1)it's open late
2)it has good won ton
The won ton is fatty and the soup is filled with MSG but that's what makes it taste so good. Plus you can't beat the prices.
author: William B.

description: Went w/ my breakfast club for lunch here past week.  Wonton was huge but bland w/ no taste.  Their beef stew over lo-mein was very good.  Other dishes o.k.. Price very reasonable and service good!
author: Denis Y.

description: Craving noodle soup? This is the place. Filled with locals at lunch time and carries some basics. They also have jook and some other items, a simple menu that gets the food out hot and quick. It's cash only so be ready. Also love that you get hot tea automatically.
author: Pamela M.

description:
SMELLS LIKE A CESSPOOL!!!!

Walked in here for food and left within three minutes. Do not ignore the cockroach photos or the recent story of someone eating here who found A DEAD BUG IN THEIR TEA.

Value your health STAY AWAY!!!
author: Charles B.

description:
Old school old school !! Yup right on the spot.. for my tummy lol.. and open till midnight too.. 
tasty beef stew and shrimp pork wontons... yes other items on menu is great too.. portion huge.. serve hot .. wow .. I will be dreaming of this place again..
author: Crisy G.

description: You can't beat low price, quality food that is open late; especially after drinking at the bars across the street. I had the brisket noodle soup and it was delicious! Not too fatty on the brisket. Noodles still had a little bite. And the soup was tasty and not salty. Best thing of all, it was clean.
author: Nick N.

description:
Not sure why this place only has 3.5 stars. It's delicious and cheap!  

I have been going to this restaurant since I was a child. It's Chinese comfort foot. Their wonton fun noodle soup is amazing. If you are willing to try it, their beef stomach (organ) fun noodle soup is even better! Add vinegar. And use their hot sauce on the table, the one sitting in the oil-- its not something you can easily purchase at the store. 

Also, try the turnip cake. In my opinion, its the best turnip cake in the city.
author: Ong-Dee W.

description: Exactly what you would expect from a good won ton place. My ngao nom (beef stew) won ton noodle soup was delicious! Very tender beef and tendon and a generous portion. The won tons were plump and tasty, there were 6 of them. The noodles were cooked to perfect tenderness. The soup was flavorful and not too salty.  Perfect comfort food, only $7.95!
author: Nellie J.

description:
WONTED SOME WONTONS~

CUSTOMER SERVICE: 3/5. No check ups, but at least we got hot tea on the house, quick orders and food plus everything is super cheap!

FOOD:
ROASTED DUCK NOODLES: 4/5. Small portion but the duck was delicious. Nice, chewy and about 4-5 big pieces in my soup. The soup was a bit bland but nothing black pepper and some sriracha can't fix. 

SHRIMP DUMPLING SOUP: 4/5. Big dumplings about 4-5 but still bland soup base. 

OVERALL: 4/5. Clean, plenty of tables and everything was cheap. Not the greatest food but it was okay.
author: Nikki B.

description: Pretty solid wonton and dumpling noodle soups. They are fast and cheap, good for those nights coming home late from work and don't have time to cook.
author: Mimi T.

description:
So many better options out there. It's like the place hasn't changed in 50 years. The floors and tables are sticky, the kind of sticky from the accumulation of grease from the open kitchen. Speaking of the kitchen, it's not really the cleanest state of the art facility out there. People are praising a  health score of 85?? Really? 

There's really only two good reasons to come here. You are desperate for noodles or jook/congee and this is the only place open. 

So I was recently both of these reasons, and grabbed beef stew noodles, two jooks, and some wontons. The beef stew was stringy and not very tender. Taste wasn't very good; star anise and spices were off. The two jooks were semi decent, it's just that you can tell the quality of ingredients are low. There's a reason for the cheap prices, you know. The wontons were plain "bleh". 

Haven't been here in maybe 2-3 years. Now I remember why.
author: Dom L.

description: Got roast duck to go and it was the worst order from a restaurant I can remember. It was all bones, fat, and skin. Hardly any meat in the whole container. Completely inedible.  And it was cold! even though they had me wait 15 minutes. I've never such an experience before, I had to throw the whole thing out and just not have dinner.
author: Eliyahu B.

description: Nostalgic more than anything. Ive been coming here since i was a little girl. Always get the beef and wonton noodle soup. Not the cleanest most asthetically pleasing place but if you want some good cheap chinese food this is the place to be. CASH ONLY.
author: Melissa K.

description:
This is the Chinese version of a western diner and I absolutely love that unique atmosphere. Food is good not great, but you come here for the typical Chinese comfort foods. Plus, it's super cheap and filling! We paid less than 30 bucks for four items.

We got two wonton bowls, one with ho fun and shrimp dumplings and the other with wontons and wonton noodles. I much prefer the ho fun but the soup was kind of bland. Shrimp dumplings were better than the wontons. They had much more flavor and tasted more fresh.

Also got the steamed dumplings and fish porridge. Porridge was standard, but the dumplings were a bit disappointing. Filling was more like the kind you'd find in potstickers. The skin was too thick and doughy. 

Service is very fast and friendly. 

Come here for the cheap noodle soups and porridge, they're the best Chinese comfort food items!
author: Mary X.

description: Stinky. Urine. Fishy. 3 words to describe the smell of this restaurant. We went ahead and ordered to go to give them the benefit of the doubt. Took two bites, closed it up and threw it away. Eating at In N Out now. Should have came here in the first place instead of Won Ton House
author: Ed M.

description:
This place reminds me of the Chinese equivalent of an American Diner. There's lots of regulars who show up to eat alone while reading the paper, the decor is basic, and the food is cheap and comforting. Was able to try the dumplings, the won-ton noodle soup, shrimp dumpling noodle soup, and fish porridge. Everything was A-OK, not spectacular but not bad. Not sure what the difference between Wontons and Shrimp Dumplings were but the Shrimp Dumpling is definitely better tasting (Seemed like they both had the same type of filling)

Price was very cheap and the food reminds me of childhood. I could probably lounge around here for a few hours.
author: Daniel C.

description: My go to place. I crave everything they make there. It is the ultimate comfort food place at an affordable price!! Love the tea, porridge, veggies, won ton, and everything else. Closes at midnight too, so I can squeeze in my 3rd dinner. I somehow always manage to make room for Won-Ton House.
author: Emily C.

description: Just left this restaurant and paid $28 for two orders of schezwan beef over noodles and won ton soup.  We asked what was in the won tons and was told PORK!  Wrong! Pork and shrimp with some horrible broth with overwhelming taste of fish of some sort.  The schezwan beef and noodles came and it reminded me of hot canned dog food over noodles.  None of this did we eat we left the entire meal paid the bill and left.  We ordered pot stickers as well but did not wait from them to arrive just paid for them and left based on the most horrible food I have ever eat in my life!  Do yourself a favor and just avoid this place.  It's open late but you'll be sorry!
author: San Francisco D.

description: If you grew up in the sunset or richmond districts, this place is comfort.  Nothing fancy...cash only and know what you want.
author: Dan S.

description:
Sigh, I wish I wrote my review for this place when I was 10 cause this used to be the spot growing up!!! Wonton house was always my favorite.
In fact, it's right next to my favorite bun place and there used to be a crepe shop next door that I'd frequent as well after school or camp. 

15 years later, things clearly have changed. This place is not as good as I remember it and not as clean either :( Service is average considering this is more of a cafe and there was a bunch of flies flying around our table the entire time -_- 

I got their fish ball and wonton noodle soup which is kind of my go-to but their fish balls were super salty and the wonton didn't taste handmade :( we also got this fried turnip which was probably the best part of the meal. 

Overall, this place is probably good for small snacks but it's nothing like I how remembered it before. I probably won't be back unless it's simply for nostalgic reasons. Even then, I'll opt for the buns next door which is still amazing after all these years
author: Shelly W.

description:
Cash only. Basically a no-frills Chinese restaurant, where the food is cheap (ish) and the cleanliness is questionable. 

Honestly, I was not impressed by the rice porridge. The fish rice porridge ($8!!) had just a few meager pieces of white fish and green onions. Also, there was a layer of glimmering oil on top, making this supposedly healthy dish not that clean tasting at all. The overall porridge had a faint yellow tint, rather than the signature white look of rice. The texture was also super watery with no hints of rice grains. Would not order again. 

Bf had the BBQ pork pan fried noodles. EXTREMELY oily with very little pork. 

Overall three stars for now until I come back and try more dishes... maybe.
author: Samantha C.

description:
My friend from out of town was visiting me and he wanted to go to a  Won-Ton place in the city and we chose Won-Ton-House. We wanted to go somewhere with parking and boba/dessert places nearby after dinner.


I ordered Curry Beef tendons noodle soup and turnip came for appetizers to share with my friend. 

*Turnip Cake - Small and it was not as good as I hoped it was. There are minimal pieces of turnip so  all you could taste was the flour
*Curry Beef Tendon Noodle Soup -Served in a bowl with the same designs that you would find at your grandparent's house. The portion was just enough (which is probably why it is cheap). The broth was just bland and the tendons did not have any curry taste to it at all. 

Ambiance - Lots of seating and casual chinese restaurant with not much decor but still comfortable and cozy

Service - The waitress was attentive and kept refilling our cups with tea. Took our order quickly and food came out within 10 minutes.

The reviews saying that this place used to be much better is true. I haven't came here before buy my mom told me she use to come here all the time. However, the food isn't so great anymore so she stopped coming here.

Overall, i wouldn't mind coming back if I am looking for a cheap quick meal to fill up my belly. Besides that, there are plenty of other restaurants nearby.
author: Allie Y.

description:
This little gem is one of my favorites in the whole city.  I've been coming here since I was a kid. Parking around noriega can be tough at peak dinner hours during the week and all day during weekends, so if you are in a hurry I would highly recommend calling in for take out, dragging someone with you, and have them run in to pick up your food. This is a real no nonsense place to get cheap, pretty good comfort food. 

*Cash only

Food - 4/5
My family usually gets the bbq pork wonton with noodles, porridge, duck/ bbq pork rice plates ,and "Chinese tamales"
The theme of all of the dishes is that they are simple, but good. 

Service - 3/5
This place is usually never busy when I come, so service is pretty quick. Only real knock is that you need to flag someone down if you need something. You always get hot tea to start. 

Ambience - 3/5
It has a pretty homey feel and can accommodate  groups. Since it is usually not packed it is great to come in on a cold day and grab soup.
author: Ryan J.

description: Came here on a week night with my boyfriend. It's never crowded here and the price is cheap. You can get a bowl of wonton soup for about $5+. The wonton soup is simple, it really just has the wonton in soup. I wish it had some veggies tho lol. My boyfriend ordered the wonton soup with bbq pork and it tasted a better and has more flavor. This is a definitely a go to place if you're in a rush or just want something warm on a cold day. Another plus is that they open late! So if you got that late night munchie and don't want to eat fast food, you should check this place out!
author: Monica W.

description:
We were out and about on a weekday, it was late and this place seemed to be one of the few places open in the neighborhood.

We sat down and ordered two soups which were somewhat reasonably priced, I got a won ton noodle soup and my fiance got a fish ball soup.
My won-ton soup was pretty good, nothing out of this world, my fiance enjoyed her fish ball soup as well.

The reason why I'm giving this place 4 stars is 
1. Its nice to have a place that closes late on weekdays in the neighborhood.
2. The food was actually decent.
author: Josh Giosue D.

description:
This is always a good idea. Their porridge are so good. Surprisingly I like their porridge better than their noodles. Be careful which kind of noodle you choose, my bf chose the one that was not Cantonese and it was not very good (its like pho noodle) and he is NOT a picky eater. Hence, he finished it for the sake of finishing, like I said not picky, but he did not enjoy it very much.

Tip: The thin noodles are good, they are either called shrimp noodle or egg noodle. The ones that are yellow, chewy and thin. That's Cantonese style. The thick white rice ones are very hard to make good and it's not very good here.

Their won-tons are of a good size and price. For two people, two entrees and an appetizer is usually less than $20 so this is always a good idea if you're looking to eat a good amount without over spending.

Remember though, they are CASH only. I come back whenever I'm hungry and in the sunset area. When I'm not here I'm at Tofu Village.
author: Kimberly W.

description: Saw the biggest rat in my life running around the restaurant. Didnt pay didnt complain just left.
author: Mark K.

description:
Had an early dinner on a Sunday evening around 6pm. This place has two big Chinese characters meaning "porridge" and "noodle" on the windows - which really assimilates to some authentic Hong Kong local restaurants decorations.

The menu looks pretty extensive but basically they are just combinations of repeated items over rice, noodle, porridges etc. 

#Beef Brisket Wonton Noodle: B++.
Pretty nice. Beef brisket was tender. Noodle was spongy. Soup was classic wonton noodle soup with lots of MSG (which is pretty authentic I guess..) Wonton skin was pretty thin however the only thing I would have wanted for improvement was the size of wonton ingredients - it's definitely on the (very) small side.

Overall, a low cost and quite authentic wonton noodle house. When I want to get some quick and cheap bites in the Sunset area this is going to be on top of my list.
author: Simon C.

description:
Check this out for yourselves. This is a clean space with a Health Safety score of 85 serving above average food. They are open late, the service is very good and for what they provide, the price being under $10 is inexpensive. 

At $9.95 the Won Ton Noodle with BBQ Pork and the addition of a vegetable was very good and still under $10. The pork was thick and flavorful while their Won Ton was a mix of meat and shrimp nicely served over a bed of thin egg-noodles. I thought the broth was not at all too salty, a real plus for me.

For another $9.95 the Won Ton Noodle with Fish Ball plus and the addition of a vegetable is more than reasonable.
author: Caesar A.

description: I have tried many won ton house style restaurants in the city, this place is legit! Variety type of won ton soups with noodle as well as some rice dishes. The best roasted duck ever! I like their great selection of porridges. Service is good and cash only.
author: William C.

description:
Ah brings me back to high school days. ALHS alumni 2002. 

Big wontons with a nice size shrimp inside and noodles. What else can you ask for? 

Sure the interior isn't the prettiest but I'm here for the food. They do not come to check on you. If you need something, just wave them down.
author: Serena F.

description:
I gave 2 stars for opening late 

But seriously the food is bad. 

Not only no taste but it's bad quality 

Won Ton Noodle soup was Terrible

Vegetable wasn't taste right. 

Service was good tho. 

First and also my last time here. 

Here are just too many good restaurants to try but unfortunately not this one!
author: Mack A.

description: Really disappointing. The hamhock was tough - and not falling off the bone gelatinous that's the trademark. The wontons were tough - the shrimp inside was sizable but tasted like rubberbands. Filling lacked seasoning. Overall just so much below what a decent Chinese restaurant in the city should be able to serve with this menu. I give it a star more than the minimum because the waitstaff was friendly. But it's not enough
author: Eddie J.

description: When my daughter and I saw that ELITE YELPER, JUDY K., came here and shared such a positive review for WON TON HOUSE, we knew we HAD TO try it!  Well, just as JUDY K. said, "no-frills dining, just good food on the cheap"!  Service was GREAT!  The waitress was very friendly and accommodating.  The food was SO YUMMY!!!  We ordered 1. Won Ton Soup; 2. Won Ton Noodle Soup; and 3. Duck Porridge.  All three were GREAT!  Daughter said, "Next time, I'll probably skip the noodles and just get the Won Ton Soup."  LOVE finding a great Won Ton restaurant close by to home . . . AND endorsed by JUDY K.!!!
author: Victor T.

description: This place is the hole in the wall restaurant you probably wouldn't notice in daylight but on a cold night , this place is your perfect getaway . They have hot steamy won ton and porridge to warm you up . They're opened pretty late and that's why it sticks out so much on a block of darkness when other businesses are closed . This place has a pretty small menu but there are truly some amazing staples . It's not super unique or any type of fusion that stands out but more like food how your grandma use to make. BBQ pork rice plate , won ton noodles soup , veggies , porridge and their special red bean dessert is what I always get and they never disappoint ! This place has been opened for over a few decades , so they obviously have something good going on in there .
author: Carmen V.

description: Best turnip cakes around. Always get two orders. One for me and one for the rest of them. Pork dumplings are good but skin is a bit chewy than I like. Just a different way of making it. None the less it's very tasty.  Wontons...man if their wontons were awesome then they need to change the name of the restaurant but it's been around for at least more than 3 decades. We didn't even get Noodles with the wonton. Think it takes away from the deliciousness of it. Lastly, get the red bean drink. Will not regret it. Wonton House, still kicking ass!
author: Ben L.

description:
**CASH ONLY*** 

Porridge is my go-to sick food because who doesn't love porridge?! They make some delicious porridge here! 

There used to be a local dim-sum bakery by my house in Ingleside but it closed down. I used to go there for siu mai and some Chinese bean cake or something for my granny who resides in Laguna Honda. Since I didn't know what else to order for her besides porridge, I decided to come here since it was just a several minutes away from Laguna Honda. My granny loves their porridge, so whenever I visit, I grab some for her here. They are around $6 for the beef porridge. Though she doesn't eat the beef (but I do), it adds a nice flavor to it - better than just bland porridge right?! I tried opting for other porridges nearby my place, but she said it tasted like poo....... she just love Won-Ton-House's porridge!! She tells my other relatives that the porridge I get is the best, so I must be doing something good ;) 
I'd definitely recommend this place if you need porridge for an elderly lol 

Other than porridge, I think their won-ton soups are pretty good too! My bf loves to eat their won-ton noodle soup, and I love their beef stew soup (lol, see, I don't just go for the porridge!!) They open late, so this is a great place for you drunkies who need some liquids in you lol..or if you're hungover! Asian remedy is the way to go ;)
author: Mandy G.

description: It's actually saddens me that I have to write this review...we love coming here for their noodle soup and Chinese broccoli for a hearty simple meal...however tonight, I ordered food to go and while waiting for my order. I saw a roach crawling on the wall by the register and where the clean utensils and bowls are. Their food safety score is 85 but I just can't eat anywhere that has roaches...
author: Linda L.

description:
Friends insisted we go here because it was cheap. So we went. And cheap it is. 
I ordered the Szechuan Beef over rice.  There's a TON of rice, very little beef, and the beef was really chewy and tough. 
The utensils did not seem very sanitary, and it always freaks me out to use chopsticks that aren't packaged. Just plain eww. 
There's a reason this restaurant is cheap. 
Two stars because the service was very quick. (Although this of course means everything pre-cooked in pots in the back, so they can sling it out quickly.)
Just avoid this place if you can.
author: Reed S.

description:
Wonton soup is bland! Turnip cake is only ok and doesn't have much filling.

I don't have anything else to say.
author: Jennifer M.

description: I rarely give an updated review of the same the restaurant once i submitted a review for the first time but this time i have more to say. When i first came here couple years, i thought it was so good and cheap with quick service. I came here again for dinner and order beef brisket and wonton noodle soup for $7.95....now i think about it, its not that cheap...they don't even add vegetable. I thought the soup was average and it gives an after taste for some reason. When i bite into the noodle, i thought it wasn't fully cook, had a little hard texture when they first brought out my food. Then after a few minutes or so, it was okay to eat. The service was still really quick. The food came out within 5 minutes. Not sure if i want to came back again.
author: Julie N.

description:
Best in SF. Cheapest!! Very OG style, nothing new here.
Been eating here before Pac died...

RN get the combo wonton & dumpling noodle soup w
a side of spicy tendon and Chinese broccoli. Shrimp juicy. Taste like cutting class in high school with $6 in your pocket. Nothing like it...

$25 = plenty for 2

I recommend.
I always come back
author: Mono L.

description: Stumbled upon this place while walking around noriega . I must say I am very impressed . Service is straight to the point but in a kind way . They bring you tea even if you don't ask for it so if you don't want any make sure you tell em. Food was great  , I got the shrimp dumpling bowl and man was it delicious . Before it came out I wasn't expecting much from it because the bowl was only 6 dollars and I am in San Francisco where 6 dollars could barely pay for your parking . The bowl came out steaming hot with (I counted ) ten decent sized dumplings , each having atleast a shrimp in it and some pork . This is really a steal and I don't understand why this place doesn't get more love from Yelp .
author: Toan T.

description:
My version of cheap comfort food!

I always come here and get porridge (fish or pork with preserved egg) and the spicy beef tripe! The spicy beef tripe is a MUST. Especially when mixed with the porridge.. drool. 

The last time I came here, I got fish porridge (of course), spicy beef tripe (duh), and my bf got wonton noodle soup. Wontons weren't bad, but they kind of looked like a weird version of siumai. I'd say just stick with what I know.. and that's the porridge and spicy tripe! Can't go wrong at all :)
author: Leslie C.

description: I've been coming to this place for over 20 years. The menu hasn't changed at all, and what's crazier is that it still tastes the same when I came here as a kid. Talk about consistency. If you're craving noodle soup, there's nothing better than ordering the beef stew, wonton, noodle soup. Add a side of gai lan choy and you're set.
author: Mark L.

description:
MSG can kill or make some persons really, really sick, but some people are not the least bothered by consuming MSG.  Me?  I'm a bit in between.  While MSG can provide an irritating tingle in my mouth or on my tongue I've never become sick from consuming it.  Sometimes I enjoy living on the edge, and it's those times when I visit the Won Ton House on Noriega Street.

Don't expect impeccable service here.  It's basically a sit where you want type of place and the waitress will wait until you are properly seated before bringing you a boiling cup of hot tea.  She'll take your order, bring you your food, occasionally glance at you to make sure you're not doing anything mischievous (taking photos of food is the exception) then she'll bring you your check.

Living on the edge isn't the reason I eat here though.  I eat here because the food is cheap and as much as I hate to admit it I do have some of those cheap-Chinesey genes in me.

Let's take a look at what I've ordered on recent visits:

Won Ton Noodle Soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/won-ton-house-san-francisco?select=xa6sEzBFnVtxqz5a0NHwug#_o08CiG6XmYhflC8fhnn-w) - The won tons are nice and plump and pretty decent.  The noodles stay firm for the duration of your visit, and they don't get mushy.  The broth is where the MSG is really noticeable.  Don't finish the broth and I'm usually okay.

Potstickers (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/won-ton-house-san-francisco?select=xa6sEzBFnVtxqz5a0NHwug#0QLakvWbQuiqJmkBpM7jtg) - Sometimes five to an order and sometimes six!  Mixed with the coarsely ground pork is a bit of cabbage and sometimes a bit of ginger.  It's not bad and the MSG is minimal.

Stewed Beef Brisket Noodle Soup (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/won-ton-house-san-francisco?select=xa6sEzBFnVtxqz5a0NHwug#kGkSDCM8wN7sEWGeDcTf3g) - The beef is usually tender and the tendons are properly chewy.  Like the won ton noodle soup the MSG is in its broth.  You'll know what to do.

Roast Duck & BBQ Pork over Noodles (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/won-ton-house-san-francisco?select=xa6sEzBFnVtxqz5a0NHwug#xa6sEzBFnVtxqz5a0NHwug) - You can have this over rice too, but I'm always going to be a noodles kind of guy.  As with mostly all Chinese BBQ the MSG is in the marinade.  They use the same sturdy noodles on this as they use in their noodle soups.  They pour some of the fatty liquid from the BBQ meats into the noodle to give it some extra oomph and extra MSG.

Make sure you drink a lot of liquids after eating here just to wash away the MSG.  

So if MSG and low health scores don't bother you so much, and you want hot, cheap food relatively fast this place is A-OK!
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
Great place for late night greasy chinese food goodness.
Came here after Outsidelands (we were starving) around 11:00 PM and were seated quickly.

The duck congee was delicious - perfect balance between creamy rice and savory duck.
The shrimp dumpling noodle soup was good too - but next time i'd pass on the noodles and just get the shrimp dumpling soup!
author: Michelle L.

description: Hungry or having a late night dinner? Definitely come here.  Found this gem while looking for restaurants that's still open after ten and this was the place. This place doesn't have enough love for how good it is. Super friendly restaurant and it's very quiet inside since it was late at night. I thought this place wasn't going to be busy considering this a quiet neighborhood. This restaurant is huge which can actually seat up to maybe around 30+ people. The menu is simple but have diff varieties from noodle soups to egg noodles to rice plates. The lady that took our order or everyone's order(guessing she's the owner) super friendly and patient. My friend who doesn't eat pork since she's allergic to it, she had a hard time choosing because the lady said almost everything was made with pork. She nicely recommended what to get without getting all angry because usual Asian ladies have no patience and rush everything(from experience). We ended up getting the Szechuan beef rice plate and the noodles which both came with pork broth which isn't bad but tastes too much like msg so I passed up on that. The portions are huge for the price you pay like where else can you find prices like these now in San Francisco. Two huge plates which we couldn't finish so got it to go for UNDER $20. I think this will be my new favorite late night restaurant because the service, the price you pay, and the flavor of their food. 10/10.
author: Lisa W.

description:
I loveeeee wontons and Won Ton House did not disappoint. Maybe I was super hungry also, but I know it when I taste a good wonton.

I ordered the wonton soup and my friends ordered the wonton noodle soup. The difference is only with the egg noodles, but I say the pure wonton soup is muchhh more worth it because they give you more wontons. And our check came out to be around $7 per person. What a great deal!!!
author: Vivian W.

description:
Solid place for a quick bite to eat.  The noodles were firm and the broth was light and flavorful.  The BBQ pork in our soup was a lttle dry and lean, but still very tasty.

Service was quick and friendly.  I would visit again the next time I am in the area.
author: Terry T.

description:
Note: CASH ONLY

Won Ton House is a great go-to for your typical Chinese comfort food, especially for noodle soup. My friends and I wanted to get some late dinner (at like 9pm) and this was one of the restaurants that opened late, according to Yelp. 

I wasn't too hungry so I just ordered a shrimp-wonton soup without the noodles. The portion is great and the wontons were tasty! The soup was very subtle and wasn't too salty or anything. My friends also enjoyed their noodle soup, and lo-mein. 

Overall, I would definitely come back if I was craving some yummy authentic wontons! It's a great spot for late night food and also very affordable!
author: Wendy Y.

description:
Been a big fan of wonton noodles and i chanced upon this place when i companied a fren to the dentist.

Ordered braised wonton noodles to go. 

Service - no greetings, no smile.

Noodles - extremely dry as less gravy in it. I had to add hot water and mix it.

Wontons - prawns inside and it taste not bad.

Overall - that will be my first and last visit.
author: April L.

description: Wow... what happened here? I used to love the wontons and dumplings here and now it is completely different. Before the wontons has a perfect mix of meat and shrimp and the dumplings has a great mushroom flavor and a nice crunch from the wood ear. Now the wontons and dumplings are just meat and they basically taste the same, just different sizes. Did you change the person who makes your food? If so can you please let me know where he/she went???
author: Tommy C.

description:
Hot. Won. Ton. Soup!

I come to this place for their hot wonton soup! It's always a cheap, comfort foodly dinner! $4.75 for a decently large sized bowl... I haven't seen a deal this good anywhere else yet!

FOOD | Wonton Soup
-Wontons are mixed meat + shrimp on the inside
-Lots of egg noodles
-Hot wonton broth soup

PROS
-Everything on the menu is pretty cheap, around ~$5 or so. I haven't tried many other things on the menu... I'm sold on their wonton soup already :)
-Open late (M-F: 11am - 12am, Sat: 10am - 12am, Sun: 10am - 10pm)
-Super quick service. The nice asian lady brings you hot tea as soon as you sit down!
-They do accept to-go orders. Call and order in advance!

CONS
-Cash only (good thing there is a Bank of America nearby)
author: Grace J.

description:
Their food is solid. Every time I do order the same item, beef brisket noodle soup, and it is good every time. As an ABC, this ho fun is really good. It is thick and not thin. Each noodle is not stuck to each other as it would be if the noodle was sitting too long. I cannot vouch for the other noodle soups, but since their name is Won-Ton House, their wonton noodle soups must be good too.

Come and eat here. Each portion is perfect. Not too much, but not too little. For the price it is also good. The only gripe I would have about this place is that it is just a noodle house and nothing else. Parking is a bummer, but other than that it is great. You'll never have to wait in line but doesn't mean the food isn't as delicious as neighboring restaurants!
author: Natalie T.

description: Really quick and has good food in pretty big portions! Perfect for a quick cheap meal with a group of people. Only thing is that its cash only and they have a ~5$ spending minimum for every person at the table
author: Claire N.

description: This place is our go to place when we want fast, delicious, an inexpensive dinner on a cold, foggy night. The noodles are perfectly cooked with a very flavorful broth. The broccoli with sesame sauces is great and I don't like broccoli. Whatever you do, don't use the restroom. The staff is quick, to the point, and attentive. This is not a place to take your snooty marina friends. This is for your down to earth friend that enjoys the true won ton experience in the sunset.
author: Dee Dee R.

description:
This used to be the spot I hit up to get my fix of asian comfort food. I think it's been about a year or two since I've been back, but I remember the dishes being more flavorful and hearty. 

Ordered the usual beef stew noodle soup. It came with a handful chunks of brisket and whopping bowl of flat rice noodles. The dish came out within 5 minutes, but was lukewarm and could've been prepared warmer. Broth was bland and beef was chewy. Like cow eating grass chewy. Overall, it was missing the steaminess and flavor of "Asian comfort food". Maybe my taste buds became more bougie after eating at 4-5 star restaurants, but I definitely did not feel satisfied with my meal. Ended up getting a snack and drink right after to satisfy my palette.
author: Shirley L.

description: Definitely a hole in the wall Chinese place, don't expect anything extravagant at all. But this is my go to place for a good bowl of wonton soup! :)
author: Terilyn T.

description:
Cheap, fast, tasty Chinese food. I have ordered the mustard green pork noodle soup which I did not find very good. The noodles were over cooked. But the pig ear and turnip cake made up for it. While the pig ear isn't sliced as thinly as most places, the flavor and texture is spot on. The turnip cake is pan fried to order, fresh and piping hot! 

Went back today for iced Hong Kong milk tea, wonton noodles and pan-fried turnip. The milk tea tasted more like a mix of tea and ovaltine which I did not mind. The wonton noodles were very good. My husband ordered the dumpling soup, which was a generous portion. 

 They have late hours and parking is normally plentiful.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
It's never crowded, and the food comes out fast, hot, and tasty. It may be hard to get their attention to order/pay at times, but you're not allowed to complain at these prices.

You can get a bowl of won ton noodles or porridge/congee for about $5+

I don't know about you, but it's hard to beat a deal like that. I could easily get two small meals out of one of these bowls! Such a good go-to when you're feeling sick or congested and just need to consume/breathe in some chicken soup.

They open pretty late, too!

*Note: If you order plain shrimp wontons, you WILL find meat (pork? beef?) in them. If that's a problem for you, don't order them.
author: Colleen M.

description:
I ordered a dish of oyster sauce with vegetables, which was $5.95, and a bowl of wonton noodle soup with an additional topping of bbq pork, which was not on the menu. So, I asked how much the dish would be with the additional topping. I was quoted $7.95. When I got my bill, the quoted price was correct, but my vegetable dish was added an additional $.20. So, I asked why that was the case. She then told me that she had misquoted me the pricing for the noodle soup. It should have been $.20 more ($8.10). So, instead of letting me know that she had misquoted the dish,  she went ahead and decided to add an additional $.20 to my vegetable dish . 

Oh dear.... I would have been fine if she would have verbally communicated with me for the misquoted dish. Now I just can't trust this place and won't come back at all. It is not the $.20. Dishonesty is not ok. Lack of communication on pricing is not ok. Charging extra without letting customers know is not ok. It is illegal. Last but not least, the entire conversation that I had with the waitress was in Cantonese. Language barrier was not the issue. Bad business conduct was.
author: GR Z.

description:
Big portions, low price. What's not to like?

Came for a late lunch. I was starving at this time so I just ordered the beef tendon lo-mein without pondering much of the other options on the menu. Also ordered it as such so that I could also enjoy the gravy that comes with the beef tendon stew and switch it up with broth, if I wanted. Meal was delicious. Compared to the amount of noodles on the plate, the beef tendon seems skimpy...but don't let that fool you. I finished my meal but was definitely incapacitated later by food coma...

Probably should have split it into two meals - but sometimes my eyes are bigger than my stomach.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Watch out!
Just got some bbq wonton noodles and red bean drink to go, according to their menu, the total should be around $10 with tax. The lady charged me $2.00 more, I guess she deserve a 20% tip for to go food too.
I will take my cravings to Just Won Ton next time.
author: Ivy C.

description:
Some things just taste better when you're a kid: lunchables, Benihana's, dried macaraoni, you get my drift.  My dad used to take me here all the time when I was a little girl.  I think I used to get either the wonton mein or the bbq meats noodle plates.  Well, I went here months back with a friend for a small bite to eat and got the shrimp dumpling noodle soup.  Maybe I should have just stuck with some wonton mein, but it was not good at all.  The meat tasted odd like it was old and it was more meat than shrimp.  Noodles were cooked fine, and broth was standard by wonton house standards.  Prices were cheap too.  The waitress was really nice, but dang those dumplings be gross!  Maybe I ordered the wrong thing?   

I think I'd rather just wait for a trip down to San Bruno to get some good noodle soup at Fat Wong's.
author: Cat C.

description: This is my go to "Mom and Pops Cash Only Hole in the Wall place for Chinese Comfort food."  I have been coming here for about 6 years.  Their shrimp won ton is very good here.  I usually get some sort of soup noodles when I come, and have mot been disappointed yet.  When I am too lazy to make my own dumplings, I order from here in bulk, take it home and freeze it.  There is always a lunch crowd.
author: Robin A.

description:
I only live a block away from this place and only go when it is last resort. I don't think I will be coming back. there is way too much MSG in their porridge. when I ate food with too much MSG, I don't feel good. mind you, I am okay with eating package instant noodle and those always have MSG in it. 

their porridge gets watery after you keep stirring it. I hate that. the pork liver is tender enough and those are the only factor that gets them an extra star otherwise, it would be a one star. 

cash only and the ladies are nice enough. but not enough for me to go back ever again.
author: Jules L.

description: I wish they let me give this reataurent 0 star. I walked in that day with my friend. We Oredered wonton noodles , rice soup and fresh vegetable. And then OMG in the FRESH vesgie had a worm. We was very polite to tell the staff about that. And the only thing the women said that"its ok. Sometime u clean the vesgie but still have some left". Horrible food and sevice. Right After that she talked shit about me outloud with another people in chinese in front of my chinese friends. Never coming back again.
author: Hana N.

description:
I came here with a friend because we were both craving noodle soup.

I ordered a bbq pork wonton noodle soup. The bbq pork was underwhelming, and wasn't very good at all. The wontons were okay, and they were very generous with the amount wontons in my soup. The noodles were super filling, and I wasn't even able to finish half of them! The soup was pretty good. I kept mentioning to my friend how full I was, but somehow still ended up slurping on the soup as we talked.

My friend ordered the roast duck with wontons, without the noodles (smart choice!). And by the time he finished his meal, he was pretty full, even without the noodles.

We also shared an order of turnip cakes. They were surprisingly delicious! They were perfectly crispy on the outside, and soft on the inside. They weren't too oily either, unlike most places that serve turnip cake.

Decent food and generous portions at cheap prices. I won't argue with that. Definitely coming back for more turnip cake!
author: Vivian L.

description: Yum! Dumplings are big and flavorful, prices are extremely reasonable. Turnip cake is amazing! Ask for a side of plum sauce since they don't have Xo Sauce :)
author: Emily L.

description:
Best wonton place in San Francisco. I always come here for the wonton soup and I add stewed beef or dumplings. The wontons are not skimp and are flavorful along with their soup. I come here with my mom, friends and coworkers and we all keep coming back. 

For those of you who don't like this place please recommend me another spot because I've been to most other wonton spots and they don't even come close. 

Those long time customers who blast this place. Is it possible you're getting older and your taste buds are changing?
author: Stanley C.

description:
Cheap. Hot Food. Fast. 
2 stars for the quality of the food and 1 extra star for their price.

As a college student with inadequate cooking skills, you learn to hunt down all the cheap food. 

If you're looking for good quality food, I suggest you dont walk near here. Because I only ate here due to scarce money at the time.  

Recommendations:
WONTON house= get wontons lol
-BBQ Pork Wonton Noodle Soup $4.95
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/won-ton-house-san-francisco?userid=sd4E5iKUZotDEeiF3cC81Q#25VLPZ3mQ2HDZozD2D5H_Q
-Roast Duck Wonton Noodle Soup $4.95
-Curry Dumplings

** they charge a $2 fee for people who dont order anything, so order something small like the curry dumpling if you ate already***
... or wait in the car while your friends eat haha

CASH ONLY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! 

Yes, there is a lot of msg. Yes, the dishes had strong soap smell. Yes, the meats are a bit dry. BUT, if you dont care much about the quality, then this is a very good deal for cheap hot food!
author: Chena N.

description: I was craving wonton noodle soup over the weekend and we decided to give this place a try.  We had wonton noodle soup and spicy beef soup, along with red bean drink and Hong Kong iced tea for ~$20.  There were 6 wonton balls in the wonton noodle soup and the soup base was pretty good.  We were content with what we had for a late lunch and were going to give this place 4 stars.  That is until the lady that worked there ruined it by asking "What? No service tip?" As we were leaving.  Mind you we had already put money on the table, tucked under one of the soup bowls.  Service tip is to show appreciation for the service that was provided and it is not mandatory.  Lack of etiquette left a sour taste.
author: Joyce L.

description: One of the best Wonton Noodle House and the sunset owners are very nice food come out really fast I usually always get it to go. They're duck and rice noodles are good too. Very inexpensive. Dinner for two $15
author: Michele T.

description:
Wanted to like it. Cute, cheap, fast and open late. But the food wasn't very good. It's edible, but very oily. I got the wonton soup. I've had it many places before and it's usually my favorite but this seemed like a watered down version. 
If you don't mind the quality of the food and want to get some warm, comforting soup for cheap at 11 o'clock at night, I would still recommend this place. I just don't think I'll be back.
author: Kayla P.

description:
I've been here a number of times over the course of many years. At this point, the waitstaff has become familiar to me and is on friendly terms with my family. 

First impression is that the restaurant is clean and the food is pretty affordable. We definitely have a tendency to come here when it's later at night, as the hours are good and the restaurant is often open during holidays. 

We typically order the won-ton noodle soup with roast duck, the pork and thousand year egg congee and stewed beef brisket over rice. The noodles come in a pretty big portion and they allow you to customize what type of noodles you want (egg noodles, shanghai noodles, fun). The broth is pretty simple and straightforward; pretty much fulfills what you would be looking for from Cantonese style noodle soup. The noodles always come with a good portion of duck with some meaty pieces, but the skin isn't very crisp. The won-tons themselves can be hit or miss. When they are fresh, they taste great, but sometimes you can't be sure. The congee tastes great and doesn't disappoint. My favorite is actually the beef brisket over rice; the flavor of the beef is great. My only qualm with it is that the pieces are often a little fatty, and there isn't a ton of meat. Might have to go with a double order if you want enough beef. 

Ultimately, the food tastes good and is cheap, but the quality isn't always perfect or predictable, especially when it comes to the won-tons. 

Favorites: Beef brisket over rice
Tips: Great late night spot!
author: Amanda C.

description:
Simple tasty reliable Won Ton Noodle soup for $5 cant go wrong with that. Primarily you come here for the won tons. The soup they use isnt just water with a sprinkle of flavor, it tastes pretty good. The won tons are good sized. They have several variations with roasted duck, different kind of dumplings  and other varieties of dishes. There are plenty of rice options here also. The food is good but not spectacular. 

They get pretty busy during lunch and dinner time. I swear the 2 ladies working here have been there forever. Good service and the waits arent long. The place isnt fancy or a hole in the wall, just very simple and kept pretty clean.
author: T C.

description: If you come here expecting a fancy meal or diverse dishes, you're at the wrong place. However, this is one of the staple comfort foods of many people, old and young alike. I always come for the wonton noodle soup, which has a flavorful broth and wontons that don't skimp on meat or shrimp. Their prices have gone up over the years but it's still a good cheap meal perfect for cold days in the city.
author: KC W.

description: It cost me under $10 for extra noodles and 12 wontons!! HELL OF A DEAL! #1 is LEGIT. I've also had their chicken with ginger and chives over rice which is awesome. Also, their duck and BBQ pork over rice is yummy too. Definitely one of my go to spots! Cash only!
author: Elton N.

description:
Some girl named Andrea K below me complained as it was the wonton spot's fault that there was no vegetarian dish for your starving friend. I am quite disturbed that you blame the establishment when you don't do your own research. What did you tell your friends that they have before impressing him/her? You tell them they have vegetarian wontons? Hello? Maybe read the menu before walking in? Plenty of places to eat across the street. It's your own damn fault to starve to that stage when poor you had to eat whatever that is in front of you. Also, maybe consider ordering your friend some Chinese broccoli on a bed of noodles? Drop the victim mentality here please. If you friend was pissed, it was not their fault. You don't go to a Chinese restaurant and expect they have Italian food. Make sense? They have rolled ho-fun with plum sauce. I go on vegetarian diet for days sometimes too. I still come for those. 

Also, I don't know where you are from. I grew up in China and this is the closest you can get in SF. Stay home and eat your mom's food next time. You should never compare the two. Or next time, when your mom cannot compete with a restaurant dish, you should bring it to her attention. She will listen I am sure. 

I have been coming here for almost a decade. I truly think this is the most authentic wonton place in SF. There might be other spots in SF but I am loyal to Won-Ton House. I like the hard working lady there too. She is awesome.
author: Brock L.

description:
I recently went back to my old neighborhood, the Sunset District in San Francisco. Living in LA, I forgot how chilly it can get at night. So after arriving in the fog, we decided to go to Wonton House to warm up. 

This is a place I often ate at in the 80's while cutting school. So it was nice to see they still had my favorite dish on the menu: Spicy Beef over (rice or noodles) I chose the latter this time. The price hasn't changed much, if at all since the last time I went there over 10 years ago.  The flavor was just as I remembered it, and it was a huge portion. We also ordered wonton noodle soup, a necessity in Chinese late night comfort food, along with an order of turnip cake.

So I rate the price a 5 star, because it's so affordable. Rate the food a 3 star as it's good, but not great, the same for the service, not great and not bad... just as it was when I went there decades ago. I'm leaning towards an overall 4 star because it brings me back to my childhood, but that's just my personal feeling. So to be fair here on Yelp, an overall 3 star.

If you're looking for a great meal experience, maybe not here. The decor has not changed for the past 20+ years, but then again,neither has the price.  But if it's a cold night (or day) and you crave some hot wonton noodles or the like, than hop in and order up. 

Worth a visit or a return if you've been already.
author: James L.

description:
When I lived in San Francisco, this was a definite "go to" place for Won Ton who did it right compared to their peers.  I could have sworn, and maybe I'm either... a butterfly dreaming he's a man... or... a man dreaming he's a butterfly... that this place used to be called "Marie's Won Ton House" (or maybe Marie was the name of the owner or one of the workers), but I could be wrong.

I've not revisited this place in well over a decade or more, so after reading the reviews (and seeing the delicious photos), I'm feeling nostalgic to want to come back the next time I'm in San Francisco.

I remember this was one of the 1st won ton places that loaded up their won ton's with large whole shrimp prawns, a generous size and quality, where before it was like rolling the dice ordering won ton from various restaurants, never knowing what's inside the dumplings and more often getting disappointed.  Once this place emerged, it was one of the premiere places for Won Ton... I'm speaking from my 1990's time machine 'tho.

I've not had a bad meal here before, and it's always been a great place (later, "Just Won Ton" became an easier option to go to based on parking since parking can be difficult here).  If you're up to the task, there's parking up the hill and on adjacent residential neighborhood streets if you don't mind walking and have the stamina to take on some of the hills and distance.
author: Rick S.

description:
Cheap, tasty and open late? I'm all over it!

You won't get top notch service but hey, you get what you pay for. The staff are nice but you will have to flag them down for things.

The wonton noodle soup here doesn't beat my all time fave Hon's Wun Tun House in Chinatown but it's good enough when I want something close by late at night. 

Beware that there is a $2 per person min. Which isn't bad even if you had to pay the $2 bucks.
author: Andy W.

description: Nice simple Chinese place. Wonton noodle soup, maybe duck over rice, beef tendon, porridge and a few more. It just hit the spot and they are open til midnight! Sweet!!!
author: H R.

description: Tasty comfort foods. Nothing too fancy, just solid and done well such that you want to come back again and again.
author: andrew v.

description:
This was my first trip to a noodle house and my first time trying wonton noodle soup.

The food was good and nice big portions. The restaurant itself is very bare inside.

Cash only. I'd go back. Good food.
author: Richard M.

description:
I was hungry at 11 PM and stumbled upon this restaurant. The prices are decent, all under $10. I ordered the wonton noodle soup and dumplings. The wonton noodle soup was alright. The dumplings were drenched in oil. I felt unwell after eating the dumplings.
CASH ONLY
author: Kelly O.

description: One of the best Won-ton I ever tried in the city. Very hong kong style dishes. Price/quality/quantity wise it is a 8.5/10. The beef noodle soup its amazing (which somehow I never find in their menu, I just order it in cantonese and they bring it to me lol) The only drawback is that they only accept cash.
author: H C.

description:
This is a wonton place for Americans!
If you want to have a good Hong Kong style wonton, you will be disappointed.
author: Candy M.

description:
It was a great surprise finding this place.  My roommates and I were out for noodles down the street but they were closed.  So I decided to find a noodle place close by.  Luckily we found this place.  They have both broth noodles, braised noodles, rice plates, and a good selection of porridge.  I wished I discovered this place sooner so that I could have tried their porridges.  I settled for roasted duck noodle with added won ton.  The added won ton was $2 but well worth it.  I received 4 big pieces of roasted duck and a good amount of won ton.  The broth was delicious.  I will definitely come back here.

Keep in mind it is Cash Only!
author: Minhphuc T.

description:
Worst Chinese food I've ever had. I would rather just go hungry and not eat anything until I raid my refrigerator when I got home before I would order anything from here again. The brisket over rice was pathetic. 99% of the brisket was gristle.
The minced pork over noodles tasted like dog food.
author: Suzanne E.

description: 28 bucks for some microwaved roast duck that was still cold, curry tendon and porridge? Sounds gross but actually pretty good. They dont sell yao tiu anymore or the curry potstickers. Wish the food wasn't microwaved  otherwise it would live up to its past experience. Open late but cash only. Inflation at its finest, 5 years ago it would be under 20.00
author: Winston C.

description: Look at picture no. 80 and look at the cockroach on the side!! WTF! Where is the food inspector when you need them!  This place needs to be shut down ASAP! DO NOT EAT HERE!!!!!!
author: ed t.

description:
There are nights that nothing can beat a good bowl of won ton soup. I went to Won Ton Noodle house because their soup has always been made properly with the right amount of noodles and won tons. The soup by itself is excellent.

I ordered the shrimp won tons and my friend ordered barbecue pork. It was my friends first time going here and he came away pleased and full. I insisted he try some of my shrimp won tons and after sampling one he remarked that he will be ordering that on our next visit.  Gone are the days of him thinking that the won ton noodle soup at the local Ranch 99 was the best won ton in town.

I live in Daly City so it's not really that close but, in my opinion it's worth the drive. Parking can be difficult depending on the time of day or night you decide to go. For the most part if you're patient a spot will open up or at the very worst you will have to park a block away and walk to the restaurant. 

I would also suggest trying their fried pot stickers but, order them the minute you are seated because it does take a little while for them to be served.
author: Mario O.

description:
Hot fast cheap and good food. Nice lady who is there day into night.  Good comfort food.  Won tons are made fresh everyday.  And I'm not talking about made fresh then freeze then thaw.  No. Fresh & size of golf balls.  Order any of the meins. 

Try to order something off menu & see if they can make it for you.  

My fav: won ton char sui mein.
author: Lokelani Y.

description:
Cheap "comfort" food, it wasn't that good minus the steamed gai lan (veggies) with oyster sauce and even that, they didn't cook it long enough making it kind of hard. The wonton is sub-par and the tendon is a no-no. Do NOT order the tendon, it tastes like plastic and the "curry" that came with the lo-mein was just so watery.

I mean, it's cheap though so that's all I can give this place and it's edible and I didn't get a major tummyache afterwards. I wouldn't recommend this place if you're in the area.
author: Vanessa K.

description: Been coming here since I was a kid and it's exactly how it used to be still. 4/5 stars because it's cash only, but still a great place to eat. You can never go wrong with the wonton noodle soup. And the soup is one of the best parts. Don't forget to drink it too.
author: Courtney D.

description: Wonderful won ton soup, very fresh, flavorful dumplings. The noodle dish was not so great. I guess that's why they call it Won Ton House, instead of Not So Great Noodle House.
author: Jonny A.

description: This place has been here for 20+ years, yeah it might have been better in the past but I don't get the point in people constantly restating the fact. Also, keep in mind that it's hard to keep up with the food trend because they are a very simple shop, with a simple menu. You can't walk into won ton house and expect to have five star service and have your food taste like it came from Alexander's. It's simple, you come here, you eat your food, and you go. You can't really complain when the food here is only like $5-7 and the portions are pretty big. For me, the service has always been fine. I feel like for most people, it's the language barrier that makes customers feel as if their servers are rude. Most people mistake the waitress here for the owner but she's just an employee that's been here for as long as this place has been around. Won ton house is nice for a late meal because they're one of the few businesses open til midnight on Noriega. The pot stickers, turnip cake, red bean drink and the beef stew are prob my go to items here because I've noticed that those are the most consistent when it comes to flavor.
author: Joanne C.

description:
What they serve is comfort food.  Very basic and a very no frills place.  A greasy spoon place.

Fourteen of us came in for siu yeh around 10pm on Saturday night.  Quick service.  Our food was brought to the table in no time.  

Where can you pay less than $6.00 for a late snack?  Including hot tea?
author: Shirley N.

description:
Do not go here. The wonton was below average. The soup sucks. Way overpriced for the quality. We weren't going to give any tips, but as we were leaving, the lady (assuming she's the owner) asked us "where is our tips?" WHO DOES THAT?! 

I rather skip a meal than eat at this place again.
author: Thao L.

description: Been coming here ever since I was a kid with the fam. I always get the won't ton noodle soup with beef stew. The hot sauce they got there I haven't seen anywhere else. I think they hate me cuz everytime I go there I use up just about all of their hot sauce. Lol. Potstickers are good as well but they always come out after the rest of your food. I really liked their curry Potstickers, but am not sure why they took it off the menu. Fyi, If u order the red bean drink they bring it right away. I ask for it a lil before I finish my meal and have it as a dessert.
author: Eddie B.

description:
I've had better wontons in SF. Those restaurants also didn't give me diarrhea. 

I give them credits for having pretty fair beef brisket and rice noodles, but it stops here. I had better noodles, fish balls and whatever else on the menu elsewhere. What kills me is that I had nothing to eat one day and amid running errands, I passed by this place, so I stopped and had my first meal of the day. 

three hours later... I had a case of diarrhea. Not the worst, but it wasn't fun either.
author: Sandy N.

description: Beware!!! This restaurant hands out fake counterfeit $20.00 bills! We went to have lunch there on February 16th 2016, we order pork with egg porridge, roast duck noodles, Chinese broccoli and turnip cake. We handed a woman waitress/cashier a new $100.00 bills and we received $20.00 bills and some change in return. Did not pay attention to the $20.00 bills until trying to pay my electric bill at PG&E outlet and they told us that it was not a real money but fake counterfeit $20.00 dollars bills. We went back there on February 19th 2016, to inform them that they give us a fake $20.00 bills and that waitress/cashier was not there, we talk to the restaurant owner and they denied the whole transaction. So, look at your change before you leave the restaurant, they are not honest! They should know it was a fake $20.00 bill when they received it! As a customer we are not aware of these fake scam!
author: J L.

description: Great wontons and a very reasonable price. They pack all the noodle soups in containers with noodles apart from soup so you can take it home and warm it up.
author: W A.

description:
Pros:
- DIRT CHEAP food. Seriously about $4-7 per dish
- Great for warming up after facing the typical SF cold weather
- No MSG taste in the noodle soup
- Service is decent and prompt
- Not crowded, but always a steady stream of customers
- Good to come here as a group

Cons:
- Small-ish menu (not a problem for me, because I have 2-3 regular faves)
- THEY TOOK THEIR CURRY POTSTICKERS OFF THEIR MENU ;(
- Roast duck is always mostly fat, better off getting it somewhere else

Not a restaurant that's mindblowing or for snotty people, but I always keep this place in mind if I'm too lazy/busy to cook or I just want something quick and cheap.
author: Bonnie S.

description:
I still remember when a bowl of Wonton Noodles here was 2.55 back in my early teens.  Considering the inflation and cost of living increase it's still a good cheap bite for about 5 bucks here at this hole in the wall.  To put you into perspective for all you young guns out there who has a car... gas was about a dollar a gallon back then.  There is nothing fancy about this place and their idea of friendly service is nothing a San Franciscan, who is not tied to their Asian roots, can possibly understand.  We are in snob city when it comes to food and service no doubt, but I love these types of joints.  You've been here all your life and you know exactly what to order and you know that what you've been ordering for years will be exactly the same way you had it 20 years ago.  Their food isn't the most alluring but it is surely comfort at its best.  4 stars is for their consistency and cheap eats for the last couple of decades.  Wonton House kept my belly full while my pockets were starving as a kid.  20 years later they still keep my belly full without sacrificing my pockets' lean waistline.  

What I order every time:
Wontons (no noodles)
Braised brisket beef with sauce over wonton noodles (soup on the side)
Pan Fried Turnip Cakes (savory but consistency isn't the best... a bit too soft)
Chinese broccoli w oyster sauce on the side
Their in-house made hot sauce is something special... the thought of stealing a jar of it has crossed my mind many times but that would be a crime.

All that serves 2.  Best 20 bucks you'll ever spend to get your fill.
author: Colin M.

description:
PROS
Closes late, midnight on Friday, which is why/how we came here.
Cheap, mostly ~$6 noodles and rice dishes
Huge portions, so much meat on the combo rice plate!
Free hot tea for cold SF nights
Lots of tables
Surprisingly good noodles

CONS
Nonexistent customer service bordering on rude
The szechuan noodle soup was not in the least spicy.
author: Vivian H.

description:
+ + +PROS
+ cheap
+ flavorful broth
+ family owned

- - - CONS
- not the best service
- cash only

Dispute having so many amazing reviews when a friend and I visited the place was empty. The owner was kind and brought us tea and water straight away. She came back for our order and to deliver our food then I never saw her again. Granted I'm used to this type of service from Chinese restaurants it's still always a bit displeasing.

I ordered beef stew wonton mein(it's not on the menu but you can order pretty much anything to your specification if you speak Chinese). The broth was very flavorful and didn't need to be drowned in sriracha or hot chili oil. The wontons are mostly shrimp which is a nice change since most restaurants just pack their wontons mostly with pork. I'm happy to say the beef stew wasn't mostly fat either! I was thrilled. My meal was only 6.50$ and it was so filling I had a hard time finishing!

The place is CASHONLY just like most of the Asian restaurants in the area are, but it is conveniently a block away from a BoA and a Chase. So if you don't have cash you can walk to the ATM.
author: Minnie P.

description:
Greetings!
My bestie and I stumbled upon this restaurant late at night after having dessert in the area, so we were quite desperate for a place to eat once our stomachs called us to action. We yelped places near the area but unfortunately nothing was open. We then gazed across the street and saw this little place open. This is perhaps the restaurant's greatest asset, that it is open really late until midnight.
The food was average at best. My friend had noodle soup and I ordered dumplings. I don't know if it was that my friend was stressed from packing for college, or that her friend was dealing with personal issues, but after eating the extra oily and greasy dumplings, we felt very unhealthy and experienced hypertension. 
Overall, the restaurant had a friendly environment, swift service, and average Chinese food. Good place to eat on a whim, but not if you're looking for the best Chinese food experience on this side of the city.
author: Angelo C.

description:
Had this place earlier for lunch. For sure this place is cheap for their won-ton. I mean, cheap in their prices, but other than that, their won-ton is ok. However, when I was eating it, I was chewing and I can't chewing something crunchy 2 times. I thought it was the noodles being hard, but when I was almost done eating, I looked closer into my won-ton soup. Guess what I found..3 tiny dead bugs. There might of been more, but I didn't finish the rest of my noodles and won-ton. That's probably the last time I'm going here. Having dead bugs in my food is really disgusting. There shouldn't be bugs inside the food in the first place and having more than 3, that's gross. So if you want food with bugs, come here. If you don't, don't come here.

Cheap food, yes, but with bugs, no thanks. Make sure to look closely into your food for bugs!
author: Billy L.

description:
I remember this place use to be the go-to place for cheap wonton.  No more.  Basic wonton soup is $5.75.  Only a few years ago, it was $3.75.
