I understand about inflation, but nearly 200% increase is a bit too much.  It comes out about almost $1 per wonton.  Yikes.  Major restaurants charge just as much, and probably cleaner with better ambiance. 

Came here on a Saturday during dinner time.  Only 3 tables.  Surrounding restaurants had people out the door.  Should had known.  Not cheap for the price due to low quality food.
author: Jason L.

description:
Honorest great beef noodle soup! I felt like I am in a restaurant in Hong Kong. Now I know where will I go in a hungry, cold night. 

Only con is they don't accept credit card. I need to find somewhere else for my hungry, cold and cashless nights...
author: George C.

description:
Has really gone down hill. The quality is lacking. This is evident by the lack of customers in the restaurant.

Bought a beef stew lo Mein and one Jong the other day and it came out almost $12. 

Pretty expensive and the quality was not there. 


I guess when you are drunk and this place is open late, it will do the job.
author: U L.

description: Ordered the wonton soup and shrimp dumpling soup! They both tasted exactly the same. Not bad but nothing special. Super cheap so that's a plus! I would come here again :)
author: Michelle H.

description: This is probabaly the best wonton noodle soup spots I have found in the city. I also ordered the veggie and oyster sauce. Everything was fresh and the hot tea served hit the spot !
author: Samantha C.

description: Consistently good cheap and casual eatery. They have noodle soups and porridge. Super quick on order fulfillment.
author: Julie L.

description:
One of my favorite local spots in the Sunset. It's a cool hole-in-the-wall type of place that I have been coming to since I was a little kid. The food is CHEAP (ranging between $4-6), the food is FAST (comes out within minutes), and the food is DELICIOUS!!

Personal favorites:
- Beef stew lo mein 
- Spicy minced pork over noodle
- Porridge (of any kind)
- Chinese tamale
- Chinese turnip cake

*CASH ONLY
author: Crystal G.

description: Roast duck porridge is really good. The porridge was well made, it had the correct flavor and consistency (i.e., they did not simply add rice to boiling water, that is rice soup, not porridge). The Chinese tamale was good and filling. Service was fast.
author: Hiroshi K.

description:
Close to home and basic Chinese food.

Always a fan of Won Ton House when i'm craving for wonton or jook. 

Cash only.
author: Carol Y.

description: Good, Cheap and Open Late. Shrimp Dumpling Noodle Soup really hit the spot.
author: Bruce W.

description: This place is expensive for a Chinese noodle shop, and its products are only mediocre at best. As usual, you'll get a dirty bathroom and sticky tables, but that's par for the course with Chinese places. What wasn't up to snuff was the food. Portions are tiny for $8 plates/bowls, and you're only going to get so much meat and/or wontons in your order. The noodles are fine, but each dish tastes like it's just been doused in a little oyster sauce and that's it. In my plate of char siu and roast duck noodles, I got about 3 pieces of duck, and two of them were either just fat and skin or a giant bone. The broth that came with it tasted like reheated chicken broth from Costco, which is great on your own when you're cooking, but I expect actual soup from a place like this. My girlfriend and best friend were also disappointed with their bowls and tiny portions and said that the food was far too expensive for the little we got. Cash only, people. Service here is also pretty lacking and unattentive.
author: Danny C.

description:
My favorite go-to place for a quick, homey, affordable/ cheap Cantonese won-ton and porridge place.
The ladies who work there are actually quite friendly. 

What I always order,
Won-ton (no noodle) is actually very delicious.
Boiled Chinese Broccoli - very fresh and nice
Porridge - fish, pig liver, and minced pork with preserve egg are good
Home-made chili sauce is very spiced and tasty.
Red-bean drink is yum
What else to complain?!

When I pay this little for a meal, I do not complain much the food quality. 
unbeatable value, very much satisfactory
author: JustinE Y.

description:
This is the to go place for a quick but hearty lunch or dinner. Service is super fast and you always get complimentary tea.  It's a cheap place to eat but it's not dirty what so ever!

You can get roast duck over rice, a bowl of wonton lo mein, jook (porridge), and other asian staples.  There are a ton of different restaurants similar to Won-Ton House, but the waitresses aren't rude, they give you a lot of food, it's clean, and not loud inside.

I ALWAYS get an order of their Red Bean Drink for $2.55 :) Ask for less crushed ice so that they add more sweet milk and red beans to it!

Tonight I had the Braised Beef Noodles for under $6 - STEALLLL.

It's as good as grandma would make it and that makes me a happy customer.
author: Samantha L.

description:
I started coming here 30 years ago...and regularly, too.  Mostly for the won ton noodle dishes.  Jook (congee) to take out on sick days.

Now, it's only place I know between the Richmond & Sunset that has a nice selection of jook.

Today was the first day back in over 4 years.  Same menu, good prices.  The portion of my braised beef stew won ton noodle soup was more than enough. Unfortunately, it wasn't as flavorful as in past years  It wasn't bad, though.

I'd still call it a neighborhood gem. After all they don't have any competition on either side of Golden Gate Park.  Girl's gotta go somewhere for jook & won ton in the same place.
author: Debbie T.

description:
Good old fashion porridge, noodle, rice Chinese restaurant. they have a variety of items on their menu and are all very reasonably priced. They even have specialities like beef offals.

My favorite is their porridge, mMM goodness in a cup! One order fills up a giant plastic cup & is enough to feed two-three. Pair the porridge with a bowl of shrimp wonton noodles and you've got a delicious lunch for two! :) Only downside of this place, is the fact that it's hard to find parking. After circling around for 10 minutes I finally found a spot two blocks away from Wonton House..in the time I spent circling Noriega for a spot, I could have probably parked at my house and walked over :(
author: Jess s.

description: Won ton should be the shingling star here but you will be extremely disappointed like I do. The meat inside is hard and the flavor is completely covered by the pepper. One of the worst won ton places in the America. Ordered a plate of rice dish. Holly kow. The rice is strongly hard to my mouth. Rice has to be continuously cooking in the pot since morning. Not recommended for any food here.
author: Xx Z.

description: I used to come here a lot baCk a few years ago cuz I lived around the corner but I tried to avoid this spot majority of the time . The food is just cheap lol I mean look at the prices. The beef brisket stew is mostly fat not that great , wonton is just whatever's. I drown everything in hot sauce cuz it's just so mediocre, lack of flavor. The only decent thing was the egg noodle with oyster sauce and green onions/scallions. You can't really fuck up with that lol
author: Colette P.

description:
I'm a fan of Won Ton House and have been here twice so far, both as "real food" stops before going across the street to Golden Island for dessert. :)

Won Ton House reminds me of the restaurants we visited in Hong Kong... No frills in the decor or the presentation of the food, but really good flavors and extremely well-priced.

When you sit down, the auntie lady acting as both server and cook will bring over two mugs of tea. The tea, while brewed in one of those diner-style coffee carafes, is actually quite good - warming on a chilly night and not over-steeped. 

Since this is "Won Ton House," I've only ordered won ton noodle soup, which happens to be my #1 comfort food. It's a really simple dish, so the $4.75 price is fitting. You get a heap of egg noodles, about five wontons with shrimp and pork inside, and broth. No veggies, no meat - though maybe the other options on the menu include them... I'll have to check next time.

The won tons are very good and are full of meat. Every won ton seemed to have at least one shrimp in it. The broth (chicken-based) is light, but flavorful and I didn't really detect any MSG. That is, I didn't feel super thirsty after finishing my bowl, but I'm not really a stickler for MSG to begin with. Most Chinese restaurants use it, so it's not a big deal to me.

During our first visit, the bf's sister got a noodle dish topped with char siu bbq pork. There was an incredible amount of pork; I was actually thinking about getting this to-go. :p Our second visit, the bf got the spicy Szechuan noodle soup. The noodles looked good and the chunks of beef were lean. I wish they were a *little* more tender than they were, but I'm thinking that this dish might not be a specialty of theirs so personally, I wouldn't pick it. Bf said that the broth was good though.

The best part of our meals here has been the turnip cake or "law back gow". SO GOOD. It's pan-fried so each piece is crispy on the outside, but once you bite into it, it's incredibly soft and pillowy and so smooth. You must order this no matter what.

Dinner for two was about $8 before tip and we left (for dessert at Golden Island) full and happy.
author: Steph S.

description:
I called to place an order, asked the lady to wait for just a moment while I got my boyfriend's order and she hung up on me. Then she was super rude when I called back to try and place my order again.

Enough said - won't be going here for my preserved egg congee fix!
author: Sophie B.

description:
Won Ton House has a simple menu: won ton, noodles, porridge,  items over rice or over noodles etc.

dining room clean, modern look.

sampling: shrimp dumpling soup (4.15)
-10 very large dumplings, filling about 1/2 shrimp,  1/2 pork
shrimp mushy, not crunchy, tasteless
pork was salty, tasteless.
*freshness of meat/shrimp in question   2 stars
-broth mixture of msg, beef taste (powdered?)
comped tea was very nice.

leftovers:
-entrees cheap, portions large,  good value. 4 stars
-service reasonable.-
-msg aftertaste later
-wonder where the employee was wheeling open containers (not covered) of chopped char siu to? he headed out the front door.
-cash only

chinese lesson     mandarin
dumplings             shui jiao
author: Victor G.

description: Went in for a late dinner. Standing at the counter waiting for someone to take my order and saw a rat in the kitchen run under the stove. Enough said.
author: Anna V.

description: I would like to give a 3 and half star if I can.  This wonton house is not as good as 20 years ago.  But still one of the best in San Francisco .  The other wonton place because the owner is getting old. The quality go down too.    So their is not much choice.  The wonton still ok. The red bean drink still the best.  The beef sauce still very taste.
author: Ed Y.

description:
I can't say enough good things about this place.  I've been visiting it quite frequently for the past 8 years or so.  I think the waitresses know who I am but don't know anything else about me haha.  And every time, EVERY time, I order #34: Szechuan Beef over rice.  Ohhhh man... that is heaven on a plate.  the way they cook the beef with the sauce, and the lettuce and the rice is the PERFECT combo.  And it's super cheap (~$8 including tax and tip).  You really can't go wrong with anything else on the menu (wonton soup, noodles, other rice plates, etc), but #34 is and will always be my go-to.  Service is amazingly fast too, which is a plus.

Also, their tea mugs are insulated, which means that you can pick them up without burning your hands! Awesome.  

The only issue I have with this place is that they only accept cash, but that's most Chinese restaurants for you.  Remember to bring cash.

EAT HERE. You will not regret it.
author: David L.

description:
Had this a whole ago. Their specialty is (obviously) wonton soup. I got it with just wonton where as my mom ordered it with noodles. 

Both were good, nothing special but that's the beauty of wonton soup. It's never a failure!

We also ordered the pork and preserved egg porridge which was pretty standard.

All in all a good meal at a good price.
author: Chloe Y.

description: Love!!!! This place is my favorite place to go when my hunger craves some good ol' wonton soup. They definitely hold up to the name. If I live closer I would be there all the time. Their wontons are so full of flavor and they put TWO shrimp in each wonton. Yum!!! Getting hungry just thinking about it.
author: Kim L.

description: Good Beef Stew!
author: Peter K.

description: Food is decent. The soup can be somewhat bland so I just add soy sauce to it so it'll taste better. I ordered the basic wonton noodle soup if that matters. If I was in the area and hungry, yeah I'd swing by cause why not.
author: Eric A.

description:
We wanted to go to Bakery & Cafe for lunch but they were crowded and there's a wait.  If you have two small children you know that won't do.  Checked out the restaurants adjacent to Bakery & Cafe (Icehouse & Won Ton House).  Icehouse looks like they are empty.  There were people in Won Ton House so we went in (that and the under $5 meals lured us in).

There is no one to seat you.  You pretty much seat yourself but the waitress does notice you and comes by with your tea and water in a jiffy.  My tea came in a cracked cup.  I was definitely worried that it would implode and spill all over me when I touch it -- luckily it didn't.

We ordered BBQ Pork Lo Mein and 2 won ton noodle soup.  You can chose thin or thick noodles for your noodle soup.  That's a plus for me because  a lot of places only offer thin noodle and it feels like you are chewing on wire.

Food came fast.  There were about 8 won tons in the noodle soup.  No veggies.  I guess you would have to order that separately.  Come on, even some lettuce would be good.

Won ton is good.  You can see medium whole shrimp and some pork.  No mushrooms - fine with me.  Noodles are cooked just right.  They are not undercooked like so many places do it (that makes them wiry!).

3 dishes = $15.  Wow!  That's cheap!  Portions are just right.  Cash only.

Yes it's a hole in a wall and service is typical "I don't care" Chinese style but hey, this isn't a 5-star restaurant and we aren't paying 5-star prices so fine with me!
author: Wendy H.

description:
The truth is this place use to be a lot better but it is still an awesome best bang for your buck type of place.

What has remained over the years?
-Awesome broth
-cheap
-great quality
-quick and easy food

What has gone downhill?
-portion (literally only a few pieces of any order)

It use to be that I can come here and order a cheap rice plate and expect lots of meat. The last couple of times I only had like 4 pieces of roast duck. I ordered the tendon and I only received a very small box of maybe nomore than 6 curry tendon for about $7. The quality of the food is still awesome though.

Open late. CASH ONLY
author: Wilson P.

description:
EW

i ordered the chicken wonton soup... the boiled chicken still had feathers on it! and it smelled gross. 

I understand there being skin on the chicken, which i also don't prefer because its flavorless and slimy, but I understand if thats "authentic" or whatever...

then they charged us extra for the gross chicken and didnt warn us that it would be $2 extra!

plus the place didn't smell that great and i found the food unappetizing. 

i have no idea how this place got this high of a rating. im not eating this soup.
author: Brianna N.

description:
Another cheap eats success gold mine! 

On my search for tasty noodles & wontons I found the Wonton house! My #1 go to place for dry noodles with meat and wontons! On my first visit I got the bbq, but the braised beef on my following trip was the absolute winner for me! Mix in with some chiu chow chili sauce on the table you have one fantastic golden meal that won't hurt your pocket!
author: Gordon O.

description:
If you are here. Walk out the door right now.

I had a horrible experience here. It was a cold and foggy day in the sunset (as usual) and I really wanted some wonton soup. This was basically the last resort because most of the restaurants on Noriega and 19th close at 6pm. The place smells like a wet dog the place was bare. It looks as if renovation started and they only got to demolition. I figured maybe the food is good because usually crappy places have the best meal. The food was just as bad as the setting.

I would not recommend this place to my worst enemy.
author: Kirita S.

description: Love the affordable noodles! On a cold cold night in the sunset I would recommend this place! I had the won ton noodles before and tonight we had the wonton with duck noodles in the soup. You can see the shrimp through the wonton skin! They're big and yummy! :) will be back soon!
author: Alice Z.

description:
This is a "greasy spoon" Chinese restaurant in the Sunset District of the city. Don't expect fancy dining, but satisfying portions and good food quality. The Wonton noodles soup and potstickers were pretty good (8/10) and service was friendly.

Every table was occupied today, so I guess the locals know where to eat!
author: James W.

description:
In search of a cure for all that ails you, then look no further.  Won ton noodles house have the cure for the common cold to the gnarly hang over.  perfectly stuffed shrimp and pork won tons matched well with a light broth will make one feel better

but if you are look for some good grub then tack on the chinese broccoli with oyster sauce and some super crispy turnip cake (super good).  

The best part about this place is that you can get all this for 2 for under 20 bucks and that is after the hefty tip.
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Amazing comfort food and the best price in town! This is pretty close to what you can get in a wonton house in HK. 

What to order:
curry pot stickers - takes about 15 minutes
pot stickers
wonton noodle soup 
Shanghai low meen - dry stir noodle with bamboo shoots and pork
jook - rice porridge
rice roll with chinese fried donuts inside with sweet plum sauce!
red bean drink
pork ears (if you are really chinese lol)
steamed gai lan(veggies) with oyster sauce 

The service is good! it's always the same lady day and night, she is very attentive and nice! You always get your food fast and it tastes amazing!

Enjoy!
author: Mindy C.

description:
Cheap!!!
open til midnight.

Yes, I've had better wontons elsewhere. And cleanliness might be an issue (You've been warned!! you come in at your own risk).

- Most dishes (soups, porridge & rice plates) are under $5.
- Egg noodles are a bit undercooked.
- They are generous with the rice for the entrees over rice plates.
- Potstickers (6 per order) have a thicker skin than normal, and look handmade (probably from the dumpling shop across the street). Note: Takes 15 minutes to prepare. Also I like to use the pink vinegar that's available at each table.
- All the food is served piping hot.
- Service is cordial enough to do the job.
- They have a large restaurant space, lots of tables but it never fills up.
- This place has been in business for a long time. I rarely come here now, and I've never found any bugs on my food (lucky I guess? - or maybe they were taking a nap).

I do have high standards for eating out, but in this tough economic times I thought it'd be worthwhile to review places that give you value for your money. I'd rate this place 2.5 stars.

If this place doesn't suit you, there's another wonton place down the street on Noriega and 32nd Ave (Ming Tai), they are more expensive.

CASH only.
author: Luis C.

description: They have the best won ton noodle soup for years in the SF. the won tons have meat and shrimp inside the wrapper. the broth is good and not too salty. price is definitely afforadable too. street parking is hard to find and there is no parking lot.
author: Ray S.

description: Popped in for some late night dumplings-6 bucks for a plate.  Quite good, and they have an orange sauce that is one of the best I've ever tasted at a Chinese restaurant!  It tasted vaguely like an Indian style onion chutney but went so well with the dumplings.
author: Rushil R.

description:
3 stars for the following reasons:
1. CHEAP no-frills grub. If you are starving and happen to only have a few dollars, you can order the straightforward egg noodle soup (just noodles and standard broth) for $2.95. Everything else on the menu is less than $7.00

2. Stays open late. The outer sunset isn't the most convenient neighborhood to dine out past 9pm. The Wonton House, on the other hand, stays open till midnight (except on Sundays)--a major relief for the drunk and hungry.

3. The food is solid for the price. I typically get the preserved egg and pork porridge (with Chinese donut on weekends) or the stewed beef egg noodle soup and always leave satisfied. 

Why not 3 1/2 stars?
1. Not the cleanest place in the world. I swear I saw a roach scramble across the table beside me this one day. Also, they roll out their trash bins through the dining area and out the front entrance everyday--not the most pleasing sight in mid grub mode.
author: Dave L.

description:
I love their cheap wonton soup with egg noodles. FYI, 1 bowl is not filling, especially for guys!! They also have some good red bean ice drinks. 

I really need to remember, they're cash only!
author: Winn D.

description: My family and I have been coming here for years and it is still very good. The noodles are excellent and the tamales are a rarity outside dim sum restaurants. It's sad that they do not put the salted egg inside the tamale anymore. Occasionally they will put the curry potstickers back on the menu and that is one of our favorites. Good food, good service, and great prices.
author: Nicholas T.

description:
Clean tables and floor, steril and stark atmosphere and extremely quiet. The flavor is the same, kind of bland but not bad. 

I'll be back because the service is OK and its a block from my house.
author: Justin S.

description: I got the wonton noodle soup and it was terrible. The broth smelled terrible. I wish I did not go there. Positive note, take out was very fast.
author: RD S.

description: I love how this place stays open late and their small portion of noodles. Came here with my sister after rocking out at the Matt and Kim concert. We weren't too hungry but soup sounded really good on a chilly night. I ordered wonton noodles and my sister got the bbq pork noodles. Fast friendly service so it was nice to get in and get out. The soups contained too much MSG. My sister said her pork was super salty. My wontons were ok. This place is ok though if you're out late and in the area but special.
author: Julie C.

description: The only place I go for jook and won ton noodle soup. Food is always good and the price is on point!
author: danny h.

description: If I could give no stars, I would. Bbq pork over rice was my choice of meal, the pork was microwaved, half hot half cold,the lettuce was wilted like it was four years old. My son had the duck over rice, the duck was stone cold and tasted awful. My fiancé got the wonton soup, which smelled like sweaty socks and tasted just as bad. Avoid this place at all costs, your stomach will thank you!!! My ass won't in the morning
author: Ken C.

description:
I find it hard to come here without getting the song by Lil B stuck in my head, but it's all good. I usually get the rice porridge with wontons, and it's DA BOMB. Authentic food and low prices, what's there not to love? If I could change one thing about this place, I guess it would be to increase the amount of wontons you get (not that they're frugal on it or anything, but just as with boba, I believe there is no such thing as 'too much' in one serving). The lady that works there is also really nice, and after you come here a number of times, she knows what you're gonna order. I've never had to wait long for my food here. The absolutely only thing that keeps me from giving it five stars is that they don't accept credit cards. 

Another thing that I really, really love about this place is that it closes pretty late, so craving wontons at 11pm when everything else is closed? No problem, Won-Ton House is still open!
author: Vilde E.

description: Dirty late night eats. They raised their prices but it's still worth it to come here for jook or noodles. Don't come here looking for awesome customer service because you ain't going to get it but you will get some good grub!
author: Minie J.

description:
How many countless times have I dined here at 10pm, with their perfect turnip cake and refreshing red bean drink? 

I've been going to this restaurant for most of my life and its become a standard place to eat at. Not for exotic or interesting food, because frankly, the store's food is pretty normal. The appeal of this place lies not in powerful flavors or diverse palette, but  in their plain wonton noodle soup, their large steamy zongzi, their pig feet rice, and again, their perfect turnip cakes. 

What I truly come here for is their clean, pure, simple food. Its for when you don't feel the need to get something out-there or extravagantly spiced. You get literally what you get when you order something. No super special sauces, no secret ingredients. Just plain simple food.

What I love about this place the most is the atmosphere. Usually the place is never full, with plenty of room to stretch and feel at ease. The high ceilings, the bright lights, the incredibly clean and simplistic style of the restaurant just puts me at ease every time I walk in. The service is a periodic refilling of your tea, just when you need it.

Cheap, simple, clean, and relaxing. Oh and did I mention open super late?
This place is like a second home to me.
author: Staly C.

description: I've been coming here so often lately. I think this place has the best Wontons in the city.  They've been here for years, I remember coming here when I was in high school. I usually get the plain wonton with noodles and a red bean drink to go with it.   Their wontons are huge, and i love their soup base.  I have a habit of adding their chili sauce because it gives it the perfect kick.  My friend always orders their potstickers here.  It takes a while for the potstickers to come out, sometimes we finish our wontons and noodles and it comes out.  I think it's pretty good, because it taste fresh and the pan fry it to perfection.  This is one the best cheap eats in the city.. Their wonton noodle soup is under $5.00! How can you say no to that?!
author: Belinda C.

description: Had the Beef stew noodle with won ton, was not disappointed! Will be back for more!!!
author: Moi R.

description: I am a vegetarian, so I picked the green onions and ginger over noodles, and it was terrible. I am not a very picky eater but I could barely stomach this meal. When I walked in to place my order I noticed that the kitchen was very messy. When I received my order, I was even less pleased. The noodles looked days old and reeked of old fish. The ginger was stale, and I could barely taste the green onions over the cruddy fishy smell. Don't waste your money here.
author: Wo W.

description:
You can't go wrong with this Chinamen place. it's cheap!!

Most of the menu items (except the bbq items) are yummy. My personal favorite is their beef stew...veyr tender.  Followed by their dumplings and Jaa Jeong Mien (prepared Shanghainese style). 

I've been going to this won ton house since 1993 and not much has changed, still the same waitress with a great big smile.
author: Vee V.

description:
Great place for wonton and noodle soup on a cold night.  I have to admit I haven't tried a good portion of their menu, like some of their rice plates...but why would I when the whole point of coming here is for the wonton?  No really...I mean, it even says "WONTON" on the freaking window...

But seriously, good value for the money and they are open till midnight too.  And don't forget to order their curry potstickers...those are some tasty little pouches of meat and curry oil/juice/flavor.  Just watch out, they tend to squirt...
author: Mike L.

description: Awful first time experience. We ordered shrimp dumpling noodle soup and the braised beef over rice last night. The soup was okay. The beef had more inedible parts (ligaments, tough tendons) than what can be humanly digestible. To top it off, the chili sauce had an insect in it! That was the most unacceptable thing of all! It's been more than 12 hrs since that meal and I'm still feeling queasy. Awful awful awful!
author: Kathryn H.

description:
I love Hong Kong style won ton noodle soup.  This place makes a great won ton and dumpling noodle soup.  It tastes just like what you get in Hong Kong in a dive joint.

The side dishes, meats, veggies all suck.  Too much goo and not enough flavor. 

I would continue to eat here, except I decide to go to the counter and pay... that is when I witnessed the chef handling my food sneeze into his hand and fling the stuff out of his nose into the compost bin and then wipe on his apron.  That is it... no hand washing.

I'm not eating here anymore...
author: Frank M.

description:
wow.


wow.  shibe such hapy. plus 10 point. shibe favorut place 4 won ton. such close to home, eazy peezy. such gud fud 4 price. but keep inside of mind: only cash.

a. locaiton: parking not bad, ez when compair 2 city. inside such not flashy, but who care? shibe trot inside and smell, shibe know shibe in yum yum land.

b. fud: wonton noodo soup such simple, much taste. such delishus. so comforts. obvius not #1 quality. but make sens for $5. turnup cake gud 2. or if super bravery, order pig ear. many ear. very portion. such fresh.

SO GUD SHIBE WRITE AND FEEL MANY HAPPINUSS. shibe want to try red bean drink next tim.

wow.
author: Doge S.

description:
After my trip to South America, the first thing I was looking forward to was eating some wonton noodles.  Since I was in the area, this was the place to be.  

Food: Quick. Consistent. Decent portions. Noodles are springy and wontons are meaty.  Decent prices. 

My one feedback: Get better vinegar bottles!  Those things kept leaking all over the place every time I poured some onto my wontons.
author: Meshell C.

description: This restaurant smelled funny when I went in but I decided to stay the course. Brought the food home and it all smelled like dried shrimp. The broth was funky but the wontons were yummy. Couldn't stomach the smell though. We ended up ordering a second dinner.
author: ivy c.

description:
More often than not, a cheap Chinese restaurant is cheap because their dishes are heavy on the carbs and light on the protein. Not at Wonton House! Don't be fooled by their dirt-cheap prices (all their dishes are under $6) - they're very generous with their meat portions!

I came here for dinner to catch up with an ex (AKA former eating partner). We're both food addicts and have a tendency to enable each other's eat-like-there's-no-tomorrow habit. (He even told me that breaking up probably added 10 years back to his life since he will no longer die from obesity!) When it came time to order, we had a hard time narrowing our choices down to 4 dishes because we wanted to try everything (old habits die hard!) Even then our server asked if we could eat all that food. (Well, *we* thought 4 dishes were reasonable for 2 people...) We got:

SZECHUAN SPICY BEEF NOODLE SOUP, #13 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/syIHvIqM4ON4FkK_lHcvGA?select=H7bBbjdubPDOKeD2k5jyng) - we added dumplings to this and were so glad we did! They were little pillows of perfection. The beef was also very tender, not to mention plentiful. The soup wasn't as spicy or flavourful as I would've liked though and the egg noodles got a little soggy later on after soaking in the soup.

BBQ PORK & ROAST DUCK OVER BRAISED NOODLES, #23 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/syIHvIqM4ON4FkK_lHcvGA?select=f52GIBtilK6UoarfF3qlQw) - The noodles were cooked to a perfect al dente and lightly dressed with soy sauce. The B.B.Q. pork was passable but I've had way better. The roast duck was really flavourful and tender though.

FISH & LIVER CONGEE (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/syIHvIqM4ON4FkK_lHcvGA?select=bBYReYxQuDNTFPakvYlZhg) - so much fish and so much liver! The liver was a little overcooked but still tasted good. The congee base was OK - a little watery though.

CURRY POTSTICKERS, #57 (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/syIHvIqM4ON4FkK_lHcvGA?select=tqAc_KHRIHtU9tNwW9IKeg) - LOVED these! They were filled with an ample amount of perfectly seasoned meat (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/syIHvIqM4ON4FkK_lHcvGA?select=gSCwB1Y0Yg-5SPDFxcfHTg). The curry flavour made dipping sauces unnecessary but it wasn't overpowering. The skin had just the right texture and wasn't too thick. Though they could've been crispier, I liked that they weren't greasy like at a lot of other restaurants.

I was also very impressed with the service - super fast and friendly! My ex went to the bathroom right after we ordered and our food came out before he did! We stayed for a while just chatting after we finished eating but they never rushed us - didn't give us our bill till we asked for it and even kept refilling our teacups :)
author: Steph L.

description:
Cheap. Wonton Noodle soup is about $4

Porridge is pretty good. 

Their beef brisket is very tender. 

Menu is a bit confusing because it says just noodle, but they mean egg noodle, ho fun, or vermicelli. Some items can be with rice too.

Overall I like this place because it's cheap and the food is pretty decent. Service is whatever but eh I dont expect anything.
author: Erica L.

description:
Went here yesterday with my family and friends for dinner. I ordered number seven on the menu which was like a noodle soup with brisket beef (I forgot the exact name) and I recommend you guys to try the Hong Kong Milk Tea. It's pretty good.

However, she (the worker) gave the wrong item last night. My friend ordered 'Ice Milk Tea', but she heard that my friend said 'Number nineteen' and finally came up with another plate of noodle. The good thing was she took back the wrong noodle and changed it with Ice Milk Tea. I also noticed that she complained to other workers in the kitchen because of the wrong order.
author: Owen S.

description: I love this place. No frills, delish, economical. A mainstay. Makes my Chinese heart and tummy fill with glee.
author: Shendi X.

description: This is the great place to go for quick wonton soup noodles. It's especially good when returning from a trip out of town. Ambiance is so so, but their dishes are all quite tasty. My fav is the beef stew wonton noodle soup. You can't go wrong with it. The red bean ice cream drink also hits the spot.
author: Katie L.

description: I'm regular in here :) They offer Hong Kong style noodle and porridge, I love it for breakfast or lunch, Fish poriddge is my favorite, and chinese broccoli with oyster sauce please...hmm...healthy and yummy I like it :)
author: DontHurtMe T.

description: Brought friends here from out of town in 2014 but Yelp keeps updating the date. It was 2014. Everyone said it reminded them of Chinese places in Bangladesh, India, Malaysia. Who knew?  The late night hours were a big hit. My personal favorite is the pork and vegetable dumpling.
author: Nan L.

description:
Oh my..... I couldn't get to a coffee shop fast enough to get the taste out of my mouth.    

That was bad even nasty.  I had the duck noodle soup.   My wife had the spicy beef and although she said the beef was ok the broth was falvored water.  She said the tea had more flavor than the broth.

Must say for San Fran how in the world can this place be rated so high?

Just barely edible.
author: jeremy L.

description:
Places like this are becoming quite rare. They have a good selection of Hong Kong style porridges and noodles. I've been coming here for years and the prices haven't changed much, it at all, from the early days. I usually go with the thousand year old egg porridge. The minced pork over noodles is really good as well if you want something more hearty. 

The great thing about this joint is that the food is pretty simple. There isn't alot of sodium thrown into the food and it makes for perfect food if you're feeling under the weather. The wontons here are fantastic. I believe they are home made and very generously sized. The two waitresses are very nice and will quickly serve you scalding hot tea.
author: Wil M.

description: I didn't think much at the time. But afterwards, I am pretty certain that I got overcharged for my meal. Was not too happy about it.
author: Bob S.

description:
Surprise, I didn't get a won ton dish at the won ton house!  But my BF did, along with the fried doughnut and I got the salted pork and preserved egg porridge with turnip cake.

I could tell the fried doughnut was not fresh.  It was cold when I'm used to it coming out warm.  It was also kinda overly crunchy, like when it's been sitting in its own oil for too long.  Oh, and it was extra oily.  But the won ton soup was good and there was plenty of flavor in the meat and shrimp.  The porridge I got was great.  There was a bunch of pork in it and just enough egg.  The turnip cake was also good but a little oily.  I think there's a theme to their fried foods.  But that can be cured with a little dab here and there with a napkin.  They also have an excellent hot sauce.  The pickled veggies minced up in there are super good and not to pass up!

Oh, and if you didn't know, it's cash only.  The whole meal came to about $12.  Now that's a deal!
author: Rosalind S.

description: Their wonton and dumpling noodle soups are fairly good. Nothing special, but their wonton and dumplings were pretty meaty compared to other places.. But they also only give you 4. One thing my bf and I agreed was the spot hitter was the free range chicken. The meat was delicious along with the ginger sauce. Now THAT was good! :) oh, and also you can buy their frozen wontons here..  It's just as great at home.
author: Meemee T.

description:
This place helped us out-- It was definitely for those who were hanging off a cliff the day after partying at an open bar in a VIP section for New Years Eve. Giggle .  My friends and I were so stoked to come here after the come-down, and realizing our headache would not go away unless we had substance in our stomach. 

Cheap and filling!  

Gai Lan (Cause my mama always said to get a vegetable dish), Won ton min with noodles (good luck noodles for new year!), Roast duck rice (for more substance and because I effing love roast duck... but it only came with 5 pieces?  What!  There are four of us!!) Turnip cake (Just cause we saw other table ordering it and it looked bommmmbbb.

The broth was mediocre.  The won tons were good, so were the shrimp dumplings-  I  prefer Just Won Ton, but they are ALWAYS closed during holidays!
author: Cat A.

description: This place is great, quick, and cheap. Won ton noodle soup is about $5.50 and they make it in about $5-10 minutes depending on how busy they are..
author: Rob T.

description: I can't ever say anything bad about this place. I've been coming here ever since I could remember (maybe even younger than 5 years old) and their food is always the best for their price (which has always been super affordable). I always get their wonton flat noodle soup, but sometimes, I'll opt for the shredded mustard greens and pork shanghai noodle soup. They're really the best. Really.
author: Bonita K.

description:
CHEAP~FAST~TASTE FINE MAYBE GOOD(for me)
I love their iced milk tea~really Hong Kong or Canton style! 
do NOT judge their environment or something like that cuz you do NOT know or understand our Chinese style! If you want nice eating environment or something you can enjoy during your meal..go to the real expensive "suit" resaurant please! Come on~ They just a won-ton house and little or mid food place! They already good enough for their business and even better than dozen of others!
I will come there in the future cuz their price is fair and worth their food`s quality!
BTW,they are CASH ONLY~
author: Young L.

description:
True rating would be 3.5 but I rounded up. 

This is my go-to place for won ton noodle soup. My mother trained me well and this is the only thing I know how to order in Chinese to look like I'm legit. It's not the best food, but it is comfort food. Sometimes, you just want those thin egg noodles. The won tons are loaded as well, as it is a struggle to cram the whole thing in my mouth. And for some reason, i am always drawn to drink the soup.... maybe it's full of MSG? Also, they bring your order out fast!

Overall, a cheap deal for some comfort food. Try it!
author: Tiffany C.

description: My boyfriend and I's most favorite place to go for a good bowl of wonton. Reasonably priced and tastes delicious.
author: Kathryn Y.

description: I recently started getting my orders to-go and they are really stingy on their homemade chili sauce. Only one small container per order. I tried asking for more and they will say this is the last container we have and don't have anymore. Yet, I see all these chili sauce on their tables. -_- their chili sauce is so addicting!!!! I need more when I'm eating here!! But overall, still a decent wonton noodle soup place for $5 a bowl. The pot stickers are delicious as well.
author: Nancy N.

description:
I've been frequenting this place since I was little and it's been consistent all those years. I always get Won-ton noodle soup with a side of turnip cake, extra crispy. Their hot sauce that has a little of this and a little of that is delish.. That probably adds the extra stars because you won't get amazing service here and the 'cash only' kind of bites especially when that means you need to go to an ATM for a $10 meal.

Mostly everything I've had here has left me satisfied and for the price, you can't get better than that.
author: 3beeskitchen ..

description: They open late until 12am, so it's convenience if you wanna get something late at night. One of the reasons I kept coming back to this place was their chili sauce, but I came here last week, and they changed the chili sauce!! What a disappointment. I'm not sure if I wanna come here anymore. I used to always get the BBQ Pork Braised noodle.
author: Lovetoeat A.

description:
Cheap dishes? Scooore. I found this place through my grandparents years ago. A majority of their dishes are under $5, and they're pretty good. I usually just get the wonton noodle soup, cuz that's what they're known for, right? I also get the side dishes of intestines, vegetables, etc. as well if there's a big group of us. 

Service is pretty quick and it's usually not busy. 

Make sure you use the weird colored hot sauce (you'll know what I mean when you see it). It will definitely give your soup a kick. It's not spicy, but it burns your lips.
author: Olivia D.

description:
i've been coming to the good ole wonton house since i was in elementary school.

my dad used to take me here late night after a fun filled evening of bowling.  we would always order the same 2 items...shrimp dumpling noodle soup and beef brisket over rice.  they also have other items such as jook and items over noodles...but i have pretty much stuck to my family tradition with the 2 items.

the dumplings and wontons are homemade...and after you order, your food comes out within 5 minutes.  the prices are uber cheap!  i don't think any dish is more then $6.  3 of us ordered 4 dishes and the check came out to $20...can't beat that!

i've never been disappointed...the food has been the same for the past how many years...the same lady waitress still works there.  haha.  now that i think of it...i remember the same mugs being used when i was a kid!

if you're looking for something to warm you up when the weather is cold or if you have a cold, won ton house is the place to be...it won't empty out your pockets...and you'll leave super full.  woot woot!  oh and they don't take credit cards...bofa is down the block.
author: Jen W.

description: This place is serves great remedy to fight Karl the Fog. You know,  those foggy nights when you are depressed and not int he mood to cook or go out. The only thing could save you is wonton soup (#2) and DVD from Redbox. Soup is hot, flavorful and cheap. You could grab it to go and be out in 2 minutes.
author: Victor B.

description:
It started off with a dry irritating cough - sporadic? yes.  inconvenient? yes.  but at least it wasn't the flu.
But the cough lingered well beyond the normal duration of an allergy and now my throat is sore and nose is runny.

These symptoms could only mean the onset of the dreaded cold.
But who wants a cold when a potential Tahoe trip looms ever so close?

My solution to staving off a bed ridden cold is a lot of soup.
So for the last week or so, I've been eating / drinking a ton of the stuff.
My latest need for tasty broth and noodles led me to the Won Ton House.

I was really surprised by how filling it was, but what impressed was how much I got for about $5.  The soup itself wasn't oily or salty (my two pet peeves for soup) and the won tons were fresh and flavorful.  And after eating here, I have a new appreciation for home made won ton  - as opposed to the frozen pre-made stuff.

Unfortunately, the wife was rather underwhelmed with the duck over noodles.

Overall, I'd stick with the soup.
And depending on how sick I feel, I may have to come back for more.
author: Dan B.

description:
I went here for dinner two days ago. I was starving after class around 9pm and wanted something cheap for dinner. 

I didn't even notice this place until my friend showed me the day before because it was super small. I could say it's one of those hole in the wall for me. One of the positives about this place is they open till 12am, not that late but still pretty good. 

My friend and I shared Shrimp Dumpling Noodle Soup, Turnip Cake, and BBQ Pork & Roasted Duck over noodles. The Shrimp Dumpling was okay. The soup was super bland for my taste so I added loads of chili sauce in order to enhance the taste. The turnip cake; however, was amazing! It was definitely my favorite and I'm super glad it was that cheap. The BBQ Pork & Roasted Duck was pretty flavorful as well even though I wish they could have added some sort of vegetables to it. I'm not tripping though since it was pretty cheap and the portion was just right. The order came out to be $14 something which means my friend and I paid around $7 each. NOT bad since we were both satisfied AND full. 4 star? Yeah, why not. 

As for service, I give it a 3. I think they are a lot better than other typical Asian restaurants I've been to. Nevertheless, my tea cup was not fully washed when it came out, so there goes a star for service. And since my water and tea didn't get refill so down another star. 

Overall, the waitress was nice to us and I was content with my meal so the service star didn't effect that much about my opinion of this place. I would definitely come back again no doubt!
author: Anna L.

description: Usually come to this place after work and then head to boom with the bf . I only order the won ton noodle soup and turnup cake ! Their to go service is quick ! I never actually sat down and ate there but I def recommend if you want a quick bite then here is your place to go and it is affordable :)
author: Tiffany K.

description:
At a young age, my family would get me porridge from here when I was sick. Growing up, I discovered the location and started going on my own and providing the remedy to my friends as well.

This place has great porridge and it's the primary place I go to for it. I once had their wonton soup, since it's called "Won Ton House" I expected it to be better. However, it's nothing out of the ordinary. 

So simple, if you're looking for porridge come here!
author: Austin N.

description:
Oh Won Ton House.

I am a fan indeed. I come here every so often with my friends, but when it's summer time... goodness we're here a lot. It brings back so many memories. I always crave this place randomly and it always, always, always hits the spot. Yay for instant gratification! 

But the food is good and cheap. I always get the shrimp dumpling noodle soup with the bbq pork added. I will never stray from that either. 

I LOVE THIS PLACE! :D
author: Krissel A.

description: I came here for a tasting session specifically on their wonton noodles (since many Yelpers here are singing in high notes about their food). Noodle texture and quality was 6 out of a perfect Hong Kong 10, however, the real let down which also affected the noodle's taste was the soup which lacked the authentic taste of even an average bowl of wonton noodle in Hong Kong would offer. The soup was borderline tasteless, which also affected the taste of the wontons. The wontons were also on the tasteless side with very little shrimp in it. I didn't finish my order, as a few bites were all I need to rate this restaurant based on their wonton noodles alone, and it certainly didn't sing to me. If ABC Bakery Cafe in CT sets an average standard, Won-Ton-House is way below such standard (1.5 Star).
author: Mango M.

description:
The food's not spectacular, but I'm giving three stars because everything here is DIRT CHEAP.

+HELLA DIRT CHEAP. 

+INSANELY DIRT CHEAP. 

+SO CHEAP that even my parents would approve (and they don't approve of much, being Chinese immigrants who always look for steals, deals, and sales of any sort).  

A hearty bowl of won tons, or noodles, or jook will set you back $4.  Maybe less!  Most of the stuff on the menu is $3.95.  

WUT!  

Now, the downside is it's not very good.  My bowl of congee with pork and pidan was hearty, but the pork was dry and confused me.  I ended up not eating any of the pork and just ate the congee and pidan.  My friend's egg noodle won ton soup looked really mediocre too.  

But hey you get what you pay for, right?  

And I needed it after a tiring weekend. 

In the foggy white,
On a Sunset night,
This was just right.
author: Vivian C.

description: I got here last weekend with some of my friends. One of my friends highly recommended their amazing meatballs and I took it, I understood why it is their best selling.
author: Steve Y.

description:
This is an old establishment and upon entering, my first sensory nerves that were affected were my sense of smell was of urine.  After being there for a few minutes, I also got the odor of simply an old establishment with old carpeting, and maybe a little fishy.  Needless to say, this first encounter did not make me want to stay and eat.  The won ton soup could have been hotter, and it was quite bland.  The noodles in the soup were different than I had eaten, but they were tasty.  They had a "lite" soy sauce that had red dye in it, and it made the rice a cotton candy pink.  Again not appetizing.  

We were passing through the City and looking up on Yelp chose this restaurant because of the high review.  In our opinion, the reviews were very misleading.
author: Patrice F.

description:
It's great that it's opened late. Foodies like myself scavenge late at night like a raccoon looking for a quick bite.

Prices are great, but service could be improved a bit. They're not attentive one bit and they weren't even that busy.

If you're looking for a cheap quick bite, this is the place for you! But don't be expecting great service.
author: Amy C.

description: The last time I was here I swore I would not come back again because the bbq pork gave me diarrhea. But I did come back again because I missed the spicy shanghai noodles which is my favorite item here. Favorite no more! because the noodles really downgraded and the meat is still not fresh!! I could clearly taste the pork is at the brink of spoiling. So disappointed in this place. Beware of the almost spoiled food here.
author: Carmen L.

description:
Came here with a coworker to fill our gullets with won tons and noodles!

Service was fast and no frills. I got the won ton noodle soup accompanied with pot stickers. The soup base was lacking in flavor and  substance. The won tons and the pot stickers saved the day with the help of some rice. Filling but lacking in any great flavors. How can this be when you're place is called Won-Ton-House!?! A let down to say the least.

If I had to I'd probably come back but would definitely order something else.
author: Gary T.

description: Tasty, simple and delicious menu that is extremely reasonably priced. I tries the shrimp dumpling soup and Szechuan beef noodle broth were really excellent. Shrimp was in a light broth and the szechuan was made to perfection by adding a little garlic-chili paste. Definitely a great place if you're feeling under the weather or a rainy day!
author: John P.

description:
This place is great for quick hunger fix. Especially in the rain and if you want to warm up fast, have a bowl of wonton (shrimp) noodle soup. This place is cheap!

The food is really quick here. I like eating their food at home so I usually call, walk over (5-10 minutes) and it's ready. Don't worry I know what you're thinking. I've seen them cook it, They don't just stick it in a microwave, they have a guy cooking it back there.

They have some good dishes that I don't know the names for, but you can't really go wrong here. It's quick, satisfying Chinese food. Not greasy or commercialized like Panda Express. 

Sometimes it might be hard to understand the waitress, I can also see myself asking her to repeat herself. I always get the right dish, so at least I know she gets what I'm saying.
author: Leanne K.

description: This place was ok. My feelings and I ordered the Szechuan spicy beef over noodles, Won Ton noodle soup, Won Ton soup, shrimp dumpling noodle soup and pot stickers. The soups were average, the angels would appear to be Angel hair pasta and it wasn't even cooked al dente. The broth was ok but it was on the salty side. The pot stickers were ok but never again shall I order the beef. It was disgusting!! The beef was rubbery, the noodles were undercooked and the sauce want spicy and it was extremely bland. Service was despicable, they totally forgot we were there.
author: Melissa C.

description:
looking for good food for a very low price? this is got to be the place! they've been around for years and from what i remember the price is still the same as they've been since the 1st time i came here 9 years ago.. 

Wanton house still looks and serves the same food on their menu. You can't really find another place that serves wanton noodle soup for under $5!! They open til 12am so is good for those late night cravings! 

The service here is quick, within 5 minutes you order they serve you already! i mean c'mon, where else you going to find cheap, good, and a clean chinese restaurant in SF?!
author: Jenny G.

description:
Won Ton House is a cheap and filling option for cold, blistery nights (which is every night in San Francisco).

The Won Ton Noodle Soup is only slightly better than what you would find in an instant bowl, but with a serving size that is probably two instant bowls, fresher dumplings, and a price tag under $4, it is still a bargain.  The bowl is probably not satisfactory by itself for dinner, but would hit the spot as a late night snack.

The Curry Potstickers are appropriately greasy and complementary to the Won Ton Noodle Soup.  The strong curry flavor, slightly crispy skin, and hot sauce available for drenching make the potstickers a dangerous addiction.

Visit Won Ton House for a satisfactory, hot meal on a budget!
author: Andrew M.

description: Love coming here. Always a must when I'm craving won ton noodles. It's a small place but service is fast. You get the bowl of won ton noodles for about $4-5; can't complain! It satisfies the craving. I would come here for the porridge too. And it's open somewhat late so it'd probably be a good place for a cheap, warm, late night snack!
author: Amanda L.

description:
Have you ever fancied what Alpo dog food would taste like? Wonder no more and order the Szechuan beef. It'll probably be as close to what you imagine it to taste. But to be fair, Alpo smells better. This dish, which by the way, was listed as spicy (not even close). I ordered it to go and when I opened the bag, I was taken aback by the chunks of meat swimming in some tomato looking sauce. I had to chew one piece of *meat* in what seemed like eternity just to ensure I wouldn't choke...if not for the size, but also for the taste of whatever I was eating.. This is the first time I just bagged my food and went out to a corner where I know some homeless frequent and left it for them. Unfortunately, I expect to see it strewn across the street in the morning.

I think most people who rate this place high must factor in the cost. The food is just bleh. It's average at best, but the price is decent. The beef stew rice plate hit the spot for me, but I've had better at the same cost. Just whatever you do, avoid the Szechuan beef unless you bring your dog along.
author: Ray C.

description: Love this place for late night dinner. But the downfall is that they serve you 65% of fatty stewed beef or stewed brisket than just meat!! I mean I guess you get what you pay for. $5-7 for fats.
author: H H.

description:
Matt and his co-worker was at this popular restaurant for a quick lunch, after we pickup some business related items from nearby. We were here at lunchtime, and it was crowded so as every restaurants along the Noriega St. strip. Surprise?

Matt ordered the monstrous Beef Stew Won-Ton Noodle soup. Matt's meal, which cost $4.50, had 6 golf-ball size won-ton dumplings combine with tender Beef-Stew in his Noodle soup. Co-worker had the $4.00 Preserved Duck Egg and Pork Porridge. Her tasty soup had no complain at all. Both of us each ordered the Frosty $2.50 Red Bean drink, which was also a sweet treat in classy tall glass. We managed to eat and leave within 30 minutes, which was the best way without further hassle.
author: Matt G.

description:
quaint little chinese place that's known for their noodles. this place doesn't take card or checks so bring cash money people!

we decided to come here because my friend got their curry beef tendon noodles and remembered it being delish so he wanted to try it again. when the noodles arrived, he realized he ordered the wrong dish. what he really meant to order was the beef brisket noodles so we ordered a side of it a la carte. the curry beef noodles were simple and good. it's chewy pieces of beef tendon in a curry sauce served over egg noodles. the side of beef brisket is definitely a must try! it was cooked perfectly. the meat was tender and the gravy was delicious. yummmmm.

we also ordered the wonton noodle soup and the curry potstickers. the wontons were good. they were filled with ground meat and shrimp and served over some more egg noodles in an abalone-tasting broth. the broth was delicious but i was all egg-noodled out! i suggest ordering a rice dish to mix it up. 

the curry potstickers were interesting. i've never curry in my potstickers so it was different but good. it really reminded me of an indian samosa or something indian, not chinese because of the strong curry taste. the dough was really good and it was filled with meat and veggies. definitely homemade and worth trying if you love curry and potstickers.

everything here is reasonably priced. don't expect anything fancy. just some good ole hearty chinese food that hits the spot.
author: Bobbie W.

description:
An oldie but a goodie!  Been coming here for years, but just not so often and I 'almost' forgot about this place!  

Food is simple, cheap and quick!  Nothing fancy here on the menu and you get what you order.  Typical and most popular dish would be the obvious won ton soup.  You can get it with or without noodles, and there's usually some cooked lettuce thrown in there too.  And they are pretty generous with the amount of won ton dumplings you get in an order as well.

The other night I got the Preserved Egg Porridge (no pork), at $3.95.  It's a steal because it looks like they dump two eggs in there as opposed to one egg like most places.  I had a piece of egg in every bite when drinking this warm soup.  

They also have this hot sauce with chunky stuff in it.  I haven't really seen this hot sauce around at other places, so it's always cool when you find a new hot sauce to complement your meal. 

One thing bad about this place...it can get drafty!  We sat at the second table in the middle and every time the door opened, a big draft would come in.  Not so nice when it's freezing outside.  Just try to get a table further in the back or against the furthest wall in.

Parking can be challenging, but it's not so bad later on at night.  And that's pretty much when you'll find us hungry souls dining there anyway.
author: Teri C.

description:
I really like this place (cheap, fast, simple Chinese food, open late) but their congee just isn't that good.  Won tons are probably the way to go.  They have 13 kinds of porridge on the menu.  I had my usual, pork with preserved egg ($3.95).  The rice was broken down (good sign) so the consistency was good but more watery than I like.  The problem was the thick, dry pork strips they used.  The meat tasted funny (not good).  Also, the broth was downright bland with no ginger.  On a positive note, they do top it with fresh scallions and the preserved egg is excellent.  

I noticed that some of the employees were having lunch, and guess what they were having?  Won tons.  I really need to get those next time.  They also offer braised noodles, noodle soup and rice plates.  And if you still want the congee after reading this, they have the fried donut, but only on the weekends.

The service is very efficient.  It's good for groups or solo.  As soon as you sit down, they bring a mug of hot tea.  There's something comforting about this place.  You feel like you're in a family run Chinese diner.   Cash only, of course.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Cheap as shit. Good as hell.

Egg noodle bowls for $4.19? Turnip cake for $2.99? Ginger chicken w/ rice for $5? And its open until 12am?

No fucking way. I felt like I just ripped off the ladies who work there after I was done pigging out, alone, like the fat fucking american I am. Illegally cheap. Almost as good as a $20 blowski in Tijuana. Almost.
author: I No Lie U.

description:
This place is pretty darn cheap and not bad for the price.

I had a beef organ noodle soup for like $4. The quality is so-so but for $4, can't  really complain.

Also, my friends ordered the duck braised noodle for about $5 and the duck was REALLY good, it had this sweet sauce on it that made it taste extra good.

I would definitely come back for some duck congee.
author: Wilson T.

description: I liked this place , the food was good and the lady who works there was very nice. It was close to closing and she let me and my husband in and didn't rush us or anything as we ate . Very cute hole in the wall , Try it see if you like it  :) to each there own .
author: Dollybell R.

description:
I remember the wonton and shrimp dumpling use to taste better.  The portions (5 dumplings and noodles).

I love "just right" noodles.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
I miss this place!

my boyfriend and I used to come here all the time late at night because I didn't want to cook and it was too late to go anywhere else. it was such a... happy find. the prices are insanely low here but the food is great! the wonton soup is a no-fail. and the curry potstickers are great! 

last time I was there, I ordered the shanghai style noodle soup; it had shredded pork and "preserved vegetables"-- and it reminds me of home. it was very delicious.

& they have congee for hangovers as well (oh, I mean.. when you're sick!). xD can't go wrong with that!
author: Aya T.

description:
My brother heard about this place & decided to take us there.  We had the braised beef over noodles, w/ soup, and w/ wontons.  We also tried the congee w/ beef balls.  All were delicious!  

Nothing is over $6 :)
author: Tisha Y.

description: Lol this place is so dam cheap. I always get DUCK when I come here its really good also. SUPER CHEAP, really good food and much respect for this little hole in the wall.  And they prepare the food super fast.
author: Kyle R.

description:
Any place that gives me an option of extra noodles, gets a thumbs up from me! Of course, there are probably cleaner restaurants that de-vein their shrimp in the wontons, but for about four bucks, this is the best deal for wonton noodles. Some people may not like crunchy wontons, but I can deal with it once in a while. 

I've been sick with the cold and was super hungry after work, so I decided a big bowl of wonton noodles would help. They only have one size of noodle soup, but for $1.40 extra, you can get extra noodles like I did. It made the difference! They also have the best red bean drink around. And I hate red bean whatever! Now that's an accomplishment!
author: Lisa X.

description:
I've been coming here since it first opened in the 90's.  Never disappoints me with their greasy Chinese food and their dirt cheap menu selection.  I always get their turnip cake, beef stew lo mein, and duck porridge.

Definitely a hole-in-the-wall "dai pai dong" type on Noriega.  Don't come here if you looking for super-clean, great service....just great, fast, greasy Chinese food.
author: Patrick C.

description:
I wasn't overly impressed with this restaurant.  Certainly, the service was fast but the dishes I chose were only so-so, not exceptional.  I had the roast duck, fatty, of course, as roast duck will be and the shrimp dumpling soup, while tasty, was not something for which I would make a special trip.  I even tried the spicy beef tripe ( since I am
a tripe fan ) but I found that only mediocre.

Try to use the bathroom at home before dining here as the one at the Won Ton House is horrible.
author: Carmen H.

description:
It must have been 25 years since our last visit?  Driving down Noriega, nothing really caught our eyes.  Walked by a few and most places were empty...really make you think, is it the economy or is it the restaurant?

We ended up here since it seems a safe choice and there were at least a few tables of people.

As always, I can't decide...we ended up with:

bowl of wonton - $3.95 - it's ok, not like restaurant style but more like what I would make at home

beef organs lo mein $5.15 - the beef organs (stomach and spleen) in this really dark sauce over noodles served w/ a side bowl of broth - it's ok - the sauce was a bit sweet

calamari w/ sa cha sauce - $4.65 - it's ok

red bean ice - $2.55 - this is probably the worst one I've ever had.  it's watery and super sweet - not to mention, they didn't use the shaved ice.  I stopped w/ one sip...

It's cheap but there's a reason for it.
author: Gloria H.

description:
We went to wonton house on a cold blustery Sunday. Eager for some warm comfort food, we were not disappointed. As other reviewers have pointed out, it's ridiculously cheap. It's definitely not fancy, the flavors might not be incredibly authentic, but they do serve hot food, appropriately seasoned with fast service.

The potstickers were crisp and juicy, just the way we liked them and the ginger miso soup that came with the noodles was delicious. The rice porridge and preserved egg had me excited, but I found it heavy on the starch. Either way, it's worth the visit if you're in the area.
author: Crystal T.

description:
This is chinaman's comfort food and being a chinaman, it's also my hangover cure if the wallet is looking a little thin. I have fond memories of coming here with my parents when I was in elementary school and ordering a Chinese tamale and a hung dao bing (red bean drink). 

Throughout the years I've lost my sweet tooth and ditched the hung dao bing for their scalding hot tea. For the n00bs out there to Won Ton House, here's a tip: let the tea cool before taking that first sip no matter how thirsty you may be. 

I can really say I've tried everything on the menu and everything is great. For a bowl of won ton noodle soup at $3.95, they're practically giving it away!
author: Eric L.

description: Late night or in the afternoon good food with friendly service, i live close so it's a bonus
author: jonathan h.

description:
Came here with my church family (9 people).

We basically all ordered the #1- wonton noodle soup! When they brought it out, my initial reaction was: the bowl is so small =(! but when I was finished, it was just the right portion. The wonton was yummy, and so was the egg noodle (I usually like to switch the noodle to the 'haw fun' but they didn't have it). In the end, I even drank the soup, which was really good.

We also got the calamari which was alright. My friends wanted some spicy sauce, but they ran out, so we just had the bbq sauce instead.

It came out to $6 per person including tax and tip. I would come here again for my wonton fix. It's a four star because my mom can make this too! But nonetheless, it was still really good.
author: Diane L.

description: Nothing beats a steaming hot bowl of wonton noodle soup on a chilly, chilly SF morning, but to make things even better, Won-Ton House's wonton noodle soup is only $3!!!!  LOVE this place!  Very homey and delicious!
author: Tracey L.

description:
Cheap and good won ton soup. Place is dirty and the service is whatever.. But hey its cheap. I always order the won ton soup noodle with extra wontons to go. I ate here one time and it smelled pretty bad and the restaurant is dirty so ever since then I order to go. 

*Won ton soup is very good ( i love the wontons)
*Overall restaurant appearance & service is whatever.
author: Ella P.

description:
Cheap. Good. Quick. Clean. Friendly. What more could you want?

This place has all the basic dishes you might want for a quick fix or a late night snack. I usually get the Shrimp Dumping Noodle Soup, which is quite the bang for my buck. I timed them once, and I got my soup in 2.5 minutes. The broth has just enough flavorful without being salty; they give you about 5 dumplings; the noodles are cooked just right, perfectly crunchy with texture without being under- or over-cooked. 

It's around $3.85-$4.15 for noodle soups.
About $3.85-$5.15 for rice porridge.
$5-6 for braised noodle and rice dishes.

I also got the Roast Duck Rice Porridge, which was a hefty bowl of jook  and a decent amount of duck. It came out hot and fresh, and didn't need much flavoring. I did add a little bit of soy sauce to it, but not much.

The restaurant is spacious with plenty of seating. Complimentary hot tea that goes down easy and refills quickly. Not overly popular, where you can still have a quiet meal to yourself or with a friend or a few friends actually, without having to compete with the crowd control or noise level.
author: michelle f.

description:
Heard from bf and his coworkers said this place has pretty good wonton and its cheap.

they were right!

Went in tonight for dinner.  really quiet since it is a thursday night.  The lady was pretty nice.  I looked at menu and was looking for the wonton noodle soup.  $ 3.95.  holy shit? 4 bucks for a bowl?  havent see one of those for a long time.  I ordered a bowl.  wonton was pretty good.  decent sized portion.  I also ordered the "lor bak go".  That was alright.  a bit mushy.

This place is cash only!  They open till midnight Mon- Fri.  i think.  Not bad!  Good place for some wonton cravings
author: Stephy L.

description:
The won ton was actually only OK. I think Cooking PaPa in Santa Clara has THE best won ton in the bay area. Their beef tendon (I'm not sure what it's called in English actually) is really good.

We also got their sticky rice wrapped in leaves (a.k.a. Joong to Cantonese) and it was, as my brother describd, the closest thing to what my grandmother used to make.

My brother also got this tapioca dessert with red bean in the middle. Interesting...and pretty authentic in terms of it being something your aunties would have made.

If I want won ton, I'd rather do the drive to Santa Clara but this is good if you're in the area and want decent Chinese food.
author: Sabrina L.

description:
It rained and Tb wants soup...and brought me here. 

we ordered the rice porridge i got the one with pork and preserved eggs and asked for additional liver. he ordered the chinese broccoli, rice porridge and squid...like always he knows i will ask for lemons, so he went to a produce a couple of blocks before.

its a chinese restaurant you all know how service is.

if we are in the area we might... drop by again.
author: Malou C.

description:
The price has gone up at this establishment but i'd still call it cheap.
side order of tripe, Chinese broccoli, and oyster sauce lo mein. That's my idea of a good meal here and i'm stickin' to it.
author: Susy C.

description:
Shrimp won ton noodle soup for $4.15? Complementary tea? Quiet, with no hustle and bustle? Win, win, win! 

This ain't no fancy meal, but when you and your friend are sick, broke, and hungry, this place fits the bill perfectly!
author: Diane G.

description:
You need to hit this place up if you're ever around 19th ave. I'm a huge fan of wonton soup with egg noodles, so trust me

I went on a Thursday night, and it was real empty, with only a few tables being occupied. The host/waitress had "service with speed."

I had the curry filled postickers, wonton soup, and their house tea. Their house tea is incredible. It had this nutty-smooth consistency. I wish I had some right now. 
 
Pros: Ample parking, only 2 ATM's in the area, and it's real cheap!

Cons: Cash only, and wish they had a larger bowl to chose from, because I was real hungry.
author: Darryl D.

description:
I've had better won tons at Vicente and the parking isn't as bad. The only thing is this has more porridge and rice place than that place for those who don't like won tons. 

Their tea is becoming watered down or maybe that is just because of the soapy water which the cup was sitting in before they brought it over..
author: M C.

description:
wow!  this restaurant is been here for a long time.. long long time. It is been awhile since I was here the last time but it is still the same. 
This is a good place for a quick lunch and the price is mostly under $5.
I think anything that I ordered it is good.

Parking on the streets is not too bad.
author: Lena N.

description:
This place used to be one of my favorites for cheap, fast, and delicious food.  I loved the beef brisket over rice because it was tasty and the portion was large enough for two meals.  Tonight I had a craving for it, so I hopped in my car and drove up to the restaurant, looking forward to eating large, tasty pieces of beef brisket.  I put in my order To Go and paid the bill.  It usually took a few minutes for my order to be ready, but this time, I barely sat my butt down when the waitress handed me my order (which I thought was a little odd).

When I got home, I opened up the plastic takeout container and to much disappointment, there was very little beef brisket.  Instead, rice filled up most of the box.  To make matters worse, the beef brisket was very bland and it wasn't even hot!  The rice was hotter than the meat!  I was so disappointed that I ate up the beef brisket and threw away the rice in the trash.  I was still hungry, but I wasn't about to fill up my stomach with white rice.  I can do that with my own brown rice!  

Sorry, Won Ton House.  You used to be my favorite go-to place, but after tonight's experience, I will no longer eat your food.
author: C M.

description:
I used to hate this place because I considered the food plain, plain, plain.  Well, I still think the food is pretty plain, but perhaps my tastebuds have mellowed out a tad because I no longer loathe eating here.  In fact, I don't mind it much at all.

Prices are really cheap, portions are decent, but, again, don't expect a ton of flavor.  The restaurant itself is fairly drab, so I've generally preferred to-go.  The wonton noodle soup, which I order with flat noodles instead of egg noodles, has become a meal staple whenever I'm fending off an illness.

Oh, and if you just want plain noodle soup, no wonton, you'll save about $1.35, but the lady at the register will likely give you the stink eye (What?  I'm just not that much a fan of your wontons!).
author: Mel T.

description:
all i have to say is ...

FISH CONGEE (sooooo good)
author: Michelle Y.

description:
The wonton noodle soup is good, and so is their spicy pork over noodles.  I haven't had much else.

What makes this place stand out is the pricing, the majority of the dishes are $4-5 dollars, what a steal!  Come here for a quick, inexpensive fix.
author: Ben S.

description:
I go there for years and used to be a fan. The portion in the past was quite generous and the food taste good. Recently, I don't go there too often because the portion has been reduced, price has raised which I don't feel surprised. However, I do mind my food not hot enough. It seems that the dumplings are just been taken out from freezer and stuck in the microwave. The filling is still cold while the wrappign is just warm.

Moreover, they are a bit under-staff. Usually, I have to ask several times to get glasses of water, spare bowls or napkins. Sometimes, I just go to grab it by myself from the racks next to the cashier.

I do like the iced red bean drink with milk. Watch out for the MSG though.
author: Roserrele W.

description:
I usually get the beef stew noodle soup. My mom gets the pork hand noodle soup. Then the siu gao noodle soup on some days, and in Chinese, "Wo Tep." (It's a Chinese dumpling). The make it their own and it's pretty good. I used to get the Chinese carrot cake. Mm

Just got back from here, pretty cheap too. Quick :)
author: Vivian L.

description: We had our dinner here with friends and had an awful experience on both the service and the food. We ordered the beef porridge and asked for it to be completed cook since someone in our group cannot have any undercooked food. The waitress was unable to communicate either by mandarin or English and had an attitude when she promised everything is cooked. When it comes, the beef was pink and at the first bite some blood actually came out and finally we had a pool of blood on the porridge. It was no where close to being completely cooked. Other than that, we had to go over to the counter to order after significant efforts of waiting and waving at the waitress. Other food were also under expectation and cannot even qualify for ok food. I would not recommend anyone to go here if you are looking for food or service.
author: Kay H.

description: I'm giving this place 1 star out of spite.  I don't appreciate ordering the shrimp dumpling noodle soup, but getting the shrimp & pork dumpling noodle soup.  I'm a pescatarian, so I could not even eat what I ordered.  If the dumpling is a pork and shrimp dumpling, state that on the menu, not shrimp dumpling.  Maybe they didn't want to pay for the extra print?
author: Sandy K.

description:
I don't care what anyone else says.  This is the best place ever!  Almost everything is under  $5 and it is a generous portion that normal people should be full.

I ordered the preserved egg and pork porridge. it was delicious and well worth it for the price.
