My bf ordered the Duck and wonton noodle soup. OMG. the duck here is awesome. Nice juicy with enough meat.

And the wontons delicious.  Big and juicy shrimp. Lovee it

we also got turnip cake and wonton noodle soup.

The turnip cake is SOO good. it's a bit gooey but it's nice and crunchy on the outside. Veryy delicious.

I will definitely come back here.
author: Zu W.

description:
Cheap Casual Fast Chinese Food

A casual noodle and porridge place with fast service and cheap prices. I stopped by for dinner for the first time and was not impressed.

Shanghai Noodles with Spicy Meat Sauce - thick egg noodles with a spicy ground meat sauce - nothing special

Fried Chinese Donut - not fresh because it probably sat there all day - would not order it again

Wonton Noodle Soup - alright - I would get this next time.

Convenient and cheap but go somewhere else for better taste and quality.
author: Lisa M.

description: Yummie comfort food, especially the won ton soup on a cold autumn night! The picture we took was of another tasty dish: bbq pork & duck over noodles. Those two dishes totaled a whopping $11. Wow. If you're hungry for some good food, fast service, and you're on a starving students budget (or not) I recommend them.  P.s. if you didn't already know duck is naturally greasy so you may want to get it over a rice dish. That will absorb some of the grease.
author: D M.

description: call yourself wonton house?  wontons?  really?  nah the wonton's were too big and meaty like a meatball.  suppose to be lighter, a big smaller and more water chestnuts and veggies to have a better balance.  noodle were just ok, broth good.  Hon's wonton on kearny street is the best and is second to wonton from hong kong.  if i want wonton soup noodle i go to hon's only.  also had the cha siu rice here.  way too much rice and cha siu too lean.  hon's also has better cha siu rice and also there curry beef stew is sick.  i usually order rice plates when i'm at hon's and wonton without noodles.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Good cheap eats.  The won ton and porridge (jook) are best bets here.  Sometimes I get a side dish of Chinese broccoli (gai-lan) or pot stickers to go with my soup.  The lo-mein or beef stew is good too.  They open late, always a plus.  

Service is typical of every Chinese restaurant I've ever been to that cater to Chinese peeps, so don't be surprise if the staff doesn't want to chit chat about the weather with you.  Not a deal breaker for me.  

I like Just Won Ton on Vicente and Win's Restaurant on Taraval better for different reasons, but neither opens as late.  

Oh, and watch that first step.  It's a doosey.
author: Stephen F.

description: best hole in the wall ever. Cheap prices, great food and fast service. Wonton and porridge yumm best combo area.
author: Yennie N.

description: I have been coming to this place since I was a child and love it all the time. It's cheap, good food that has yet to disappoint me. I have moved away from San Francisco, but I usually eat here at least once when I visit. The atmosphere is usually calm, easy to talk to someone else, and they're open fairly late for San Francisco.
author: Katrina L.

description: The prices are extremely cheap. Everything on the menu is less than $6 which is extremely good for college students trying to save major money.
author: Jeremy H.

description:
I finally went here a few days ago.  I've passed by a bunch of times and it's one of the few places that I haven't tried on Noriega.  My first impression...this place is dirt cheap!  Everything is under $7 and the wonton noodle soup is only $3.95. It's also kinda hard to find if you don't know where it is already, because it doesn't really have a sign.  It's located next to the restaurant with the Sun logo on it (I can't read the chinese characters).  I ordered the Wonton noodle soup and the Ngow Jaap (beef organ) a la carte. My friend ordered the Fish Ball Noodle Soup.

To be honest, I wasn't impressed with their wontons.  I've had much better wontons in NY and if you're gonna name your restaurant after wontons, I expect the best.  Their wontons are just ok, although it's not bad for the price.  One thing I didn't like was that I thought there was grains of sand or something in my wonton, but no one on yelp has mentioned it before, so it could have just been a one time thing.  

I did like the beef organ dish.  It's the standard dish you'd get at dim sum, but it's missing the intestines and the daikon.  I don't care for intestines, so I don't mind being without that, but I would have loved some daikon in the dish.  I also don't like spleen, so I put all of that to the side.  Haha, the only organs I like in that dish are the different types of beef tripe....Mmm...Yummy.

My friend said that his fish ball soup was decent, so I'll take his word for it.  The reason why this place gets 4 stars rather than 3 is because the prices are so cheap.  I didn't order any congee, but I saw that they were all around $4.  That's a pretty good deal, so I know where I'll be going if I need congee.  I'm guessing that it's hard to mess up congee, but I'll update this review if it turns out to be bad.  Another plus is that they're open until midnight every day of the week.
author: Tyler C.

description:
Came here last night because I was in the mood for some soup because I'm still a little under the weather. I came here a couple times before and the one thing I remember that I liked from there was the pot stickers. 

Everything here is cheap and pretty tasty. We ordered the won-ton noodle soup ($3.95), pot stickers ($3.65), beef jook ($3.95), Chinese donut for the jook ($1.35), and ginger chicken ($5.05). The won tons were really good, pretty plump and full of filling. The pot stickers are my favorite..the pork filling was really tasty, and the skin is good- you can tell the skin is homemade and not the pre-made wrappers. The jook is alright, tho more soupy and not too much rice in it. The ginger chicken was good and the portions were huge! 

Overall - this restaurant seems to be a hole-in-the-wall, only not. The restaurant is clean, and the service is fast and friendly. This is like comfort food, Chinese style!
author: Betty S.

description: It so hard to give this place only 3 stars cuz I grew up eating all the food here. Not sure what happened and it has to do with the chef now but the quality is not the same. I still go here because I have been a long time customer. They even got rid of the bean hot sauce that I loves with my beef stew. That really changes everything for me!
author: King L.

description: Pretty good.  The portions are a bit small, so you might want to get two bowls, which still can end up under $10, so the prices are reasonable.
author: Javier G.

description:
You're getting what you pay for. That said, $3 for a bowl of won ton noodle soup is not going to be very spectacular...and it wasn't but it was still $3 so you can walk out the door without feeling you got jipped. You shouldn't anyway.

I only tried the won ton noodle soup but I don't think I would get it again. Or if I did, I would skip the noodles and just get the soup. Noodles were kind of hard to chew. I peeked at other tables and the other menu items didn't look that amazing either. Nonetheless, if you're looking to eat on the cheap, this is your spot.

Won Ton House is as ghetto as they come. Service is quick but don't expect it to come with a smile ;)
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
Sure it's cheap.  actually quite cheap.  but i wouldn't necessarily say the beef stew in soup noodles (ngow lam mein) was all that wonderful nor worth driving from northbeach to eat here.  Frankly, if i was hungering for some wonton mein, I'd venture further down the street to Ming Tai.

However, they have rice noodle rolls in plum and soy sauce (jyu cheung fun).

overall it was "just OK".
author: Jason J.

description:
So have you heard of thousand year old egg??  Well, I just had thousand year old char sui.  I ordered the char sui and duck over braised noodles and received duck fat and thousand year old char sui over noodles tossed in oyster sauce.  The wontons were unspectacular.  Oh, and the pot stickers we ordered for our appetizer, were served last after all the meals and not fully cooked.  The pot sticker wrappings were still doughy when biting into it.  Gross!

I would absolutely NOT come here again!
author: Dennis L.

description:
I have one word for this place: 

"meh."


I really wanted to like this place, it sounded good and cheap, but as expected, you get what you paid for.  my noodle dish had only noodles + meat in it, so I wanted some regular plain sauteed bok choy w/o all the oyster sauce drizzled on it, but she said "they didn't have it" when I see their chef/worker is eating a big ass plate of it right there. uhh WTF?

It filled my stomach, but I wasn't satisfied after still. probably not coming back.
author: Jennie L.

description: Uh, really?? i feel gross from eating there. I had the wonton noodle soup with bbq pork, and UGH!!!!! i give 1 star, because the waitress seemed nice and smiled. Otherwise, I paid $8 (with tip) for something really BAD. The noodles were passable. They soon wilted to softness though. The bbq pork was stale and all clumped together, because they were just taken out of the FREEZER. You can just tell. Same with the wontons - stale and the meat inside was a strange mushy texture. God, chinese people can be so damn cheap! THROW AWAY OLD FOOD! How do you serve this to people and sleep at night? and the soup tasted like instant ramen MSG packet soup. I'm sorry, but no. I left half of it untouched, and said no to a take-home container. I never do that. Now, I'm so thirsty.
author: Verna L.

description:
Every time I come here, It reminds me of how much I miss the won tons in Vancouver......Congee Noodle House, Hon's.........Daimo......just love those places.  This place however is filthy.  There hasn't been a time where I came here when I haven't seen a cockroach. The only reason why I came here was because of my friend Dom.  

As for the won tons..........It's average at best ........but in San Francisco......what can you expect.  I have not been to a restaurant in San Francisco that even comes close.  The noodles are OK but the broth is terrible.  Especially when you see a roach crawling on the wall ...........it kinda ruins your appetite.

It really wouldn't surprise me to see a small roach in the soup base once in a while.
author: jason g.

description:
Yelp's motto is Real People Real Reviews. What about for places that you haven't been in 10 years? Old People, Old Reviews?

Well I'm far from old =). But I'm not as hip to the hop, or "fresh" as some of you. But in reality it has been freakin ages since I last ate here. 

You see, 10+ years ago we were all different individuals. Likely some of you were still in elementary school, or just barely pubescent teens, like boys who then just discovered girls and cars and wondered why you were into ninjas, robots, and frogs in the first place. For girls, maybe you were thinking about what to get next at Forever 21 while trying to call into KMEL's hot jam line to dedicate that favorite Toni Braxton, Taylor Dane, Paula Abdul, Shanice ("Saving Forever For You" or "Loving You" from 9021HO)  or Mariah Carey song to your man boo to show how happy and in the moment you were at the time (but in retrospect should have chosen Lil Kim's "Eat My P**sy" instead because your man only wanted to please himself or his car and not you. EDIT: That song is called Not Tonight. Full lyrics here, enjoy: http://www.lyricsdepot.com/lil-kim/not-tonight.html) 

Me? I was ashamed that I still clung onto my first ever girlfriend then for 5 years from college.

Back then we didn't have yelp, or people like you to tell us what the latest and the greatest were for entertainment, hot date rendezvous,  where to go for a great dinner, movie, dessert, and then get some uninterrupted romp in the back seat action to steam up the windows of the car (and not make a mess). You see back then it was very simple. For us, maybe start off the day at lunch, SF Japantown, a little walk around the area. Perhaps a movie in the city somewhere, in the afternoon or after dinner. Next would be to grab some dessert, perhaps Golden Island Cafe or if the stomachs were growling, Won Ton House which conveniently closed by midnight on weekends (or was it 1 am) and the only game in town for a quick cheap bite. Yes, how boring, but hey if it ain't broke don't fix it! Repeat the same routine for upwards of 5 years. It gets boring sometimes. Yes this is a cheap Chinese/Cantonese date or routine. There were only so few cool, hip, and accessible spots back in the day for a nice date and evening.

Oh yeah going out on dates were not cheap, even if the date is a somewhat significant other. Spend quite a bit here, a little there, and next thing you know it is next weekend. Going out to different places can be tiring indeed. But sometimes the best meal could be the one at the end of the day, where you don't need a lot when you're hungry, but want something hot and satisfying, cheap, and quick. As much as I loved that romp in the backseat at some hidden public location which essentially was the same thing (hot, satisfying, cheap quick), it only made me hungrier afterwards. Won Ton House saved my life frequently during those afterhours, by offering this cheap Cantonese snack won ton noodle in soup. They also have the steam rice crepes (plain cheung fun) which is the same kind they get from the supermarkets (sometimes labeled as banh cuon in Vietnamese), which is a nice light night snack as well. Rice plates are ok, just hit the spot, and ditto with stir fried noodles.

There aren't many places like this in the South Bay or Peninsula, where a place like this serves a small but sufficient variety of Cantonese comfort foods, simple, cheap, quick, and open late.
While quality is not high by any means, this place gets 3 solid stars for being around so long and just dishing out the goods where they are needed.

P.S. I was kidding about the romp in the back seat. It did not happen every week, sigh....
author: Ken K.

description:
Gotta agree with Ed on this one: the main attraction here is the prices, which would make even a dedicated sunset scavenger do a double take.  So if I was a starving college student I'd probably give it an extra star, or even two, especially as I could afford to come here over and over searching for some gems hidden in the menu.  But the won-ton noodle soup, while serviceable, was padded out with a whole lot of ho-hum noodles, and I was really here for the won-tons.  So if you've got a won-ton craving, stick to Just Won Ton instead.  For the gainfully employed, the price difference is negligible, but the taste difference isn't.

Props for being open till midnight most nights, though.  Would pair well with a drink at The Yard across the street.
author: Wes M.

description:
Me: Hungry? 
Ed M: Nah, going to stay in. 
Me: Alright, guess I'll get something from Bay Fung Tong.

(20 minutes later)

Ed M: I'm hungry. I want something warm, like won-ton soup. Ooh, Won-Ton House! 
Me: Uh, I'm eating dinner right now. 
Ed M: It's so cheap! There's only 3 things over $6. We can go for dinner #2!

Some people may be taken aback by the concept of breakfast/lunch/dinner #1/#2 but I'm not. My mom raised me on lunch #2. She also raised me on midnight dinners. "Hey! Let's go drive 45 minutes for cheap Chinese food at 1AM!" I love my mom. 

Me: Ooh, I have been looking for a place that does good won-ton noodle soup. 
Ed M: Awesome, pick me up in 20.

Roommate: Hey, they gave me this huge box of curly fries with my fish and chips from Cable Car, do you want some?
Me: Uh, I'm going to dinner #2 soon...
(the smell of curly fries hits my nose)
Me: ME MUST EAT CURLY FRIES NOW!!!!!

I take the box of curly fries and pick up Ed M. I'm thinking "This is pure gluttony. Two Chinese dinners and curly fries. What is wrong with my life?" 

We end up getting two won-ton soups (mine with egg noodles, his with rice), fried turnip cake, and dumplings. The won-tons were moist, the broth was hot and flavorful - just like how mom makes it. The turnip cake was really good, considering it was 11PM.

At some point, the waitress took away my chopsticks and I started freaking out and throwing around my arms. They immediately noticed and gave me a new pair. Now THAT'S service. 

Our bill came out to $15. This will probably become my new cheap Chinese food place. 

My car now smells like curly fries.
author: Patrick L.

description:
I've come here many times over the years and I gotta say, they've been able to keep their prices relatively low compared to much of the competition.  This is certainly not a destination restaurant for me though I love this type of "simple" Chinese Food but it is cheap compared to many others so I'd still come once in a while but to me, it hasn't had that little extra kick.  When it first opened, it had that little extra kick because it was new.  But maybe I take this place for granted because it's been open for so long....  

Good Prices, Pretty Decent Food....
author: Mark W.

description:
Disgusting !!! Went here with my wife about six months ago. We sat  down and they brought the tea over... except there was a big cockroach on the cup! The waitress didn't even notice it. We called her back and she just brushed it off and brought the menus!! No apologies or anything.
Needless to say we didn't stay. Out the door like a shot and never looked back
author: Richie S.

description:
Good cheap eats! $3.95 for a bowl of won ton noodle soup?!!  The price may lead you to believe that the food may be sub par, but not so! 

The won tons are the most flavorful I have had for won ton soup and they even give you TWO, count em, TWO pieces of green veggie. hahaha. For the veggie fix, we ordered the Chinese broccoli in oyster sauce which was also tasty and well priced. 

Great place for a quick and belly warming meal.
author: Mashi M.

description:
The place is very easy to find parking. The noodle is nice. The soup is a little salty but still acceptable which make it tasty. Personally, I like  Shrimp Dumpling more than the won ton. It is more tasty and better texture. I also like the Beef stew. 
Overall, it is a good place for a quick lunch, good price for a bowl of shrimp dumpling.
author: Clement H.

description:
I've been coming here forever. Sometimes the food is great.  Other times, you'll leave half of your order uneaten and feel sick an hour or so later. Right now, things seem to be good.

I can't speak to the won tons as I don't eat shrimp.  I recommend getting the beef brisket noodle soup, the turnip cakes, and the curry pot stickers.

A lasting memory associated with Won Ton House is the time, many moons ago, I ran into my grade school PE teacher and her "friend" there.
author: Eating Sleeping T.

description: What a deal for simple, comfort Chinese congee (jook) and all sorts of noodles and dumplings.  A generous bowl of congee is less than $4; noodles with dumples are around $4-ish and rice plate are around $5-ish. It's clean and parking is relatively simple being that it's on Noriega.  Service is fast with no fluff.  I'd definitely go back again!
author: FoodJunkie S.

description:
I had almost forgotten about this place- have probably not eaten here since high school!  Had breakfast with my little guy here today and the Wonton Soup was just as good as I remembered.  For $3.95, you get a whole bowl of plump, juicy wontons, filled with pork and shrimp.  We also ordered a piping hot bowl of Fish Jook for $4.50.  Ahhh...so comforting!

Come here for the classics, no-frills dining, just good food on the cheap!
author: Judy K.

description: Good late night spot if you're feeling for some wonton noodle soup or some porridge. Been going to this place since I was little and the service has been exactly the same for the past 12 years. Hella cheap too if you're broke as fuck. You can get away with a bowl of wonton noodle soup for $5 bucks. Don't underestimate this place give it a try!
author: Jonathan C.

description: Cold evening at 11:30PM came to this place.  I tried their won ton soup and a beef brisket lomein to go.  I thought the won ton was OK not the best, however they give you a lot of it.  I had to take home half the order.  Their beef brisket lomein was great, flavorful and quite tender with some tendons.  I think they should name their place Beef Brisket Lomein House instead!
author: Jim J.

description: Yes, its cheap..I can't really write anything that is different from all these other reviews. Just that it was open when we wanted to go to Just Won ton. Similar won ton noodle soups. The soup itself was kinda bland and the won tons were kinda hard. But what do you expect for a 3 dollar bowl?
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
If you're looking for a quick, cheap eat... come here! The won-ton soup is literally only $4-5  and is pretty tasty and filling. 

I usually come here and get either the bbq pork won-ton soup or ngow jaap won-ton soup. Both are awesome and their chinese broccoli is delicious too. 

Ambiance, service, and fellow patrons are your typical Chinese restaurant fare. Bathroom is like a closet. Overall, get in, eat and get out... and you're good! I tend to like their won ton soup better here than Just Won Ton, but at Just Won Ton they have a lot more variety that tastes better too. I'm conflicted.
author: Christina B.

description:
Stick to their name sake (Won Ton noodle soup) and you can't miss.  Their other fairs are ...meh... really just there for variety only.   Knock off one star if you're there for anything other then Won Tons.

Plan to get here off peak (typical feeding time) if you drive and hope to get a parking space nearby.  But what's a few blocks between car and cheap good feed...
author: Ed F.

description:
Ok so if it's super cheap and Chinese, you can't really expect to have ambiance, for pete's sake.  At least not in a Chinese restaurant!  :)  

Cheap, large portions, greasy and hits the spot.  

The duck is not the best I've ever had, but to be able to get the duck in the same place as a bowl of won ton soup (won tons good!, noodles and broth about average), alongside some yummy greasy Chinese donut (ie. fried dough, China's idea of version of the tried and true that we love, but without the sweetness), and curry fried potstickers (new flavor on potstickers and pretty tasty, even with the grease oozing out)............

In just one sitting, my craving for some won tons and something with curry was met, my father's craving for noodles and soup was met, and my boyfriend's longing for greasy duck was met- all in one place.  

I'll overlook the lack of ambiance, and the need to wash the floor, for the food that hit the spot and the cheap prices.
author: Denise B.

description:
Very cheap food for decent quality!  Majority of all the menu's items are about 5 dollars more or less.  Open conveniently late for night diners/snackers!

Tonight, on my first visit here, I ordered #2 - the Won Ton soup.  Somebody in my party ordered the #1 - the Won Ton Noodle soup.  Both of the prices were the same: $3.95.  The difference ewas that hers came with noodles, cabbage, and about 4 wontons, while mine came with cabbage and about 8 wontons made of shrimp/pork.  I don't know if she had shrimp in hers as well.  Anyways, it was a darn good deal!  

I'm usually not too big on chinese food either, mind you.  Honestly,  tonight I wanted to go for the Roast Duck over Rice but I was skeptical as to whether they would give me slabs of fatty duck; it being on the cheap end of prices, usually resulting in poor quality.  However, upon reviewing my fellow diner's Roast Duck Noodle Soup, the duck pieces were not half bad!  They were decent slabs of meat!  I'll be sure to give that one a try next time. 

Service is acceptable.  There seemed to be only one waitress or so working the floor - but that was enough.  The food came QUICK - within 5-8 minutes of ordering.  She came by and refilled our tea cups as needed.
author: Leslie Y.

description:
Came here on a Thursday afternoon after a crazy work day... I just wanted a bowl of noodle soup to cheer me up.

I ordered the spicy beef noodle soup, and it was ALL bad.

The soup base was just like any other soup base they use. If it's beef noodle soup, it should at least be beef broth and with different spices. So no, I did not enjoy the soup.

The noodles were undercooked. Why were they in such a hurry? I was their only customer at 5:30pm.

The beef was BRIGHT RED from the outside. Looks like it was artificially dyed. I've had countless bowls of beef noodle soup in my lifetime and this was by far the worst. Authentic... definitely NOT.

I mean, the place was cheap, I guess I shouldn't have expected too much.
author: Lynn C.

description:
Woke up with horrible stomach pains on Sunday morning, so my mom suggested we have brunch at won ton house for something light and not too greasy. 

I grew up in the Sunset district, so Won Ton House always brings a little comfort to me. I ordered a bowl of wonton noodles for $3.95 (wow! beat that!) and proceeded to devour the chinese girl's version of chicken-noodle-soup. The noodles were at a perfect soft-yet-crunch texture, the soup was flavorful (not bland like Hon's!), and the whooping 6 wonton's I got were the perfect Goldilocks size (not too big, not too small). Overall it was just the perfect bowl of comfort noodle soup for me and my stomach.

I don't understand why this place isn't busier on a Sunday morning, perhaps with plenty of other restaurant offerings in the area, a cheap o' bowl of wonton isn't always too appealing. But there's that saying..you can take the girl outta wonton, but you can't take the wonton outta the girl.
author: Nancie T.

description: For about $4 you can get the best won ton noodle soup between 10pm to midnight. What else do you want as an Asian.
author: Solomon C.

description:
Do not go to this place, I ordered a Shrimp Dumping Noodle Soup and a BBQ Pork plate, the Shrimp Dumping Noodle Soup portion was so small that I could finish eating it in 2 mins or so, and the BBQ Pork tasted funny, now my stomach is feels weird, and when I was there, no one was in there, now I know why..

I repeat do not I go to this place.
author: David C.

description:
This place is downright cheap, not just inexpensive.  We always get the same things:  won ton noodle soup for me, roasted duck noodle soup for husband, noodle soup (2) for girls, rolled ho fun with plum sauce (housemade white soft noodles in the sauce with a light amount of white sesame seeds) for all, turnip cake (2 orders - we're all obsessed) and gai lan (Chinese brocolli in light soy/garlic sauce).  If it's the weekend, we sometimes skip the ho fun and go with the fried dough, which is greasy hot deliciousness especially when dipped in the hot soups.  You can dip the turnip cake in the soup, too, or it might accidentally fall into the soup if your chopstick skills are similar to mine-- then you can fish it out.  Red bean drink is delicious.  Hot tea is dangerously hot; I have an s-shaped burn scar on my arm from when I knocked the hot tea onto my arm in the late 90s, so I am much more cautious with those cups.  

Service is hilariously indifferent but at the same time they always take our orders immediately, bring the food out promptly, and provide our bill with no comment.  Our meals, paid for with cash, usually cost around $25 and we get so much food it is always impressive.  We're all quite sensitive to MSG and have never noticed its effects post-meal, so we aren't sure it's used in the foods we eat, but the food provides a high that may mask minor sins.  Did I mention the turnip cake?  It is consistently the best one I've ever had, even from high end dim sum restaurants in SF like Yank Sing and lower end dim sum joints in Oakland's Chinatown.  We usually order extra and bring it home to the family.
author: Erin M.

description:
Ugh BF took me to this place and it was not good at all. I mean what kind of good food do you expect for $3.50? Had wonton noodles, and salted cabbage and pork noodles in soup and It was overly salty, bland at the same time, sort of like eating a cardboard box with salt.

I am from HK and good wonton noodles are not supposed to be like this. Gross, just yuck and I will never go back here.  The stuff I can make at home with frozen wontons taste so much better. Stay away! The only thing good about this place is its CHEAP. I don't eat cheap food.
author: Petri Y.

description:
This place is great! For some reason, it's never crowded, usually half empty or less. Which is GREAT cuz I hate crowds and loud talking. 

Food is tasty enough. I love the rice congees. Or if I'm really hungry, the beef stew noodles or rice plates will fill me up for cheap. 

Fast service, cheap prices, no crowds, and good food. What else does a hungry man need?
author: Johnny D.

description:
Good cheap Chinese comfort food.  I have been coming here for 15 years, at least.  You may not be "wowed" but this place is always consistent - from the food to fact that the same waitresses have been here just as long!  My usuals are the roast duck noodle soup, shrimp dumplings, preserved egg and pork congee (perfect comfort food if you're not feeling 100%), and the plate of gai lan is a steal too!
This is a simple won ton house - don't expect your full Chinese menu.  I was once here and the ignorant customer cursed out the soft-spoken waitress for not having hot and sour soup or sweet and sour pork on the menu!  I'm happy I'll never have to see them there again.
author: Amina B.

description: The food is really cheap.  It's insanely cheap and the food is good.  It's quiet most of the time I'm here later in the night.  Typical Chinese service in the city.  Place is pretty dirty though =/..
author: John H.

description:
Love the simple comforts of noodle soups and chinese BBQ pork. their congee is pretty good---given this was the third time I've had it. 

parking is a challenge but well worth it when you just want fast cooking.
author: Jessie M.

description: I love this place! It`s cheap and so yummy! I love their wonton noodle soup. Always come here when I`m on a fix for some cheap good wonton soup! :) So glad I found this place on yelp since me and my friends were craving for something soupy and cheap. Good stuff. Their dried noodles are good too.
author: Stella C.

description: I was debating on whether giving this 3 or 4 stars and decided to go with 4. This place is fairly simple and never really disappoint. They really only offer a few things and that's a good thing. That way you know that they specialize in a particular type of food. You can not beat the price here, you get the most bang for your buck. Most of their stuff is under $5 which is extremely difficult to find in SF. The best thing got going for this place is the noodles for obvious reasons. Anything goes well with noodles soup whether it be roast pork, duck, fish ball, etc. This place will warm you up on a cold winter day! I come here on a regular basis during my break from state. The rice plates are ok, they tend to give you more rice than actual food so I suggest sticking to noodles. If you are looking for a cheap, quick place to eat then this is it.
author: Gary T.

description: Real hole in the wall style. Helps if you speak "hongkong-nese". Also by HK standards, this place is spacious and clean. Unfortunately in SF, ppl will feel this place is a health risk. Feh. What doesn't kill me only makes me stronger. This place is a dying breed. One more star to support it but minus one for the MSG overload.
author: Chris C.

description:
This place is very affordable and convenient to go to.  I come here when i crave won tons.  Its only 3.95 for won ton noodle soup! and theres like 6 wontons.. i believe. 

When hungry, we order the cheap sides like 'Lo bok go' and pig ears which is our favorite.  All soaked in red vinegar.  

The tea is super hot !!  But this is good because i hate cold to warm-cold tea.  Must be HOT or warm-hot.  

I tried the rice plates with roast pork and duck but i don't suggest it because you should usually get those things at the place where they hang em up front since thats how you know its fresh and fat!

Too bad they close at 11 and sometimes 12 because i'd like to come here at 2am for snacks.  4 stars!!

o yeah, they dont accept credit/debit card, so have cash
author: Warren G.

description:
Good cheap eats! Won ton noodles were tasty, and smelled wonderful with the little drizzle of sesame oil.

Also had the liver porridge. Loads of liver (in relation to porridge) so it was a bit much. But my fault for ordering porridge at a Won Ton place.

Not bad for a $3.95 bowl of noodles at 10.30pm. It's a little dingy and not totally inviting looking, but hey, it's a no-fuss $4 meal. I can live with it.
author: v w.

description: I've come to eat here before with an old buddy of mine since it was near his place. We used to stay up really late driving around in his prelude and watching horror movies late. There wasn't really anything else open so we would eat here and I would have the pot stickers, just average in my opinion and I've had their soup pho with egg noodles which is pretty good. The servers were always nice and polite when I went but I'll have to update this review later as I haven't been there in a few years.
author: Petra S.

description:
I have always thought about eating here, especially after one of my friends bought me some wonton soup from here to go.  So, the other night, my bf, who had been here before, suggested we come here for some wonton soup.  We both were trying to fight off a cold, so we needed something filling yet light.  The soup really hit the spot for us, especially the tasty wontons.  I have had wonton soup at various places and the wontons here are actually quite good.  We also decided to try the curry beef potstickers which were very tasty.

We'll be coming here again whenever we have a craving for good wonton soup or curry potstickers.
author: V B.

description:
Quick good eats here. 
Everything is pretty tasty but beware odd parts of chicken or pigs feet on the menu. Kinda sick.  
I like the Jook (porridge). And the beef stew over rice is pretty good but too much tendon makes me a little naucious..
Quick eats here.. dont expect fine dining.
author: JASON L.

description:
Wontons, noodles, tripe and the best tasting chili sauce ever. Just around the corner the Wanton House is the perfect cure for  hunger, cold,  
hangover or whatever else ails you.
author: john s.

description:
Beware of the nuclear hot tea!  You have to let it cool down at least ten minutes before you drink, unless you want to lose all sense of taste from your tongue.  I think they rigged their water heater to boil their water at 500 degrees.

Other than that, the food here is good and cheap.  Stick with their soup noodles or braised noodles.  Their rice dishes are nothing spectacular.

p.s.  It's too bright in here.  I don't enjoy eating under the spotlights.
author: Ezduzit S.

description:
I always come here for the #16 stewed beef brisket over lo mein.  Been coming here for years for the lo mein.

I've tried the other stuff on the menu here and it just seems ok.
author: Charles K.

description: ordered the beef brisket soup. which was the worst soup i have ever had, mostly fat and that's what it tasted like. and the noodles were uncooked. the ginger chicken was so-so. prolly my worst meal in SF. im not a fan of won-ton soup, so maybe thats whats good here, but judging by the soup i got i wouldnt dare try anything else. i understand its cheap, but theres plenty of places that are cheaper or the same price ex. all the ones on taraval or even the infamous sam wo's in chi town. well than again nothing in my opinion beats Kingdom of Dumpling in the sunset.
author: Amien P.

description:
My favorite place for Mongolian Beef over Rice.  SO LEGIT.  Any of the Lo Mein dishes are winners, too.  And don't forget the porridge for when you are sick!  Chinese people all know what's up with the porridge action.  This place has some of the best potstickers in the city too.  Oh yes, Cantonese comfort food to the max.

Watch your step, that entranceway is crazy ghetto.  Glad they put a ramp in recently.
author: Warren L.

description:
Food was okay. Tried the noodle soup with chicken. A nice portion of noodles and tasty broth. 
Prices here are super cheap, lots of menu items under $5. 
Service was fast also.
author: Miss H K.

description: I personally really like this place.  It's cheap, filling and delicious.  I usually get the zhong and maybe a red bean ice drink.  It's just a nice place to get simple, good Chinese food at a really affordable price.
author: Melanie W.

description: Decent cheap and good wonton place steps away from my house that opens till late too! Not bad not bad~!
author: Chloé N.

description: for something fast, cheap and good won ton house is the place to go.  I've been here many many times.  this time I ordered the beef stew won ton noodles.  plenty of flavor and decent portions.  to top it off it's like I was back in hong kong.  I refilled my own cup of tea.  service here is better than hong kong.  at least the waitresses acknowledge your existence.  their side dishes aren't bad either.  I'll definitely be back since it won't take a big chunk out of my wallet.
author: Samson M.

description:
I love this place. Their porridge rice soups and wonton noodles are good. But what I really come here for is the Beef Brisket over rice. The portions are generous. Imagine, juicy and flavorful brisket on top of warm cooked cabbage and rice.  And all this for under $5 bucks!

The food comes out lightening fast and the place opens late. What more can you ask for!
author: Ace C.

description:
I thought the wonton was decent enough and the food was served fast.

The prices are decent too.

It took a while to get the waiter's attention, but I figure as much in Asian restaurants because that is usually the case.
author: Michelle L.

description:
Good meal to eat at a reasonable/cheap price. 
Limited menu; but they do know how to make won-ton noodle soup.
Fast friendly service.
author: J B.

description:
There are many ways to eat your way out of a hangover but my one of my favorites is the ancient chinese secret: roast duck jook, chinese donuts and tea. And that my friends, is exactly why I head to Won Ton House after a big night out.

I was first introduced to Won Ton House by my husband (a SF native and avid Chinese food lover) several years ago. And honestly I've never had much else on the menu there.  Their roast duck jook has just the right amount of flavoring and "richness" to ease any alochol abused body. And their Chinese broccoli is always tasty! Wash it all down with hot tea and I promise you'll be ready to take on the world by 2pm - well you'll be ready to take on the TV the rest of the afternoon from your couch. :)

Don't expect happy cheery faces to greet you. Though when I went there on Chinese New Year I did receive service with a smile and a short conversation that I didn't understand. But that's cool. I just nodded my head, smiled and ate my jook.
author: Stephanie I.

description:
Been here a couple of times and its always the same thing to get since they always make these great.  First, theres the appetizer of fried turnip pancake which is a great because it's crispy on the outside and soft and tasty in the inside, the fundamental qualities of a turnip pancake.  

For the noodle soup, I always pick the beef stomach or beef stew with flat rice noodles or the thin egg noodles because they make it so fresh and it comes in this msg filled soup that is great.  Add in some dumplings for an extra dollar or two and it seals the deal.  I had an earlier review of a noodle house with these such toppings from NY and it just reminds me of that.  good stuff!  anddddd they have this spicy chili sauce on the table that they make themselves and I always add it into my soup to give it that extra kick.
author: Vincent K.

description:
You cannot beat this price.  Wonton was very very good.  Yes the portion is rather small, but it is less than $4 - so you can get other things too.
Clean and quick service.
I was very happy about this place!
author: Miinno N.

description:
The won tons here are huge! The porridge was great here as well! The prices are cheap too!

However, the best part about this place is the Chinese donut (the long, deep fried thingy) wrapped with flat rice noodle with a nutty sweat sauce and a sweet soy sauce.
author: Andrew W.

description:
I came here for lunch by my friend's suggestion.  I have been craving some good wonton noodles for a while, so I was interested in trying this place out.  I ordered the wonton noodles with BBQ pork.  The pork was tasty and the wontons not bad.  The broth was pretty flavorless and a little disappointing.  My friend ordered the jook with pork and 1000 yr-old egg which was also pretty good -- maybe even better than the noodles.

Bottom line: Cheap prices, so-so food.  Still looking for a wonton noodle place...
author: Katie M.

description: Small hole-in-the-wall place, street parking only.  Limited menu, like the name says won ton soup is their specialty.  Sit down, get boiling hot tea and order from the two page (back-to-back) menu.  It's fast, inexpensive and good, especially for a late snack on a cold day.  Pork Won Ton Mein is my fave.  This place has been here for at least 25 years or longer (I think the decor has not changed), open til midnight.
author: Larry G.

description:
I usually order the won ton noodle soup or the sampan porridge. Very simple but very satisfying. 

But the tastiest item on the menu are the curry pot stickers. I'd be fine if they decided to change the place's name to Curry Pot Sticker House.  I was bummed out one time when they told us the person who makes them was on vacation and they did not have curry pot stickers that night. 

Great little place in the Sunset for a quick meal. Almost never a wait and it's a better deal than any of the nearby pho places.
author: Calvin P.

description:
This is probably the best wonton there is in the Sunset.  Probably the cheapest place there is for decent wonton, only $3.95! The noodles are okay, not particularly good. The service is also fair. 

If you do come here, I recommend only numbers 1 and 2. The rest of the menu is really not that good, or not worth it. 

I wish this place accepted credit cards!
author: Jay L.

description:
Cheap, tasty, and relatively clean for a Chinese joint. What more can you ask for?

I've been coming here for a long time, and I always order some variation of soup noodles. Generally I cycle between beef stew, won tons, and shui gau. Sometimes if I can't decide and I'm really, really hungry, I order a combination of beef stew and shui gau with soup noodles. Mmm, yummy! The noodles are perfect to me - not too soft, with enough bite/chewiness. I can't stand overcooked, mushy noodles. And this is my favorite place for won tons and shui gau. 

The red bean iced drink is also very good.

And you can't forget the pan-fried turnip cake! I don't know if they make it themselves or just buy ready-made and pan-fry it, but they have the best pan-fried turnip cake EVER. Crispy on the edges, but not hard. Not sticky because of too much rice flour, either!
author: Priscilla L.

description:
simple, cheap, fast.... just how i like em!

open late, great in for cold weather dinner/late night.

oh yea, and they're like 2 blocks from my house!
author: Ameer N.

description: I came here for the second time just a couple of days ago and was disappointed with the food. The food was bad this time. The porridge was tasteless and the liver was getting overcooked and chewy as it sat in my bowl while I was eating it. I would have had to eat all the liver first for that not to happen or eat a lot faster. The bowl of porridge was really hot though so I could really only eat so fast. I had to add some table seasoning to help it along. It's time to find a new place for liver porridge...=(
author: Helen L.

description: Just the hot sauce they provide on the table is 3 stars! I usually go for the shrimp wonton egg noodle. Fast service. Fills you up... and DIRT cheap!
author: Lisa M.

description: Can't be picky with cheap wonton noodle soup. The pot stickers are pretty good, but they take a while to cook them. Also the cold noodles with spicy sauce is good. Usually there is never a wait for a table here and parking is available in the streets.
author: David N.

description:
My husband and some buddies and I ventured out to Mount Tam for a double dipsea hike yesterday.   For the first 5 of the 8 hours of the hike the weather vacillates between fog sprinkles to rain....     At day's end we're pretty soggy, drenched, and chilled to the bone.  

Only the constant mantra of won ton house, and the thoughts of hot noodle soup kept us on.     

I can generally order as soon as the waitress stops by our table with the cups of tea.   Szechuan beef stew over rice for hubby, Seafood Dumpling and Wonton in soup for hiking buddy #1, Wonton noodle soup for hiking buddy #2, and a combo beef tripe and seafood dumpling with flat rice noodle, pan fried radish cake, and oyster sauce chinese broccoli (gai lan), plus a diet coke.    

We generally pick the table with the fullest chili jars and we eat up the whole jar of their special chili sauce.  I've asked, and the waitress reports they make their own with picked vegetables and a smoky chili base.   yummmm.... super good with the pan fried radish cake.   I also ladle my spoon full of the flat rice noodles and apply some chili on each bite.      They give tons of dumplings and their flat rice noodles are cooked through, soft and with good bite.

meal for 4 hungry and very cold people... $31.67     Service has always consistently been great - fast and with frequent tea and water refills.

We leave very full satisfied and most importantly...  our core is warm once again.
author: Regi K.

description:
Mmmm...great for a typical chinese breakfast of porridge or won-ton noodle soup or late night dining of some chinese specialty snacks. I come here at least once a week (and I don't even live in SF anymore...) Everytime I come back on the weekends, I always have to head over here. When I feel like I want something a little healthier, I go for some fish or sampan porridge ($4) and when I'm just starving and carnivorous, I go for their braised beef brisket over noodles ($6). Everything is enough for two, but it's so good that I always finish my own plate. Along with a main dish, I always get the pork ears($4) (I know it sounds really gross..and I thought so too until I tried it)...yes, it's pig ears, marinated, cooked, then sliced...its semi-soft, semi-crunchy (due to the cartilage) and served cold with a drizzle of sesame oil on top. 

Along with they really great, tasty food, the service is always FAST and really good here too....since I go here so much, one of the servers knows us and even gives us a bigger portion of pork ears without the oil (thats how we always ask for it, so I can eat it with chili oil instead of sesame oil). 

It gets packed here on Saturday and Sunday afternoons, and also at the time when I usually go, 11 at night on weekdays.
author: Jessica h.

description:
Cheap

Fast

Good for the hung-over belly

Satisfying

Won-Ton
author: Jen Y.

description: Just read the Yelp reviews & it's late at night.  I just need something fast & warm.  This place open late, fast service, & inexpensive.  I would go back for more take out.
author: Nancy T.

description: This place is just ok, and if I didn't live nearby it wouldn't be worth the drive. The main draws are it's decently priced and they're open really late. Parking can be annoying at times because of it's location right on Noriega across the street from a busy dessert place (also open late) but it's not too much trouble.
author: Peter W.

description:
i was craving for wonton noodles for awhile.. so my friend introduced me here for a late lunch get together. 

walked in empty (again, its a late lunch) the menu is front and back, easy- simple. i came in with two friends, we got seated right away and the lady came out with 3 cups of hot tea. we took a 2 minute look and ready to order. the wait was fast and my wonton noodles came out delish! its also cheap too. i would definitely come back.
author: Valerie N.

description:
I only go here for two things (and not people have mentioned about these). 1. Spicy beef over rice. 2. Fried turnip cake. 

First of all the spicy beef is not something you'd find at every chinese restaurant in the neighborhood (at least not the kind they serve here), but this has got to be one of best I've tried. I've recommended to friends and they all love it. A lot of ppl seem to complain about the noodle soup here; they haven't tried spicy beef over rice. I know it's a wonton house, but.. Fact is, their spicy beef is the bomb. The beef is tender and comes in a reasonable portion, and most of all, you can taste that it's not some generic beef stew; you can tell it's homemade from scratch and they sure know what they're making. Mix in their spicy pickled dish they always have on the tables which really goes well with the rice (careful not to have too much! It's a bit spicy so having too much, you might regret the next morning ;) you've been warned). 

Last but not least, starting off the meal with the fried turnip cake is a must :) Just like someone else mentioned, it's crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. After these two dishes, I come out of there stuffed as hell. Prolly not the best for a diet, but I have to go there once in a while to get my spicy beef fix :)
author: Shongi H.

description: Best wonton ever.  Huge wonton with big chunks of shrimp.  And for less than $5?  What a steal.  Sure, not a place to sit and linger for a long time but the food is damn good.
author: Melinda C.

description: Yes, it's a hole in the wall, but it's got good solid Wonton noodles, altho a little bland.
author: C L.

description:
Ok...Ok... Cheap chinese food, in and out... I felt like I was in a street vendors booth and ordered right off the rolling cart. The won tons are filliung and the other specialties are not like mom's but they will do, especially since it's only a few dollars. The jook is pretty consistent and not at all chunky...

The homemade hot sauce is pretty tasty with all of the turnips in it... I guess you can always pick out all of the turnips and really make them made., but hey, it's free.

Great late evening place. they stay open pretty late.
author: robert C.

description: Good they open late. The porridge was steamy hot but very thin. I ordered a port and preserved egg porridge I got only egg nut no pork. Others ordered won ton noodles they said it was average.
author: Rose O.

description: the place is decently good and cheap and the service is quick. my boyfriend had the shrimp dumpling noodle soup and i had the won ton noodle soup. they tasted the same to me... both were a shrimp-pork combination. the broth was just okay... nothing spectacular. the gailan was awesome but i'd pass on the pot stickers. since we ordered so much food, it was $22 after tax and tip for two noodle soups, pot stickers, gailan, and a soda.
author: Kimberly S.

description: finally came here again in ages, always order my #26 bbq pork and roast duck over dried noodle. the price went up $6+ and the portion got smaller with lesser roast duck and bbq pork. let's get down the taste, noodle and soup still the same... but the roast duck and bbq pork taste microwaved, the ends are kinda chewy so yeah... even tho its still cheap for a quick lunch or dinner but the qty has went down...
author: JessePanda C.

description: This is a decent place for a cheap bowl of noodle soup. I feel that the noodles could be better. One plus about this restaurant is that it opens very late (closes midnight or later).
author: H K.

description:
Good food, cheap prices. 

I love the won ton noodle soup here. Quick, delicious and cheap. Parking can be a pain some times since it's on Noriega, but it's manageable.
author: Rick L.

description:
Great late-night place. I was expecting greasy and was pleasantly surprised that it was not.  
Four dishes for under $20 is my new benchmark for a cheap place.  Definitely get the Schezwan beef over rice...
author: Brent W.

description: One of the best wonton place in sf....This place is very affordable. The service was fast and great. I usually order the duck with wonton. The broth is very tasty and the portion is huge.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
The won-ton in here are hugh dumplings but what's it good for if they don't  taste right.  

I only ordered their Braised Beef Brisket over noodle and the red-bean drinks.   I would give these two a 4-stars but a 2-stars for the won-ton.
author: Jenny C.

description:
Disgusting!!! 
Food was bad, place was dirty. It was cheap, but definitely for a reason.
author: ratty r.

description:
BEST WON TON period.

Great quick eats place.  Nice easy-going atmosphere and the prices are great.  To-go orders are always done without a long wait, nice for lunch dinner and late nite.
author: david w.

description: This place is fast, cheap and open late just like the manatee.  You can get soup noodles or rice porridge for under $4.  Freakin ridiculous.  The food here is average canto food.  I ate here for convenience cuz I was driving buy after a night of drinking.  I wouldn't eat here for a regular meal time.
author: Fatty A.

description:
After reading the reviews and eating at the restaurant I'm somewhat puzzled as to how this restaurant can get 3.5 stars?  I do admit that the place is fast and inexpensive to eat and for $10-12 you can get a lot of food.  But as someone who has eaten a lot of wontons this place really disappoints.  The soup and wontons were salty.  Too salty in fact to actually enjoy it.  That is if there was anything to enjoy in the wonton.  The filling was bland.  There was really no taste.  Soup?  Was that really soup or just water and soy sauce?  
Comparing the wontons to some restaurants in Oakland's Chinatown or even San Francisco's Chinatown, this place would be last on the list for wontons.  I find it ironic that the Won-Ton-House does not serve killer wontons.  
The beef porridge I give it 3 stars.  Yes, I've had better somewhere else.
Maybe people should be grouped such as those that are 1) cheap and will eat anything, 2) people who are cheap but are willing to pay a little extra for better tasting food, and 3) people that go all out.  It seems that a lot of the people who give this place 5 and 4 stars fall under category 1.  Don't care what it taste like as long as it's cheap.  I guess I'm not that type of person and have grown to actually like good tasting food and am willing to pay a little extra for it.  So there goes my review for this place and will I go back there again?  Chances are 98% that I will not likely go back to this place when I can get something better somewhere else.
author: David L.

description:
weeeeee ! been coming here since the early 90's with my bestest friend, the connoisseur of all things soupy, porridgey, and brothy. the only thing I ever order is the wonton soup w/oodles of noodles, the perfect antidote to a bad cold or the flu. they give you 6 yummilicious wontons in a giant bowl (or mega-size styrofoam container if it's to-go), careful you don't scorch your tongue. you will spend less here than for a 6-pack of Campbell's (which I love also) !

my pal orders many things on the menu I would rather not know the translation of; some jap sum thing which she devoured, smacking her lips the whole time. it looked ookie but whatev, she enjoyed. who am I to tell someone not to eat freeze-dried eggs and pig ears
author: Prima D.

description: So I went here on a recommendation from a friend of mine. Obviously I ordered the won-ton mein and wasn't disappointed! The won-ton were really good and there a was a decent amount of noodles in the bowl too. If you're decently hungry, I would recommend ordering two bowls to satisfy your hunger. But don't be mistaken, the food is delicious and cheap. The won-ton mein is $3.95 and the homemade pot stickers ridiculously delicious and worth ordering as well! If you're looking for a good place to get won-ton mein and don't feel like going all the way into chinatown, this is the place!!!
author: Nick C.

description: This place has been here ever since I was a little girl. They have good food and excellent red bean ice drink. Prices compare to McDonalds. Except you get better genuine food!
author: Stefanie Y.

description:
everyone seems to love their curry potstickers.... so it seems to be a must-have if you eat here... but order in advance if possible b/c it does take a while to prepare.

i love their... rice wrapped with the leaves thing.  i dont know the english name, but it's hella good.  the fatty pork inside is delicious.

wontons are okay... although i expected better for a restaurant named after the dish...

overall, cheap and dont expect much from ambiance... (i swear to god there was dish soap in my tea!!!)
author: Tina L.

description:
Not too many places where you can get inexpensive Chinese comfort food late at night. CASH ONLY, that's why.  They're opened until midnite daily except on Sundays.  We had just returned from Florida (can't find good Chinese food in Orlando) and wanted Chinese food but everywhere we called were closed except here.  5 orders ran us $25. Their congee is watered down but passable.  The won ton noodles are good and the beef stew noodles are very good with ample chunks of beef.  The curry beef tendon over rice was fair, if you just like to chew on tendon and not really eat anything.  There are ample tables around.  Not the best Chinese food to be had but not the worse either.
On a 2nd day, I stopped for take-out. The stewed beef brisket noodle soup was too salty and the beef pieces were dry and tough.  The Szechuan spicy beef over rice was flavorful and not too spicy with cooked pieces of lettuce, a lot of rice but "where's the beef?"   The won ton soup was fair.  You get about 5 pieces of chunky won ton.  I do like their won ton noodles which are thin and chewy.  The roast duck won ton was same as above, just a rare few pieces of duck.  If you want better won ton noodle soup with duck, then Win's on Taraval is the better place for this.
author: Ry T.

description: This is the classic "homey" cooking style restaurant that has the real "local" feel.  The wonton soup is to die for as well as the shanghai annual cake(pronounced:  "tzu ni ca") and the curry potstickers.  The atmosphere is pretty tired but the cheap prices and amazingly delicious food make this small restaurant a MUST if you're in the area.
author: Patrick C.

description:
I am suspcious why this place get 3 1/2 stars;-P
did the owner pay yelp off?
the wonton was awlful, and this place is named wonton house, go figure.
Everything was so salty.  The msg level so high it can pickle your gut and no amount of tea can wash it off.
I am normally not picky about salt or msg. This place is rediculous.
My wonton has grits in there, portion is small.  You get what you pay for.  And I have to go get something else to fill my stomach.
Somehow before I left I understand how bad is their food.
It is so bad that they do TAKE-OUTS.
If I saw that before I sat down, I would have left.
Someone came in and bough some boil ginger chicken and other kind of meat dish, and I saw them chow down someone elses' food.
How strange is that?? 
I was kind of cold and hungry wanting to drink some soup and end up very thirsty and sick from the msg.
Needless to say first time custom and will also the last time.
author: Mar H.

description: Taste to price ratio excellent!  Most stuff under $5 -- good comfort food for cheap.  Jook perfect consistency, nice amount of ginger/salt/onion, large amount of ingredients, whichever type you order.  A classic fast, cheap, lunch or late night focused joint.
author: Rob C.

description:
I've been going here since like 1995.   I decided to give them 5 stars because they never mess up my order and there  food is consistent no matter what. Its easy to order by numbers and your order comes out fast. Although their name is won ton house, I dont really get won tons here. However  when i do get it i only order the wontons and no noodles. I guess my standards on what won tons should taste like is not to high, since I grew up eating San Francisco Won Tons.
I usually order 19 or was it 20 , its cha cheung meen (minced pork and noodles).  its different from the Korean style cha cheun myung though. I also get the pig ears and a plate of chinese vegetables with no oyster sauce. I just top everything off with the brown hot sauce and its good to go. Also I started to order the ginger chicken and rice. The chicken seems like its boiled but when u eat it with the ginger and oil its all gude.
I have still yet to find a good won ton mein comparable to Asia.
author: DOM d.

description: I come here for cheap eats. The food is good I really like the minced pork saucy noodles and the turnip cake
author: Karen T.

description:
what's not to like about a place that:
1) offers a generous portion of egg noodles in piping hot soup
2) serves turnip cakes ALL DAY
3) ....and serves you QUICKLY!!  (when i'm hungry...i'm HUNGRY)
4) But the icing on the cake??!???  their cheap prices!  ~$5 per noodle soup
author: Valerie F.

description: Excellent cheap food!  My favorites are the BBQ pork won ton noodles, preserved egg porridge and the turnip cakes.  Definitely a staple when I used to live in SF - I miss it.  Great for a quick, cheap dinner - especially on those cold nights in the Sunset.
author: Jamie W.

description: I have eaten here my whole life.  The staff has not changed since I was 3, but business has sure been quiet for the past couple of years..people used to hang out there late at night..but nothing else has changed..the menu is the same great food, won tons, red bean drinks, sticky rice, porridge, all good choices and LOW LOW prices.  Please come and support!
author: kim w.

description: Won-Ton House rocks!   Great noodle soups and jook.  Service is super fast, and you can't beat the price.  Early 1990's prices I tell ya!  Great for people on a college budget.
author: Rick K.

description: The last time that I ate here was in Nov 2004.  I remember the night well, as my friend and I had just spoken with a realtor in the area.  It was late and a quick bite was what we were craving.  I'd been to this place many times earlier in the year with my ex- and enjoyed it very much....until this night.  I know I had the beef stew with noodles...I forget what my friend had.  Whatever it was, didn't sit well the next morning.  We both ended up sick.  Unfortunately, I haven't been back...mainly because it's out of my way.  I'm game to give it another go...
author: JeFF T.

description: I live 2 blocks from this place and so I've steadily had this food growing up.  I have no complaints and the food is always delicious.  Their wonton noodle soup is great (never had a bad bowl and I've probably had DOZENS of em), their "joong" is the best I've ever tried -the consistancy is perfect and there is just the right amount of chew to it.  Be warned that they do sometimes run out of joong tho!  Anyways they've never once disappointed and the price is more than reasonable - you can probably feed 2 people for about 10 dollars (if you do take out)
author: Ann H.

description: It's good on a cold day when you are sick or hungover and you don't feel like having any pho.  The won tons are substantial, not wimpy.  The broth will spread warmth all over your body.
author: Tabatha Y.

description: I do love cheap good eats! Expect to spend less than $6 (includes tip) when you come here for a bowl of won ton noodle soup (there are usually five won tons in the bowl). Other dishes are also pleasantly tasty and inexpensive.
author: Teresa Y.

description: I absolutely love it here.  Maybe I just love the hot sauce here but shit the food goes good with it.  I'm craving some wonton noodles right now and the hot sauce.
author: Allison T.

description:
Had their food about three times.  

First time: Had wonton thin egg noodle soup and for their name, it was a big disappointment.  Lack of flavor soup base and the wonton was nothing special.

Second time: Had their beef stew noodle, it was very good and also very greasy.  Yeah, had that coming, but still.

Third time: Had their shredded pork and preserved mustard green rice noodle.  I was looking forward to this dish because at the time all I wanted was that.  First bite into the veggie and tasted the nice salty goodness of the preserved veggie and then into the meat and it tasted kind of funny sour and I thought it was from the preserved greens as it its a tad bit sour.  Before taking my third bite and as a force of habit, I started mixing the toppings around so I can get even noodle to meat and veggie portion.  Lo-and-behold some of  the meat was green.  They served me rancid meat.  That would explain the tartness of the meat. Called the server lady over and told her about it and she said that it looked fine, but willing to take it away then asked if I want something else.  I felt like puking and was no mood to eat and declined the offer.  Then I waited for my friend to finish eating and asked for the bill.  They charged me for the disgusting bowl they got back, which, by-the-way made me gagged followed by diarrhea. 

That was the last experience with them, needless to mention...I haven't had shredded pork and preserved veggie rice noodle soup as Won-Ton House left a sour taste in my mouth (and mind).
author: Vanna S.

description: Decent and reasonably priced wonton place with staples such as wonton noodle soup and an assortment of jook.  Change it up a little by adding different toppings such as roasted duck, bbq pork, or beef with your egg or rice flat noodles.  Good side dishes include turnip cake (lor bat go), fried curly rice noodle rolls (jin cheung fun), and a small plate of greens with oyster sauce.  Man, how do you translate all these dishes into simple english?
author: Dave S.

description: there's a waitress there that has a haircut that looks like a storm trooper helmet from Star Wars.  back in high school we used to call her Helmet Head.  She still has the same haircut.  the food is ok, but the draw is that it's open relatively late and cheap.  if you want better won ton and a bigger veriety of dishes, go to Just Won Ton on Vicente.
author: J M.

description: Traditional hong kong style noodle house with fast service, fresh food, and reasonable prices.  I typically order the fish congee (jook), won ton noodle soup, or the ginger chicken rice plate with a side of chinese broccoli.  Open late and parking is sometimes difficult on weekend evenings.
author: Mike J.

description: The servers are really sweet. food is fast, yummy, inexpensive. i love the braised noodles (shanghai noodles).
author: Diana T.

description: Not a complaint after all these years.  GREAT prices for what you get.  The portions are generous and everything tastes delish.  Intro'd my dad to it yesterday and now it's a mark on his map for when he picks up his fave cha sui baos next door at Cafe Bakery Rest.
author: Stephanie D.

description: This place is a great value. Dishes taste decent and prices are cheap. They have a pretty nice selection of items for under $4. Some of the items i order normally are: wonton soup, beef stew, turnip cake and pot stickers. If your looking for decent chinese at a cheap price, this is the spot.
author: Steve T.

description: the beef stewed meat is exceptionally tender here.  go after noontime though because if you go too early, the beef isn't ready yet.
author: Wayne L.

description: I love won tun noodles.. I REALLY DO. I'd have to say its one of the very few Chinese items I ever even CRAVE. This place looks pretty decent and clean. But I think they were probably off today, for their won tun noodle soup was SO SALTY! I was not the only one to think so too. The won tun wasn't great (but I'm pretty picky about it, usually picking them out of my noodle soup), because I like the majority of mine to be fresh shrimp. The noodle was pretty chewy though, just how I like it. If it was less salty, I would've given it a 3 star. I will be back to try them again though, because I believe they can be better than this. Oh yeah, most orders are around $4 or so.. pretty cheap.
author: Elaine H.

description: I don't eat their won ton noodle soup but my bf  and I come here for their jook with pork and the 1000-year old egg. Quick service and very affordable.
author: kristin e.

description: Just about everything on the menu except the curries are delicious. The soup portions are pretty small, but they're also under $4, so you could just order two. The rice plates are also consistently good. The pot stickers are a MUST, and I don't know why other reviews haven't mentioned them. Slightly crispy and soft dough surrounds a moist and perfectly seasoned meat filling. You get six delicious dumplings for less than $5. They do run out, which has happened to me twice before =( Still,  I love this place for their no frills affordable menu, cleanliness, and consistence. They also open really late, which makes Chinese comfort food taste all that much better.
author: James P.

description: good place to go if you want some fast, cheap and simple food. service is typical of a family owned bbusiness.
author: mister f.

description: I used to come here years ago and recently came back whilst waiting for my car to get an oil change. While I will never ever get an oil change from that place ever again, I will come back to this old favorite. The won ton noodle soup is super and almost like the one that my Chinese grandma used to make for me.
author: Jacquee P.

description: The wonton noodles here are to die for. But i am disappointed that they dont include the vegetables in it anymore. Just the soup, scallions, wontons and of course the noodles. This place is dirt cheap. But somehow still have great food! I absolutely love the Wonton+duck noodle combo. Whats better than that? extra 2 dollars worth of wonton! okok enough of my love for wonton. If memory recalls, theres nothing on the menu over 7 dollars. The only negative thing i can say is that dont come here if one of your party members dont plan on meeting. As there is a 2 dollar minumum service charge just for sitting in the place if you don't order anything.
author: Terry S.

description: 4 stars for the wonton noodle soup, (but don't order anything else beside the noodles :D ) The soup was rich with flavor, really good wonton and CHEAP! Perfect rainy day meal.
author: Maria H.

description: This place doesn't exactly spell quality, but it does spells value & authentic Cantonese homemade food. Can't go wrong with their wanton noodle soup, thousand year egg & pork jook, spicy sichuan noodle, and red bean ice drink. Chinese doughnut available on weekends only, if not sold out.  I also like their potstickers okay, and their tamales.  First place I think of if I am desperately starving at night since they are opened when most of the nearby restaurants are closed.
author: Kim T.

description: Had the won ton soup. Not bad, but I've had better. Prices are OK. Then when I looked at the $2.00 tea charge per person, I thought that was a little more expensive than I was used to. Nice convenient late night hours worked out for us.
author: Shing M.

description: Okay Soooo.. i'll still go here again because I know what to expect when coming here. BUT today i went and had a Chinese tamale... and as i was flipping over the spoon on the table where my napkin and chopsticks were... you'll never guess what I saw!!! A freaking cockroach!!! scared the crap out of me I jumped like a dork... but yeah the lady came by and took it and gave me a new setting... I should have left.. but I expected it from a restaurant like this.. it's like Sam Woh in Chinatown.. you know what you're getting.
author: Kristina L.

description: Can't go wrong with a $4 bowl of wonton! Service is good and we always get our food in a matter of minutes. Perfect place to go for those who want a quick fix of noodle with soup or those who want to a big meal with a small bill!
author: Albert T.

description: Great on cold Sunset summer evenings or for a quick dinner.  Not the best Jook you will find, but consistent and good.  I also like the rice noodles and Cha sui and a side of gai lan for a quick dinner.
author: Kapeli M.

description: Food here is wonderful especially their won ton. Rice plates are just as great. Some times they can put alittle to much msg, but in all it's a great place to check out.
author: David M.

description: Terrible place! You might like it because its cheap, but you don't know what really hides in the back....  I've been there several times ordering lunch, until one day I found a COCKROACH inside my rice! I quickly returned it to them, and got a refund. Its ridiculous, they even dare to ask if I want something else! I don't think this was an accident, because it happened to my friend too!
author: The Black Cat C.

description: I like this place on a cold night when i don't feel like cooking.  I order their won ton mein.  Its cheap and yummy. And this place is open late too.
author: Sheenie L.

description: There are quite a few won ton places in the Sunset area.  I like this one the best.  The food is good.  The service is good.  The restaurant is clean.  Best of all, great prices.
author: Stella C.

description: This is the place to go for a cheap, quick and satisfying lunch. The potstickers are fresh and yummy too.
author: Jennie N.

description: I ate here with my friends a while back and they claim this place has good won-tons, so I tried it and it was pretty good. I need to come here more often.
author: Edgar G.

description: Best Pot-Stickers in the city. I love the soup and it's superfast. Think fast wonton soup.   Pot Sticker are made to order so they take a little longer.  Definately try this place if you want cheap good soup.
author: Brian B.

description: Another of my current neighborhood's winners.  Inexpensive, quick, and tasty.  My heavy rotation there are the pork and mustard green soup with the thick Shanghai noodles...suet choy yuk cee mein, their turnip cakes... lo bat go, their beef stew braised noodles...gnaw lam lo mein, their duck and preserved egg porridge... pei dan sao yuk jook, and of course an order of chinese broccoli... gai lan.  Way possible for fat me and the wife to get seated famished and leave totally content for under twenty bucks.  Product exceeds price here in my book.  Four stars for taste that exceeds the value.
author: Barry A.

description: SPICY BEEF NOODLE SOUP!!!  It's perfect to eat on cold days.  The noodle is thick, not as thick as Udon, but a lot thicker than wonton noodles.  They put in big chunks of beef.  They're well cooked yet soft.  I normally don't like thoroughly-cooked beef cus they tend to get chewy.  Not this one!  Spiciness is mild.  I've had wonton noodle soups here too.  Shrimp wontons are not all shrimps. More than half of it is filled with pork.  Kind of disappointing.
author: Jessica N.

description: I have been going here for years and one thing I can say about this place is that it is consistent.  The food is average and the price is reasonable so if you want a quick bite to eat, and not spend too much money this is the place.....
author: Tony C.

description: Great place to go for some deliciously plump won tons on a cold day.  Also good for that budget eater in all of us.
author: Mr. G.

description:
the place is great, great cheap chinese comfort food & its open late night until 2 am in the morning.  my wife & i typically stick to the standards.  wonton soup, shrimp dumplings w/ noodles, szechuan beef &/or curry beef tendon & finally the turnip cake.  

this is one of those places that offer a few menu items but they do it good, so why mess with a good thing.  the service is quick, attentive & the food is good.  the restaurant is clean & the decor has been updated.  there is typically no wait to get a table & they open late night.  street parking is typically not too bad at night but during the day it can be a challenge.  they do not accept credit cards or checks, cash only.

typical meal for 2 people is about 15.00.  great place, great food & they open late, not much to complain about...
author: larry s.

description: Sometimes, the parking can suck real bad. With that aside, the place is cheap and it's good enough to satisfy your cravings. Did I say it's cheap?
author: Conrad C.

description: Horrible Horrible Horrible!!! My husband ordered the shrimp dumpling noodle soup. Since it's not normally enough, we order a side of shrimp dumpling soup on the side. When the dumplings arrived, they were TINY and filled with concrete pork, barely any shrimp. It tasted like it had been sitting in the sun to toughen for a few days. I ordered the beef stew noodle soup. My soup was tasteless and the beef stew was mediocre. Not returning, ever! Told all my friends about this too. There's a GREAT wonton place on 32nd and Noriega.
author: L C.

description: the best item on the menu is the wonton noodle soup and the curry pot stickers! they make a heck of a curry pot sticker(should order it 1st because it takes a while for them to cook it). prices are decent and will come again for the curry pot stickers!!
author: Ann L.

description: Good place to go for Simple Good Ol' Chinese Comfort Food!  Everything from their jook to their noodle soups to their rice plates are simple yet tasty.  Sometimes if I felt that I had an exotic or ultra heavy greasy lunch that didn't settle too well with me, I'd go to Won-Ton-House to have their 100 year old egg and pork jook to settle things down and set everything in my world back to it's place...comfort food.   I know I know, sounds weird to have 1000 year old eggs to set things right, but it works for me..  Appears as though they re-carpeted or did something to make the place feel cleaner.  Restroom is still scary though.
author: Doug L.

description: Everything a good hole-in-the wall should be: hearty, Chinese food at super reasonable prices.  The ginger chicken is my fave.  Won ton dishes are about $4-something a pop.
author: Eric G.

description: Even if I'm dying of starvation, I won't eat here. I swear their jook is probably 3 days old. Everything is super oily and salty. The wontons aren't even that big and the main ingredient is MSG. I can't stand this place 3 years ago and I still can't stand this place today. I would rather go right next door at HK Cafe, pay a bit more to have a 3 course dinner for only $9.  Trust me. Stay away.
author: Annie C.

description: 4 out of 5 yelp stars based on 66 reviews....check.....lots of Chinese people eating here....check.......prices that will make your wallet cry tears of joy? check.  But why, Chow Mein Ninja?? Why only 2 stars?  Well...when you walk in, the restaurant has that small, dirty, all to familiar hole in the wall feel.
