Then the smell when you walk in....I'm familiar with the traditional fish sauce because I'm Chinese myself, but maaaaaaannn.....can the overpowering scent of fish sauce be toned down just a bit?!?!  It smelled like a fish army had ransacked the restaurant!! Also, tables are meant to be shared with complete strangers when the place gets busy. Ok, so this place is supposedly known for their huge, delicious won tons. Not so. Won tons are of average size, and have shrimp in them too. I don't know of any other traditional Chinese restaurant that puts shrimp in their won tons.  I think they confused their won ton dumplings for Sui Mai. And just when I thought the fish sauce aroma in the air couldn't get any worse, my bowl of won ton broth emanated its suffocating scent into my already suffering nostrils.  My taste buds wholeheartedly agreed with my nostrils, and begged me to stop drinking the fish potion. But I drank up my soup, just as any other self-respecting Chinese person would do.  $4 for a big bowl of won ton soup, but even though a poor college student, I would not go back into this war zone of fish.
author: Chow Mein Ninj A.

description:
a cheap, yet classical rainy day // night joint, opened m-sun. not only because they serve won ton soup but their teas can serve ya mighty justice -- i say this because this place has the hottest tea i've tried, so don't think you're gonna be sipping tea down cause prepare for it to boil up as it goes down your throat ... DAYAM, i literally had one tear roll down my left eye, and sucky me, had my eyeliner smudged .. don't chu hate that?

my 2nd time stumbling upon won ton..

i must be outta my mind ... on a GORGEOUS sunny day, seriously, i'm going to cry because the weather keeps getting better and better, of course not like LA standards..i'm SO jealous, i SO miss the 80 weather... but SF is just fine with 63 ... 

anyways, it was just one of those monthly cravings when i wanted a soup ... not pho, not no jji gae, but just dumpling and soup ... 

won ton house is not only cheap, but the people who work there are super friendly... everything was less than $5, give or take, and last time i came, i noticed on the menu ... CHINESE TAMALE .. $4.25. 

what the heck is a chinese tamale? beats me. 1st time i came here few months back they were all out, but lucky me got one today... basically, the only difference between a chinese and a mexican tamale is that the chinese one is basically sticky rice with sausage covered in this leaf thingie ... you get to dip it in the soysauce ...  i know i tried something like this before, but it had mushroom and egg which was much better .. i believe it was called jjong (?!?) for you chinese folks ...  BAHH~

i like my messican tamale better ...
author: Jennifer S.

description: i think its one of the best wontons in the city. they wouldn't call it that if it didn't have good ones. its cheap and quick eats. the owner isn't the most friendly but so what... she basically handles the entire floor by herself. she works hard. but regardless. my hot tea is always filled up. it closes really late so i can always depend on them to be open. i usually get the beef tripe and wonton noodle soup. mix it up and there you have it. i would go get the curry pot stickers. thats really unique that a lot of places don't have. i usually come out of there really full but satisfied.
author: Darren C.

description: My friend brought me here for a late night dinner because he told me it was cheap and fast.  Almost everything was around $5-$6.  Given the portions aren't the biggest but you can still get full.  The great things here I like are the beef brisket over braised noodle.  They give you the great nice fatty pieces that you just want to chew and tear into.  Also, the curry pot stickers are awesome.  I've introduced some of my friends to this place and they love how fast, cheap, and good the food is.  Big fan of this place!
author: J L.

description: I so wanted won ton fun. When we arrived right off the plane from Vegas, that was what we were hungering for. When we arrived, I asked for won ton fun and she said that she didn't have anymore fun. I was like huh? You're a won ton house, but no fun? Then she was like I can put ho fun in it instead. Then I was really confused, i was like isn't that what asked for? So by then I just wanted to eat and agreed. So to my surprise when my food came the won ton was in there,but the ho fun noodle wasn't what I expected. It wasn't the plain ho fun, but the thicker one with the dried shrimp and scallions in the it. I like that type of ho fun, but I always eat it with lightly fried with hoi sin sauce.I actually didn't like it too much with that type of noodle. It was still edible, but I prefer the plain ho fun better. The broth was really good. Light ,not greasy at all.  Th won ton was a pretty good sized portion, took at least 2 to 3 bites to finish 1 won ton off  and plenty in the bowl. I didn't finish the ho fun, but I sure finished the won ton. Also had the spicy beef tribe, I thought the beef tribe was cut a little too thick. It came out cold, which was what I did not expect, but I realize now that anytime I order spicy beef tribe anywhere other than during dim sum that it will be cold. I would come back here and order more won ton fun and actually try it with the plain ho fun.
author: carebear l.

description: consistency is the key for this veteran of the sunset rice soup and noodle house ... efficiently served hot food, again won ton and rice soup no more, no less, the turnip cakes are a speciality ... not grandma's, but hey, she aint here no more ...
author: tim y.

description: Hands down, this place rocks.  Been here many times to eat or for take out with my best of friends.  The Braised Beef Brisket over noodle is absolutely delicious and so are the porridges and soups.  Don't forget to try the red bean drink !
author: Hung T.

description: my favorite place to get a good bowl of won ton noodle soup. the price is good and the food is always good! lo-mein is good too. put a little bit of their sauce from the table (the one in the little bowl w/ the spoon.) this is good anytime! and their service is quick and friendly
author: Janelle H.

description: the other day i was online chatting with my best friend mel, i asked her what she ate for dinner, she said, won-tons. i said, yuuum, i want some won tons! so me and mel went to get some at a restarunt on irving, and they are no where compared to won-ton house! they're bowl was way too big and sooo not enough won-tons! but at won-ton house, its the most flavorable, the one with more taste, the right size bowls and just the best won-tons all around! i love there won ton's!!! they're soo flavorable! got soo much taste! the best won tons ive ever ate so far! well maybe next to my grandmas, but its still the best!! im gonna have some tonight for dinner! YUUUUM! won tons!
author: Annie Y.

description: won ton is good.. with some hot sauce.. their pot stickers are crispy and oily, but its delicious... price there are cheap.. only four bucks.. they have rice plate.. too...
author: Lily T.

description: I have to give Won-Ton House 5 stars. Not because their won-ton or other food is spectacular, but because like a good friend to cry on, it's always there. When you're trapped, cold and hungry in the Sunset, and you're sick of all the "pad" dishes at King of Thai (which closes at 1am), you can get some good hearty won-ton or noodles here. Late-night restaurants are slim in the Sunset, and this place closes Monday - Saturday at 12 am, and Sunday at 10 pm. Their won-ton/noodle bowl are about $4-5, and you can add more won-ton or other items for just $2 more. The beef brisket noodles or just the plain won-ton are good choices. They also have side dishes like chinese broccoli w/ oyster sauce, chinese doughnuts on weekends only :(, and other fried goods. For once my friend and I didn't order like crazy and the bill came out to be $9.22, and I had to adjust my eyes for a second to see if i was reading it right. I felt like i was in Chinatown for a second.
author: Douglas F.

description: what do you order at a place called WonTon House?  won ton soup, of course.  very good chinese comfort food, only my grandmother makes better.  =)  also try the curry potsticker (for those who like curry).  the price is great too.
author: ed c.

description: Cheap fast and I feel that msg buzzzz...... the wonton noodle sopup used to be better but the last time I came here with some out of town guests, I felt like apologizing....
author: J C.

description: The last time I came here was 15 years ago. I decided to come to this place after meeting with friends for old time sake. Won ton noodle soup was OK. Lots of noodles and about 6-8 won tons (didn't really count) in bland broth. The shrimp in the won ton is not as fresh as it once was (think they use frozen now) and they left the intestines in the shrimp, which I unfortunately had a few crunches of its sandy debris.  However, their preserved egg and pork jook was very good - quite smooth and tasty with lots of eggs and pork and it goes great with Chinese fried donut  (yau jap gwei.) Chinese tamale (joan) was mediocre - Joy Luck in Cupertino has better joan with better flavor ingredients such as the chinese sausage and duck egg.  Overall, this place isn't what it used to be 15 years ago. Sadly, the quality of their wontons and dumplings have gone downhill. I guess you get what you pay for and their food is cheap. I will just get the jook next time.
author: Nancy M.

description: Good and cheap. Got a bowl of shrimp won ton soup when I was sickly on a cold night, and couldn't have been more pleased.
author: Will C.

description: I was in search of the perfect won ton, since we had excellent won ton in hong kong. It's pretty good. Everything is super cheap here. Quick service too. I had their red bean drink and it's too sweet for my palette.
author: bob k.

description: This place brings back a lot of fun memories from when I was going to SF State. This is a cozy hole in the wall type of place and often you end up seeing the same faces and run into friends from school late at night. Price is really cheap, and the food is not bad. I mean, for the price, you can't really expect a gourmet meal. Great place to hang out with a few good friends when it's late and other places are already closed.
author: Anton C.

description: i really like this place. my dad took me here a few times, but their noodle soups are so tasty! it's actually pretty crowded during the weekends though, but then again, there's not that many tables, so it doesn't seem to make a ruckus while eating. but do look forward to random lion dancing around the streets, because they come in sometimes, and it gets loud, and they fire up the firecrackers, and the smoke lingers in the air while you're eating. kinda ickky.  so yeahh. but dont worry, it doesn't happen most of the time. haha. but yeah overall, this place is quite a treat.
author: Jasmine T.

description: the won ton is pretty good and cheap. just wish they would put than 5 in your order. the potstickers are some of the best I'll ever had. parking can be tough
author: gary l.

description: When we lived in the Parkside District, we used to come here at least once a week since 1991.  Won ton, shrimp dumplings (siu gow), spicy beef over rice, steamed chicken with ginger over rice, red bean drink, curry potstickers, white radish, jook, gailan, spicy pork noodle, noodle with soy sauce (simple but delicious!), duck noodle, joong -- ALL GOOD.  My daughter can't get enough of their joong - a bit pricier than other vendors but well worth it.  We usually buy and freeze at home - dump in hot boiling water for 15-mins. and you're good to go.  They make limited amount so get there early for joong!  Fat Wong's (San Bruno) joong is huge but not as tasty as Won Ton House's and way cheaper.  Service is super fast here; when they're busy, we get up and get our own forks, extra napkins, whatever to help out.  I give it 5 stars for the cheap eats.  You definitely get your money's worth here!  The Won Ton House, Cafe Restaurant (correct name?), Cafe Bakery (best BBQ pork buns in SF), are all on the same block and owned by the same family, different siblings.  Good people, great service and most of all, reasonable prices.
author: Dick T.
